review_text: this game is so much fun being able to destroy the world and build whatever comes to mind all the while dealing with hordes of zombies and searching for stuff to keep you alive. what a game love it
this game as only added more holes in my walls 10/10

i own this game on several consoles an have enjoyed hours weeks maybe months possibly years total, i have gotten mad but its survival it happens, i play this game offline and online fun even better with friends i even play this game with my wife and kids cross play makes all that possible 10/10
have been playing since alpha 7 the core is the same but so many mechanics have changed its hard to compare version to version which one is better. it is definitely still a fun game. i recommend it.

i played 7 days to die and enjoyed it immensely, especially the mix of survival, crafting, and exploration. the game kept me hooked with its intense nights and rewarding progression. i’ve spent countless hours playing with friends, and every session felt exciting and unpredictable. building and defending our bases together was one of the highlights. overall, it’s one of the most fun and engaging co-op survival games i’ve experience

this game has been though quite a bit over the course of it life. is it still fun, yes, is it different from what it was many years ago, very much so. once the devs get their vision built, this can become a great game, but for now, its just a fun, physics based, survival, zombie fps.

bought this game a few years back and i always seem to return to it. developers never gave up even if the cash flow has probably dwindled considerably since there's no cash shop / dlc until recently and it's been out for years. there's also great mods out there for it. imho not only was it worth the money i spent on it, but i'd gladly pay for cash shops / dlc items (as long as it's cosmetic and not p2w) to help the developers out.
great game tho patch 1.0 with trader nerf was literally 1984

ok, so review time. i have played this game for over 700 hours now and i must say it is one of the best zombie survival ames out there in my oppinion there is nothing out there that has the same feel as this game, the progressio is great and the building aspect is wonderfull. it has a steep learning curve when you start the game fresh and don't know what you are doing, but give it time and it will grow on you. it's a voxel game so everything is a block that can be destroyed but can also be exploited. this game is so much fun, but the devs have been going into a strange direction with the game ever since 1.0 but i still have faith they will make the game even better. i highly reccomend this game it is a must play.
minecraft but weirder, realistic and truly challenging and difficulty progression. with friends recommended for sure, by yourself good luck
my friend kennicon got me into it
great game its absolutely a labor of love for this team good job guys keep it up

7 days to die is the lovechild of minecraft and a zombie apocalypse… if that child also came with a serious performance problem. gathering, crafting, and building feels great, especially when you’re fortifying your base for the dreaded horde night. the sandbox survival is deep and addictive, and there’s nothing like blasting zombies with a diy shotgun you just crafted. but optimization is rough — even mid-range pcs can struggle, and the ui feels like it was designed by someone who hates clarity. horde nights are thrilling, but sometimes you spend more time fighting the game than the zombies. 6/10 — fun moments, but your pc might file a complaint.
it had changed a lot since i played it for the first time and im not sure that i like all of these changes but i can't stop loving this game.
good and fun gameplay. lots to do. only down side is that the devs added unnecessary armor sets.
i have been playing this game since it was in beta, its great and ever evolving.
avoided the game for years because it looked cheesy. caved in and played 5,000 hours. still cheesy but love it so much i started my own server - foggy ridge outpost on east coast! boom! <3

always been a little janky, there's been features added, then removed, then added back but with different mechanics... it's a fun game, especially with friends. we all had a blast back in the day. i've only played solo in the last few years, and i play it in waves, but it's something i can always go back to for a bit of fun. definitely not worth the current $57.99 cad though. get it on sale, for sure.
good zombie apocolipse game, has a few kinks but so does every other game. that being said i can quite easily find myself losing hours playing this. it is much better with friends

making us not able to craft empty jars to make survival more challenging is a cheap cop out. instead of focusing on important stuff and making the game more realistic or better looking the devs do this and further focus on their shitty leveling system. like bro it's a survival zombie game and you're making it a dumb rpg.

farthest frontier is a fantastic city builder. the visuals are beautiful, the atmosphere feels alive, and it’s genuinely rewarding to see your small settlement grow into a thriving town. the survival mechanics add just the right amount of challenge, keeping things engaging without being frustrating. every run feels different, and i keep coming back for more. easily one of the best games in the genre.
in-depth medieval city sim. combat is trash, but can be disabled

great game. ui is a bit peculiar and the game has performance issues, when you reach higher population numbers, but overall you can sink many hours into this, do micromanaging, fight against animals and raiders and so on. it's a mix of anno, frostpunk and cities skylines with it's own touch.

one of the best examples of early access done right. been there from the beginning and the developer communcated their goals well, took enough time to implement everything and there weren't even too many bugs involved! great chill but also demanding survival city building with an emphasis on forward planning, resource production, population management and trade. also big thumps up for no use of ai!
way better than manor lords

mix of city builder and rts. there's some depth to the production chains and tech tree but the military gameplay loop is pretty basic. early game food production is a bottleneck. late game the raiders are overpowered. overall it's a decent game with both easy and challenging map biomes and gameplay modes. there's some flexibility to city layout but there's certain production chains that work better when placed in a more formulaic structure, so the city building part is kind of repetitive after a couple of play throughs. the strategic combat portion of the game is very basic and repetitive after the first five raids. the devs have hinted at future updates and possibly dlcs if the game sells well so hopefully they continue to expand on the core gameplay loops like they did during early access. it's like a more polished version of banished with basic rts combat added. there's at least 30-50 hours of play here minimum. more if you enjoy city building with some environmental interruptions and the occasional raider incursion. definitely a good city builder sandbox game with some shallow military and rts components.

exceptional before release, exceptional at release. this game will suck you in for hours, even when you've finished it repeatedly. there's something really satisfying about it. can't wait to see how it develops.

finally into v1.0 and great to see the game become what most of us thought it would be. highly recommended and now its in v1.0 its time tog et right into the gameplay and enjoy the completed features.

a worthy successor to the classic banished. very pretty art style that is mostly grounded with a slight fantasy flair to it. the changing seasons are beautiful to look at, and the survival mechanics are a solid challenge and very tweakable. combat is a welcome addition as well!

8 hours of game play, gunna recommend the game but it needs polish. the production chains are difficult to navigate (ie viewing recources, how much iron do i have? do i have enough workers, great i have way to much now, feeling) plus the production chains arnt all that fleshed out, as well. no logisitcs ect (remote work camps but no low priority depot) combat sucks, trade hub no auto trade or search. basically the menus need work. as a gamer, im not going to lean into trade, until im self seficient, and if you wanna support the town, you need to do this, till like tier 3. farming sucks, interesting idea, but too much micro management, still aint figured out what sand and clay do.. speaking of, no tutorial. no clear idea what does what. its a over production mindset with this game. could use a que from captain of industry in this regard... graphs are cool, but whats the demand for an item? (am i producing to much of this? oh it spoiled.. oh there is rats now, well gotta pay the rat catcher, is that worth doing?) so problems aside, kill the hostile stuff, and forget the military, this a laid back city builder.. otherwise, similar to banished. fun, time killer, but def def needs some 1.0 polish.........thats why recommend no, even though it is actually pretty good.

it's very slow progress and if playing with raiders they are op'd in the early game and just slow down progress even more. hours of playing leads to not much advancement. feels like a bit of a waste of time.

i like the city building in this game, but they have had more than a year i think in early access and do nothing about the unit controls. worst unit controls i have ever played. you have to manually select every citizen that isn´t a soldier if you want to use them and then there is nothing more to control them. just put them in a place and then repeatedly keep them in place while trying to make them attack. i hate to give this a thumbs down because this is the only problem with the game, but this is unplayable for me.

i love banished, so i'd love to love this game. actually, i'd love to be able to play this game. i can't though, because despite the ui scaling the fonts remain ridiculously small and unreadable on a 4k monitor and a 4k tv.

game takes forever to load and sometimes wont load. if it loads, crashes constantly and you go through the whole process again. i love the style of the game and if it played, it would be my favorite game. steam said no refund because i played more than 2 hours (14 hrs) but over 90% of that was either waiting to load or trying to recuperate after crashing. 2 hrs is steams policy. my policy is when i pay for a game and it wont play and you wont refund, i dont buy any more games from you and i give you a lousy review. sorry, thats my policy.

this game was in early access for over 3 years and whilst they made significant improvements to the game, one of the biggest complaints was the terrain tool. they ignored all feedback and criticism regarding this for over 3 years and released the game to 1.0 with the tool in the same state as it was when they released to early access. why is the terrain tool such a big issue you may wonder resulting in my negative review and inability to enjoy the game? buildings and paths follow the terrain so if you place a building on uneven terrain, it is wonky. this is especially noticeable for the larger buildings. the last time i played the game on a mountain map, my mind broke as i realised my entire town was completely wonky made worse and more noticeable with the larger buildings and upgrades to housing. the other issue is that any ranged buildings and units get a bonus to their damage depending on the terrain height relative to their target. this means that to create proper defences, you have this incredibly tedious, unintuitive and somewhat broken tool to try and adjust the terrain heights. it's abysmal and ruins the entire game to the point that most people don't even bother playing on maps that have hills or mountains because they do not want to have to deal with this issue. i thought these devs would be good because they made grim dawn, but i was so wrong. how can you ignore so many complaints about the terrain tool and not do anything to rectify it? it's the worst implementation of a terrain tool i've ever seen in a game in my 3 decades of gaming.
why cant i make crude weapons myself makes no sense

farthest frontier began early access with a strong core and beautiful aesthetic, but the 1.0 release disappointingly failed to evolve beyond its "basic foundation status." the game quickly becomes dull and repetitive due to a fundamental lack of meaningful progression. the core mechanics are sound, but they do not deepen over time. maps feel monotonous, and the raiding mechanic is less of a strategic challenge and more of an annoying disruption. ultimately, the game offers a competent but shallow city-builder experience that gets boring quickly for veterans of the genre.

in recent years, among us has become terrible. everything that made it fun to play has been more or less removed. the new classes are boring, the hide and seek game mode is borderline impossible to enjoy, and the new classes make the game completely unbalanced. i used to be able to pick up any device in my house and hand it to anyone and say "let's play among us" and they would know how to set everything up without any assistance, could join my game, and would not need to have someone explain every stupid role to them. now it's impossible to join your friends with any degree of accuracy or ease due to the bullcrap new chat system and hurdles the people making this game have put in place, such as making an account to join online games. local never works, so the game is useless without an account. on top of this, when trying to create an account on mobile, much of the time you just can't. among us sucks now. you know those bins in walmart where all of the unpopular movies are sold for five bucks each? that's too kind of a fate for among us. i hope it either gets easier to play or just stops existing.

i genuinely like this game. i can easily invest many hours into it. i absolutely love all the graphs and stats, and how your decisions actually affect the people. you choose to distribute food, water, and other resources. the are random events too, like i had a lightning strike happen that damaged buildings, affected people, and lowered morale, which i thought was really cool. the game takes time, but the slow progression makes everything feel rewarding. overall, i thought it was enjoyable and i can't wait to progress further.
challenging and entertaining. i love the graphics.

old review: "the game has been abandoned. no official updates for over a year. they took the cash and ran. yet another "early access" scam. if the developers and/or publisher provide an update that gives a reasonable degree of hope that this game isn't abandoned, i will change this review." edit - the devs have finally released an update and apology to the community. i, for one, am glad the game isn't abandoned. as promised, i've changed the review to positive. i hope they keep working on the game and make it over the finish line.

so i've been a supporter of this game since march of 2024, and i won't deny that right now the game appears to be abandoned. but at the same time what we do have for the game does roughly get to about where the "campaign" is supposed to end iirc. from what i have gathered is the devs have been working on trying to overhaul everything on the back end to run smoother, whether or not this was just a fanciful rumor i can't say, how long it should take for them to do this i also wouldn't be able to say considering i have little to no knowledge in game design, much less how big their team is. what i do know is that i the game is overall enjoyable to play, albeit rough around the edges and if that's what you like then give it a shot. as for the publisher, i wouldn't fault them for any issues arrising due to the devs, we have seen some absolute slop come out like gollum, but we've also seen games such as barotrauma. all i can say at the end of the day is if you are interested give the game a shot, it hasn't been officially declared dead by devs or publisher yet.
always been a fan of city builders and this one has definitely made me a fan; highly recommend!

this game is very fun i would highly recommend this game to any one who liked frost punk and factoro so far i have had a blast even know its early on in its devemint and i cant wait for more updates to come

after just putting four hours into this game i thoroughly enjoyed it. after reading some of the reviews if the developer would have probably communicated maybe would not have such negative reviews. i complain about early access as well but to me it's like a full release. i have a 4k system it had zero problems no issues none ran smoothly no hesitation. i really had nothing bad to say about the game. it's a city builder. i like the way everything intertwines. the research tree is very large and very dependent upon what you are doing. you can't progress without it most definitely. some city builders require buildings to be next to each other or in the area close together to process items but not this game you don't have to have buildings right next to each other they really don't depend on each other that way which was different. i love that i can send out scouts and reveal the map. in order for some of that to even function properly i had to do research to a certain point which i was very far away from some of it and had a long ways to go to even get to that point, which i found to be fascinating. i had more work to do just to accomplish things that were being revealed on the map. i got the game on sale, definitely not for everyone but i think the one thing i would have liked to have seen is a variety of maps to choose from at the start. if you like city builders definitely a fun game and i do recommend.
edit: finally an update from development team. really happy to see the work progression, and looking forward to future updates! the game itself has a lot of potential to be amazing.

normally i wait until i finish a game before posting a review but in this case it seemed necessary to counter some of the negative reviews spreading misinformation that have been posted lately. firstly, this game is obviously not a cash-grab. no developer puts this many years into creating a new ip of this scope and quality with all the accompanying social media channels if they are just trying to make a quick buck. also, if the negative reviewers bothered to check the discord discussions, they would learn that the game has not been abandoned. having said that, the only way any developer stays in business is by generating enough revenue to keep the lights on so i genuinely hope this game succeeds because even as the negative reviewers admit, the developers have created a solid foundation for a great game. to give some context, i purchased this game last year on the same day that i purchased manor lords. after testing both games, i refunded manor lords and kept new cycle, not because manor lords was a bad game, but because new cycle was the more polished game - it looked better, sounded better, and had far fewer bugs and mechanical problems. i plan to get manor lords once it is in better shape but people need to show patience for early access games like manor lords and new cycle that have small development teams. new cycle is already a good game with lots of potential. as such, it is certainly worth trying out and supporting if you like this genre.

about three hours in, and i’m having a good time. there are some rough edges to this game, but juggling resources, assigning workers, and laying out roads while bracing for storms is genuinely kinda fun. i’ve already had a few “oh no” moments when water or power dipped and people were at risk, and it felt great to claw things back by changing how my resources are allocated. the vibe is on point, and the loop—scramble, stabilize, expand—keeps pulling me along. with a bit more polish, this could be a great game.

there was potential but developers abandoned the game, its unfinished with bugs, buyer beware. as of today 11-20-25, the developers have breathed life back into this game with an overdue but outstanding update, so with that, i have updated my recommendation for the game.

worthy newcomer in the building/colony sim genre! this game reminds me of two classics in said genre - frostpunk and anno, and i think this game doing a good work combining mechanics from both of them. the start is smooth and surprisingly, not overwhelming, considering amount of resources available, but they introduced and used gradually, without creating a situations when bunch of them being dropped into your attention zone in the same time. the game is also not without challenge, the further you develop - the more interconected resources and buildings become, and don`t forget that you need not to forget to manage constantly growing needs of your setlers (if you want said buildings to work of course :)) i`m sure devs can make this game even more exciting in the future updates, and with that in mind, maybe in 10 years we will treat this game as one of those classics in genre, and rightfully so

i found new cycle to be a deep and engaging city builder with survival mechanics and a polished visual style, the buildings look great, and the seasons and natural disasters are very well done and not only adds to the visuals but also impacts on the gameplay mechanics. it has a lot of layers and interesting things to do, blending city builder with survival mechanics, however there are some areas that need improvement at first, i found the ui overwhelming and the controls a bit confusing, but the tutorial helps a lot and makes it easier to understand the core systems. once you get into it, the game becomes really enjoyable. my main issue is the pacing,it moves too fast between cycles, and there's often too much happening at once. also, the population system feels unbalanced, with low birth rates and limited ways to recover when workers die. that said, the game has great potential. it’s already fun for fans of complex city builders and i’m looking forward to seeing how it evolves with future updates.

it's not a bad game. it's not great at explaining game mechanics, and the ending seems very abrupt. it hurts the replay-ability of it. i feel like now that i have knowledge of the game mechanics, i could probably do better the second time, but i have zero desire to start from scratch. it'd make way more sense if (**mild spoilers**) they developed some way to continue at the end with a population that is determined by how big you built out the bunker. 16 hours to finish it, and it's frustrating because the early ending means that you have almost no time to explore the advanced building systems like the conveyor system. i have the feeling that the development team plays the game so much that they have tuned the length of the game for someone that really knows the game. good potential, but still needs work. otherwise, it's an interesting game.
nice and fun game keep up the good work

i can't recommend this game in its current state and i somewhat wish i hadn't purchased it. i enjoyed learning how to play and the concept is really solid. i really like the world map and explorer building, it feels like a throwback to one of my favourite parts of frostpunk. however, there are major game breaking bugs that emerge when specific circumstances are met. for example, one of the maps available to play on (there are two currently) has a river, and you can build a bridge across the river to exploit resources on the other side. however, the bridge will never connect to your village's main road which has a major effect on the resource's productivity values. you can also build multiple bridges overtop of that bridge -- it's like the game doesn't detect it. the tier 3 kitchen is less efficient than the tier 2 kitchen. with multiple users noting a recent lack of engagement from the devs in the community discussion forums (some claiming abandonware), there is no telling when, or even if, these issues might be fixed. that said, this game does have the potential to be something really great. i hope they don't give up on it.
in its current state, it is too buggy and bare to recommend.

abandoned as far as is known. no updates whatsoever talked about been said in the discord that discord is banned in turkey but that doesn't stop posts on steam about updates for the game even if not weekly atleast something monthly. game had/has potential was pretty enjoyable but unfortunately nothing being said will kill the game due to the devs lack of communication. would recommend if you enjoy frostpunk and don't mind a game lacking in updates/any information.

great game that is fun and full of potential. i would not recommend this game be purchased at this time. the devs are not active in the forum and it appears that the game is not really progressing. i would wait until they show more interest in their project or you may end up with a product that remains unfinished

really was digging this game to be more like frostpunk or ixion, but i feel like over the time its been in devoment its moved away from being a hard survival city builder and more towards a chill easy anno like experience. not bad, but just not what i was expecting.

the game is a complete clone of frostpunk. unfortunately, this game lacks the vibe and elegance of frostpunk. the immersion is good, but the story is not as engaging and challenging as it is in frostpunk. the only positive aspect is that the map is much larger, but this does not make the game more interesting. 7 of 10

they did finally do an update to the game, however i am going to take 16 months to even bother looking into changing my review. i was holding off reviewing until i knew if the game was even going to make it to 1.0. currently 14 months and zero updates to the main branch. back in march 2025 they did make update to the experimental branch. no communication since then. i would honestly hold off on this game until full release, if it even makes it there. if you pay attention to some of the recent reviews, similar formats, different words, but same key points on each. the game play is fun, but it most likely will not be finished. do not be fooled by the "recent rush" of positive reviews. it is easy for a developer to give some keys out in turn for positive reviews, or even possible bots. response to developer: thank you for the information. however i think this information would be more helpful to many if you made a proper announcement on steam. i do not think your response here will make anyone dismiss the fact you have remained silent and no updates have come in a long time.
its ok and i would see it thru but major flaw is the power. you need 100+ windmills just to really start the game. really looks dumbs makes it not fun. even the wind turbines do little more.

the beginning of the game is good, the end not so much. highways, railways and conveyors need a bit of a makeover to be better placed, actually the roads too, they are built on top of each other, they should be better connected. the placement of conveyor belts is not user friendly like in other similar games. however, what spoiled the experience was the dying population. this could use a serious overhaul. according to the game stats i have everything, food, medicine, clothes, basic rations and i still have 10% dead population and low health. uninstalled for now, maybe i'll come back in a few years.

game becomes quite boring and repetitive early on. all new tech requires more and more workforce, which requires more food, which requires more resources, which requires more workforce (and water). you just repeat the cycle over and over again until it becomes too boring. there is no story to push forward. only the endless production quotas. game's ui does not make it easy to manage the production as all the information is hidden and one has to choose what resources are visible from top bar and what are not. you just constantly change resources to see what you are producing too little and again repeat the cycle.

the gameplay loop isn't very engaging currently. researching isn't particularly fun, i would have enjoyed a proper research tree instead of just bulk unlocking things in the current manner. not being able to queue up research is a pain as well, so you have to remember what the material requirements are for the research and then manually go in and queue it up when you have everything. overall though you just feel very disconnected from the citizen. you need to manually go in and check up on morale constantly, because there's no indicator on the main display. it's no apparent what the morale sinks are, since before their morale was perfect and suddenly it's going down. even though they are all fed, have health care, roof over their head etc. in it's current state it's just on the boring side for me so it's a "no" for now

[b]kamgusta's mini review[/b] the card rogue-lite everyone talks about. i understand why it's so popular, as almost everybody knows how to play cards and make a "double", a "three of a kind" or a "flush". runs are also quite short and the high randomness makes all of them quite different. as a roguelike and/or deck-building game, it has big flaws: you aren't in full control of your deck (uncertainty and randomness are unavoidable) and the stacking of bonuses ([b]+[/b]chip, [b]+[/b]multi, [b]x[/b]multi) should have been clearer and better balanced. you can get to the point where a single card (a "high") scores more than a "royal flush", erasing all the fun of a card game. game also lacks meta-progression, you just unlock more bonuses to be find on your runs. runs are too short to build your deck or create long-term strategies - you are forced to just hope for good cards and push your luck. best strategies focus only on gaining a lot of money to be able to reroll and trying to get (pray the rng god) that couple uber bonuses. for all those reasons, it's not the masterpiece some people talks about and i only recommend it for casual players (in that case, add +2 to the score). it is what it is: a casual, short-lenght, mobile game. [b]best played with mouse recommended buy price: 5$ score: 5,5/10[/b]

this game is hands down one of the best rtss in existence. it's hard to really express how well throughout and built this game is. this game being 26 years old at the time of this review and still being extremely playable is a huge accomplishment. in some ways this game is even better than age of empires 4 which i have played more(via steam anyway). the campaign section of this game is one of the best of any rts ever. the historical accuracy and the breath of historical eras covered is phenomenal. the fact that this game still gets dlcs today is incredible. this will be one of the very few games i will continue to play throughout my life. you don't have to be perfect or super skilled to enjoy this game (you may want to avoid multiplayer until you've done some hard campaign missions..). there are many ways to have fun with aoe2 and once you're hooked you'll be back again and again. i 100% recommend this game its in the top 5 of my favorite games ever.

edit: the ranked match system is completely garbage and works 30% of the time. some times it just hangs for 10 minutes trying to find a match and when you click to leave the queue it doesn't work, it was bugged all this time and you were waiting for a game. sometimes it just gives you an error message. sometimes it prevents you from finding a match after one of those errors saying that you disconnected recently. sometimes it crashes the whole game when a match starts. i wonder how bad can the developers be to create so many issues in a system that was supposed to be simple. the original game didn't have any of those issues. it's a classic game but the community is very toxic. there's a option to report a player after every match but they don't do anything about it. you get a message saying that your report has been reviewed but no action was taken. most players, especially in the lower levels, will curse and insult you for losing. some players will straight up play against you in team games, ruining the entire game on purpose. lot's of players are afk or just resign for no reason after a few minutes. you end up feeling really bad after playing this game most of the time.

this is the game with the worst match making i've ever play in my life! there's no way to go up in the ranks since the game keeps matchmaking you with the worst players or trolls who quit right after the game starts, and on the other side they match 4 players who are way better than the others. and you can't quit once you match with other players, so you're stuck with them. i wouldn't waste a single dollar on this game or time playing it online, i would maybe play against the ai. i hope someone from the game's developing team reads this and tells the rest. you suck big time!

what kills this game is how utterly broken the ai is in skirmish, not because it's complex, but because it follows a micro perfect build order that follows only the highest of skilled players. the ai is not fun to fight, always beating you to every age and instantly producing units based on counter the split second it sees your units. this isn't good ai, it's near inhuman cheating. is this how we are with games ai now? lazy and just train it off competitive multiplayer? the ai knows nothing but to rush castle/imperial and just spam out units that they counter you with. they aren't even coded to build walls, completely incapable of doing anything surprising. you can say skill issue all you want, but if you have to follow a competitive multiplayer build order just to beat the basic standard ai then it was never good to begin with. the devs claim the ai doesn't cheat on the de but i'm somewhat convinced they broke it and gave the ai cheats for the sake of "difficulty." at the minimum it does have fog of war cheats...

new pathfinding problems that didn't exist in the original, poor squad mechanics, lack of cinematics that existed in the original, removed/modified difficulties and maps, and an ai with higher apm than the best starcraft players with precision and screenreading tactics. this version was not meant to help players new to the series get into it, it was made to skip over the engine they couldn't build on with a new one presented in a graphically impressive way while adding loads of artifical time-based gotchas to every map that rely on map memory rather than any kind of information processing in the moment, to disguise how cheaply built it actually is and the illusion of replayability it's a slap in the face to rts players and it promotes negative rts multiplayer trends shifting towards high blood pressure apm and individual unit tactics that the ritalin addicted masses can't get enough of, but ultimately will not help you to improve anything other than remembering a build order and cutting years off of your life trying to keep up with cracked out ai or stimulant abusers in multiplayer. still waiting for an rts that returns the genre to quality instead of what sells an illusion of it with enough decoration to be convincing to most.

this game is really dope. after a couple of play throughs, where you get to grips with the mechanics, the small tricks you can do (like baiting the large exploding enemies into bombing everyone by running close then backing up as a method of crowd control), the game isn't too tough to master. but i appreciate the fact that it puts the power fantasy first and makes it more accessible and less reliant on rng. it also helps that the game encourages experimenting with builds by having 15 unlockable difficulty levels and a huge cast of unlockable characters and weapons that become absolutely busted when you take advantage of their perks through the upgrades you choose. each weapon is distinct; the smg rocks for elemental builds, while the shotgun is great for crowd control and skills based around reloading. meanwhile the batgun benefits from being buffed by both regular and summon attack buffs, so you can create an army of summons that decimate everything. there are several key skills to buff, like base attack, health, movement speed, as well as bonuses to your guns like elemental damage and other effects. so even if you can't get a skill you want to mainline, there's still pretty much always going to be something you can pick that will help you in the long run. and all the fun is from breaking the game. there are infinite ammo builds, summon builds, multiple elemental combination builds (like one where, when lightning strikes a flaming enemy, they explode), and more based around the individual skills of the characters. played properly, your screen will be a crazy mess by the end and you will have transcended mortality into a crazy kind of godhood. it's a total blast to mess around with.

i've seen this story before: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/671860/battlebit_remastered]battlebit[/url], [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/767810/tiny_rails/]tiny rails[/url], and, ironically, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2488510/fatalzone]fatalzone[/url] [i](this one is survivors clone as well, got randomly released as 1.0 and threw away all the good will with crappy (lack of) updates)[/i] a small game goes viral, catches lightning in a bottle, then moves on (usually to a more “profitable” mobile version). can’t blame devs for chasing success, but you can still feel disappointed when the original gets left behind. [b]20 minutes till dawn[/b] is one of those cases. it’s stylish, it’s fun, the pixel-art gun-girls blasting lovecraftian horrors still hit that dopamine spot — but it’s also unfinished, buggy, and clearly abandoned. you can almost see the potential it once had (there is literal roadmap or dev plans in the main menu xd). if you want a polished [b]bullet heaven[/b](?), grab the og [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1794680/vampire_survivors]vampire survivors[/url]. if you’ve beaten that, try [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2218750/halls_of_torment]halls of torment[/url]. and if you’re after something niche and full of promise, like 20mtd once was, check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2283940/ancient_guardians_the_dragon]ancient guardians: the dragon[/url].

game is okay but not anything super special, it focuses too much on the precision part of precision platformer, which makes most of its challenges blur together in terms of feel despite there being a lot of variety in level design on paper. the progression of the game is also quite bizarre, where a large swathe of the level challenges are made purely optional to collect strawberries, a collectable that is there absolutely for bragging rights. i am all for intrinsic motivation in games, but what this ended up leading too is a lack of forward progression in levels. you either go for most collectables, in which case you will be stuck going to alternate rooms to do many of these mini challenges, dragging the pace to a halt, or just ignore them all, and get super short levels that don't feel as though they fully flesh out their respective level gimmicks. this isn't like new super mario bros, where star coins are used to unlock content in the overworld and are placed mostly en route to your objective, which lead to them being useful to collect, without repercussing the pace of the game, yet not making the levels feel hollow if you decide to ignore them. thus the inclusion of these collectables and their impact on the level design ended up taking a lot of the bite out of the progression in the game. aside from that the story is poorly integrated into the game with middling dialogue quality and i found the soundtrack to be the typical retro ost you hear in these kinds of games without much in it to separate it from what you hear elsewhere. also the game will sometimes heavily lag-spike on steam deck, and that sucks.

i've had it with this game after years of repetitive gameplay. i find myself playing the same campaign with a slightly different coat time and time again. both wide and tall playthroughs i find myself ending the game within a generation or two of achieving the main goal of my campaign. the occasional decent dlc paradox drops usually adds only few hours of decent content before i feel i'm playing my average cornwall or bohemia playthrough with a new coat. it's been five years and paradox is still filling the void that is crusader kings 3 with overpriced dlc's. this game offers little to no late game content other than fighting the mongol empire or forming a hegemony. the release of various new governments has resulted in the five base game governments to be forgotten and never expanded upon. maybe paradox will one day finish this game, but it will likely take several years of extra dlc before they finally retire this game and release another empty crusader kings entry. i personally don't see myself playing this game again even when that day comes, because it is has already been way too long since this game's release for it not to be finished.

crusader kings 3 is otherwise an incredible game, but a severe, long-standing bug tied to succession and cultural reformation makes it impossible to recommend. this bug has been known since 2022 and is still active. the problem: when your ruler dies, and the culture head title briefly transfers to an ai, that ai instantly uses the chance to cancel and change your ongoing cultural reformation. the consequence: this arbitrarily wastes 20-30 years of development time, gold, and prestige and is an unfair punishment for a core game event (succession). the ai is operating under rules that the player does not have (players cannot cancel their own ongoing reforms). do not buy this game until paradox addresses this critical inconsistency. the core mechanic of shaping your culture is currently too vulnerable to random ai interference. this is a widely reported issue, confirmed by the community: confirmed - npc's switching your cultural tradition mid-establishing ck iii - ai cancels the current reform culture type while my emperor is a child ck iii - new culture head changes a reform in progress, but i can't do the same! game breaking issue, ai randomly changes culture reformation in progress

[h1]“supergiant game’s take when you mix a sports game/visual novel game and great world building to package it all together. does the pyre burn or does it snuff it out?”[/h1] [hr][/hr] [h2]presentation and narrative[/h2] - deep and very expansive lore, supergiant games’ never miss when creating a world from scratch. - gorgeous art and music. supergiant games aways are top notch with their art and music. - gobsmackingly great world building. supergiant games can just whiff up worlds and stories that all cohese into one big story. [hr][/hr] [h2]gameplay[/h2] - this is basically nba jam if it was 3 vs 3 with ofc more gameplay elements mixed in. - i switched playing on a controller and it felt better. - only played the campaign, and over all it’s a mix of visual novel, rpg, sports game. - going around challenging other parties to the rites while also exploring the world at a whole. [hr][/hr] [h2]technicality and value[/h2] - from the makers of bastion and transistor, supergiant games’ 3rd game - goes very cheap on sale. - versus mode that you can play with bots or friends, via couch or remote play together - would see this as a good couch play with friends, but you’ll need patient friends as the game itself takes some time to get used to. - i played this for the campaign alone and judging only by that, the game is still worth it’s price. [h1]final score: [b]7/10[/b][/h1]

2025年10月19日中午 4h首通 算是首次通关了这个游戏其实这个游戏我当时在晶体馆之后就一直很关注美术实在太棒了 但是20年以前,当时打的开投就没有再打了主要感觉就是节奏还是稍微有点慢而且我对他这个抢球、夺球的玩法不是特别感冒…… 目前玩到的部分就是把郝德文算是第一次送出了下界，当时游戏刚刚开始的时候就是他对玩家展示出了最大的善意所以也是首先选择送他出去 （而且他不强） 【美术5/5】这游戏的美术是绝对没得说的是我觉得简直可以称为艺术品的感觉 尤其是把郝德文送走了之后,车子就解锁了飞天功能,然后在各个世界穿梭的时候会有一种在翻书的感觉,每一个世界都是重叠在另外一个世界之下或者之上的。 而且 supergiant 这家公司很强的地方就是配色都非常鲜艳,但是却一点都不让你觉得杂乱,就真的很好看。像插画一样,每一幅画面都像插画一样。 【音乐4/5】这个游戏的音乐也很好听。特别是中间有几个段落。比如说翻越海洋的时候要走向最终的北极的时候。都会有一段人声的歌唱然后我当时还停下来听了不少时间。还有一开始序章的时候三个人把玩家捡到的似乎后，背景音乐就有那种荒野的感觉 相比很多其他玩完了都没有任何音乐感觉的游戏来说这个游戏的音乐真的算很不错 【游戏性2/5】不得不说,这个游戏真的不是我特别喜欢的那种。就是纯粹为了看剧情换画面才勉强玩了玩它的这个抢球的游戏。 操作非常不舒服因为能控制的角色只有一个然后另外两个角色是处于完全没有任何防御的状态的就很容易被敌人打死 反正我不喜欢而且打完了初次通关之后也没什么动力继续玩下去了先就这样吧

it's my favorite of supergiant's work, easy. practical terms - the game part is rugby with ranged weaponry, but surrounding it is this vivid fantasy world that is built on an in-universe astrology system but manages to escape that gravity to be so much more. its snappy and tactical, then has linear exploration and dialogue between matches. failure in a match is a canon event, and the game and narrative smoothly adjust for your success in your matchups to a degree reminiscent to disco elysium. it might click with you or it might not, but you gotta try it. it's just such a fascinating object, so familiar as to be understandable and easy to grasp yet so unique in so many ways. it really flaunted supergiant's ability to craft an interesting world and unique game structure in a way that is both accessible and wonderfully strange. i love it a lot, and it's a shame they've lost this kind of wonder.

alright i've tried to beat this multiple times (general playthrough) and i gave up this final time. it's still pretty buggy, i had to revert to a checkpoint multiple times because the "exit out of menu" button randomly disappears so you can't leave the vendor. the game is basically basketball with magic, and it's very awkward to control. you can only control/move one character at a time so passing leads you to toss the ball backwards. the only strat is to grab the ball with a fast hero and run straight into the fire, which is pretty silly. likely supergiant's worst game.

this game will make you feel pain like you've never felt. like worse than naruto pain we start off with what looks like an 80s style cartoon show. the plot is written and now your soul is suddenly owned by the devil himself. and of course the only way to clear the debt is to play the game and win it. sounds easy right? wrong. playing this game with another person will drive you both mad. it's not enough to play perfectly but you both have to play perfectly. due to the share screen nature both players have to stay in sync or risk slipping or stalling the screen from progressing whiles enemies and projectiles continue their trajectory towards your little bodies with big cup heads as easy targets. pain aside, this game is genuinely fun when you can finally clear a stage. it takes hours and hours, sometimes days to finally reach the next level. but when you do that feeling is unforgetable. its the kind of game that exemplifies the value of perseverance. for young kids this game can potentially be a good teacher in that aspect. i still have only cleared like 5 levels so far at the time of this writing so theres very much left to play. replay value is great. enemy variety and boss fights are top notch. this is a game you can play forever and keep coming back to

[h1]only play if you get a hard-on for boss gauntlets[/h1] yeah, i didn't play much of this before requesting a refund, and i will admit that this game does not suit my taste. i bought it with only the knowledge that it's difficult, but when i began playing it, i realized that there is zero exploration and 100% boss rush/gauntlet. don't get me wrong. i'm not saying the game itself is bad. it's just not my taste, but i didn't know that when i bought it. i adore the aesthetic of cuphead. the art and design just drip with love and care from the developers. but i just don't like the idea of playing a game just to immediately jump into a boss level. i enjoy games that have difficult bosses but with interesting level exploration for reprieve. i will say that this game resembles an arcade approach to gameplay, so if you're into that, then enjoy. otherwise, stay away and save your money at all costs.

this game is just not fun for me. it'snot that it's too hard, i love challenge, but i feel like every single time i go into a boss, i don't feel in control of the outcome in the slightest. half the time, it feels like the game will just decide that i lose because a projectile was in the wrong place at the wrong time, or i'll be unable to hit a boss because of the way shooting works. forcing me to move in the direction i want to shoot feels incredibly counterintuitive, especially when the only other way to aim forces you to stay still for it to work. chaser was my best friend, but it just isn't good enough to fix that for me. and if you couldn't guess: i also hate metroid games. same exact shooting mechanics, and i don't like them there either. not my game. and i'm willing to admit that. the controls just don't feel natural or even fair to me most of the time. 4/10, but that's entirely personal. from an objective standpoint, it's at least a 7/10.

the most heartbreaking game i've ever played. i'm a sucker for redemption arcs and johnny's is one of my absolute favorites. doesn't mash it in your face that he's sorry but makes it very clear you matter more to him than anything else. the game had me bawling my eyes out more than i care to admit, and it's easy to understand why when you see and recognize the immense love and care that cdpr has put into making 2077 truly special. every major character feels like an actual living person with goals, aspirations, and personalities, with their own unique interests and responses to how you choose to talk and act with them. you can try your best to help people but after all is said and done, cyberpunk leaves you realizing just how bleak and punishing night city, as well as our seemingly destined future is. even the "happy" endings will leave you with a pit in your stomach, but at least some of them were caused by you choosing your own fate. though, in the end, you'll wind up affecting others' lives as well as their own fates no matter how hard you try to distance yourself, because you never realize just how many people care for you. there truly are no happy endings in night city.

preordered cyberpunk and still enjoyed it on the launch version. i was fortunate enough to not run into game breaking bugs on the launch version, just minor problems. despite all of the bugs and what people have said about cyberpunk i fell in love with the game and its story. couple years have passed since then and my computer has gone through extensive upgrades so i decided to reimmerse myself in the world of cyberpunk once more to witness the major updates, the new dlc, and to test my new specs, and i have fallen in love with the game once again. no bugs, many intricate changes to visuals and finally a lively city to back up the narrative of the story. even though i enjoyed the game at launch i applaud cdpr for bouncing back from launch day and im excited to experience orion.

cyberpunk 2077 — 10/10 | chrome-grade excellence cyberpunk 2077 hits like a sandevistan to the skull—fast, stylish, and impossibly smooth. night city isn’t just a map; it’s a living, neon-soaked predator that dares you to keep up. combat slaps, characters feel like emotional cyberware, and the story burrows straight into your neural socket. compact verdict: a chrome-plated masterpiece that voids your warranty in the best way. 10/10.

absolute masterpiece. got this game long after the initial broken release and absolutely love it. story writing is cut above the rest of aaa open world rpg games and makes you feel like your choices actually matter. npcs also acknowledge previous quests you've completed giving them some credibility as opposed to skyrim's hard coded interactions. movement feels smooth and fluid (admittedly i did go for double jump & dash every playthrough xd) and the gun play is solid with a variety of playstyles made to support multiple playthroughs (on my 6th so far). if you like open world rpg i highly recommend this game, though you will need a pretty beefy pc to get the most out of it.

⭐ cyberpunk 2077 – a masterpiece reborn (100% achievements completed) after fully completing cyberpunk 2077—and i mean 100% achievements on steam, every last one—i can confidently say this game has evolved into something truly special. what started as a rough, ambitious dream has transformed into one of the most immersive and emotionally powerful rpg experiences i’ve ever played. night city isn’t just a backdrop; it’s a living, breathing beast. every street corner feels handcrafted, every shard adds to the lore, and every gig has its own flavor. the world rewards exploration in a way few open-world games do. the storytelling? absolutely top-tier. v’s journey, whether played cool, chaotic, or compassionate, hits hard. the writing, the branching choices, and the weight of consequences make every decision feel meaningful. and after finishing phantom liberty, i genuinely felt like i’d lived through a cyberpunk thriller. gameplay-wise, the overhaul patches and 2.31 update turned the combat into a fluid blend of gunplay, hacking, and cyberware insanity. maxing out builds and chasing achievements kept me hooked long after the main story. and earning that “all achievements completed” badge was a satisfying ride—some were challenging, some were hilarious, and some made me explore corners of night city i would've otherwise missed. but together, they proved how much depth and detail the game truly holds. if anyone still wonders whether cyberpunk 2077 is worth playing in 2025: yes. absolutely. this is one of the best modern rpgs—rich, emotional, stylish, and unforgettable

they updated the game with some new version of frame generation. you can't use vsync and frame gen at the same time. if you don't use vsync you get frame tearing. if you use frame gen you have to use nvidia reflex mode and it causes the game to feel terrible and laggy. when you move the mouse it doesn't move the way it should. it's like there is a delay. it just feels awful. i am done with this garbage game. when it released it was garbage. it's still garbage. there are still problems. i see npc's floating in the air some times. stacks of boxes flicker and fall over. i am not going to spend time trying to fix this garbage game. to this day the optimization is still total trash and it will not run at a steady 60 frames per second even at 1080p. i am using a rtx 4070 ti super and a 3700x the cpu that was released at the same time as this game. i even turn all the rtx settings off and it still runs like garbage. cdpr should be ashamed of releasing a garbage game like this. then they act like the game is fixed. it's not and they seem to have made it worse. last time i played it i could use frame gen the in game vsync and no nvidia reflex and now i can't. the game just feels awful now.

i started with elden ring, then went back and played sekiro, ds1, 2 and 3 in order. three felt the smoothest, and it went by the fastest for me. this was the first time that i never got stuck on any bosses. i think that was because elden ring's combat really prepared me for how to interact with this game. all in all, it was a very good time. i have my opinions, as do we all, about which of the souls games was the best, but the bottom line is that you will probably enjoy this one enough to buy it and play it. so do that.

i play ds3 because elden ring is dead. i have 5 characters in elden ring all different ranges with the proper + weapons. it takes 30mins+ sometimes to get summoned or even invade so i just give up. i have 1 single lvl 120 character in ds3. i can invade, get summoned all over pretty much as fast as i put something down.

truly one of the most remarkable games i have ever played. dark souls iii is the culmination of everything great about the first two combined into a seamless and unforgettable gaming experience. rediscovering the world, visiting old locations, and fighting new bosses made dark souls iii feel like a journey that you can only live once. it is a challenging experience not for the faint of heart, but if you have played dark souls i, you are sure to love this game.

52.4 hours, every achievement unlocked, all dlc completed—and honestly, every minute was worth it. dark souls 3 was the second souls game i played, and it delivered exactly what i wanted from the series. the boss fights were intense and memorable, the world design felt interconnected and atmospheric, and the combat struck a perfect balance between classic souls weight and faster, more aggressive action. out of all the souls and souls-like games i’ve played so far, ds3 lands as my 3rd favorite, but that still puts it in incredible company. it’s polished, challenging in all the right ways, and consistently rewarding. if you enjoy difficult but fair combat, amazing dlc content, and that signature fromsoftware sense of progression, this game is absolutely worth diving into—especially if you’re the type who loves fully completing a game.
this game is the reason i'm into hard games nowadays

one of the best singleplayer games i've ever experienced with amazing soundtracks.

dark souls 3 is not my first souls like however it has become one of my favorites. the atmosphere created by the visuals, audio, and story for you as the main character are unique to the souls like genre. the gameplay is incredibly challenging for those that do not normally play, or are unfamiliar with souls like games. but it is worth all of the frustration and struggling to be able to claim and learn from this game and the rest of the series. the story teaches you, the ashen one, to not dare go hollow in your pursuit of rekindling the first flame. the constant struggles of relentless fighting throughout the story create a sort of suffering that you as the player learn to persevere through. the most important lesson i have found in my journey wasn't patience, precision in rolling, or controlling my own anger. the most important lesson was the suffering from this game. after my first playthrough i realized that it's okay to find meaning in the constant torment and suffering of dying, but it's not okay to find purpose in it. dark souls teaches you as the player to constantly persevere for your own reasons. suffering does not make you stronger on it's own, but the growth that follows does.

fromsoftware: fix dsiii stuttering frame drops were not a problem during my first playthrough in 2018. i have since upgraded to a 9800x3d. after numerous patches, performance declined. how? that makes no sense i’ve tried to: -enable vsync/shader cache - unlimited in nvidea control panel -set affinity in task manager (uncheck cpu 0; i also followed a suggestion to disable all even-numbered cpu cores, to no avail). -disable “device association root emulator” under “devices by connection” in device manager -disconnect bluetooth devices, plug in directly via usb -set graphics settings to low/medium/high -update drivers -set screen mode to windowed -run darksoulsiii.exe in windows 8 compatibility mode -rollback on older patch -disable/stop windows management instrumentation -disc usage under 50% (storage capacity at ~30% usage) -install proper pc experience from nexus fps [i]still[/i] drops to 27 or 57 - usually in double intervals, seemingly at random (even while leveling up character, in menus or mid battle) cpu never exceeds 50°c or 20% utilization this is the [i]only[/i] title i experience this sort of issue w/. how fromsoftware managed to make dsiii perform [i]worse[/i] over time is beyond me. no stuttering in sekiro or elden ring so they clearly have [i]some[/i] idea how to program. this specific performance bug wasn’t a problem 6 years ago.. now, there are numerous crash reports & similar performance related posts sited online 2023+ edit: i found nvidia driver 537.58, wired peripherals, disconnect bluetooth devices to reduce stutters [u]specs[/u] 9800x3d 4070 32gb ddr5 memory samsung evo 870 2tb ssd windows 11 side note: port bloodborne. hop off sony’s wang - sales would do numbers

i came to dead cells as a long-time fan of metroidvanias, and it did not disappoint. usually, i'm not a fan of heavy metaprogression mechanics, but the core gameplay here is so engaging that it did not matter to me. this is hands-down the "flowiest" action roguelite. the movement is precise, and the combat is responsive and dynamic. even more, there is variety in regions, enemies, items, and secrets to find. this makes it my favorite action roguelite (so far).

on a metroidvanias kick i tested out dead cells by motion twin. a very castlevania in theme type, with similar feel in action and gameplay, 2-d rogue like procedural slash fest, sounded good and was overwhelmingly positive in reviews on steam so i went in. you play some type of goo that animates a dead body and returning from death is a thing, a thing i was very used to from playing hades, and yes dying is quite common. art style wasn't really my cup of tea but it is creative and it wasn't the pixelation i didn't enjoy it was something about the control scheme... something felt a little jank to me... i cant say i could quite put my thumb on it (no pun intended), but it didn't take long for me to realize i wasn't going to enjoy this one. i'm clearly outside the box on this one as it was so well received, but to be fair i was always much more of a metroid over castlevania player anyways. ill continue on my path, not regretting a stop over at dead cells, but not regretting moving on either.

dead cells is fun, but i don't understand the hype. base game is extremely bare bones. there is a whooping total of 4 bosses, 2 of which you will see every run. there are no random powerups which would introduce any kind of fun rng or broken synergies. instead the only thing that's somewhat random are the weapons and 90% of them play nearly the same. this makes it so each run feels exactly the same as the previous run. it also makes shops kinda useless and not exciting. in hades each shop brings excitement, because you know that you will get something good. meanwhile here shops will at best slightly improve your weapons stat-wise. i'm sure the game gets at least slightly more varied with the dlcs, but that should be the base experience. even less known roguelikes like skul provide more variety. don't get me wrong, the game is fun. bosses are well designed and combat is addictive. the semi metroidvania aspect is an interesting choice and i had fun for a few runs, but if a roguelike gets stale after 5 runs then maybe it shouldn't have been a roguelike. [h1] steam deck [/h1] dead cells runs very well on deck. keeps stable 60fps, fans are quiet and battery lasts long. in short, it's one of the perfect steam deck games.

do you remember playing your first platformer as a kid? there was a disconnect between what you wanted to do and what your character was doing, every step was a small victory, a challenging jump would make your heart race. you would fall, fall, and fall again until eventually, like an angel, your dad or your older sibling or your friend's dad or your friend's older sibling would beat it on their first attempt—and all of that, just the first level. and finally, hours, days, or even years later, you would beat it yourself. for me, that game was[i] scooby doo! who's watching who [/i]on the nintendo ds. now if i was to go back and replay sdwww i would probably slam through the game and beat it in a couple hours. i wouldn't even think twice about the first stage. i have become the older sibling, the dad, the angel. but isn't that a little sad? don't you miss that adrenaline-dopamine cocktail coursing through your little veins you used to know so well? when every corner you turned you would pray for a checkpoint, only to be met with—in absolute horror—a section that looked meticulously designed to ruin your day? jump king manages to gamify the experience of improvement. it feels like when you first fell in love with going to the gym. or when you picked up your favorite instrument for the the first time. or like you're five years old again, playing scooby doo on the sticker-laden, family ds. only it doesn't take years to build your fine motor skills, it takes a few hours. tldr: if you're tired of being good at platformers, and want to be bad at them again, play jump king.

disco elysium is a highly ambitious rpg celebrated for its deep narrative and complex writing. however, its immense focus on dialogue, internal monologue, and philosophical exploration means it is not a game for every player. for those seeking traditional gameplay loops or faster progression, the experience can feel incredibly slow, tedious, and overly dense. while critically acclaimed, its heavy, text-based nature makes it a difficult and lengthy commitment for players who prefer action or lighter fare.

well... what to make of this game? it starts of very slow. frustratingly slow. then it got rolling a little bit, and i wanted to get through it and know how the story finishes.... i can't ever remember looking up how long a game takes to finish... because i just wanted it to be over. then by the end of it. being more familiar with all the mechanics (getting time to advance) i was even contemplating a second play through. but then... just as the referendum was about to start... my game freezes. (the coppernado is back) and i can't advance even after looking up solutions on the web. the biggest anti-climax in my gaming life. so after 50 hours it leaves a bitter taste in my mouth. any tips to resolve the freeze are welcome though. i really want to get to the end.

5 out of 11 bojankles don't get me wrong- this game is both really funny and expertly written, but after completing my second playthrough i am in zero rush to touch this game again. for a game that emphasizes how you can be whatever kind of cop you want, there is actually zero real difference you can make other than being competent versus incompetent; the whole game is just window-dressing. it's extremely tedious and linear once you understand the only thing different about your next playthrough is that you just get new dialogue reacting to the same predicaments ps: i even took another point off my score just for za/um completely robbing the original team's work and parading around like they're the creative geniuses who came up with the game. in an ironic way though, it actually kind of makes the game's themes better

(i've been exposed to more than 5 minutes of this game, i've seen closer to the first 5 hours) incredible art direction, strong writing, great music, interesting concepts, a compelling world, and unbelievably boring gameplay and dialogue. i won't lie, my brain's been melted by the internet, so i could see someone else getting a lot out of this. a great deal of love and talent went into it, it really shows. i generally go for pretentious or conceptual stuff, and i can have a lot of patience if the story can hold my attention. but the characters in this game do not behave like people, and as funny or as interesting as that can be, i'd rather have some kind of emotional core to keep me engaged. it's too impersonal and cold, and the rest of the game is incredibly slow. still though, i think if you don't demand as much moment-to-moment stimulation you could vibe with it. not for me though. also, the communism stuff feels incredibly forced in the beginning. i hate the u.s. healthcare system as much as the next guy, but the messaging feels quite desperate at its inception. it probably gets better later on, i wouldn't know.

the game's story is amazing, from what i've seen so far. the visuals are incredible. the voice acting is some of the best i've ever seen. the sound design and music is quote nice. but the gameplay is ass. it's just pure luck, especially for your first playthrough where you don't know which if the 25 skills are useful (many are vital and many are useless, at least early on, but the game doesn't tell you this). often times a failed check will mean you are softlocked unless you want to have your character do truly awful things (like accept that racism is correct or violently bully a nice person). in real life, there would obviously be other options, including the option to just give up. but in the game, if you don't want to just give up and uninstall, failed checks can lead to you being forced to play a truly horrible person doing truly evil things. and that's not really a game i'm interested in playing nor one i can recommend. i plan to revisit this game at some point, but i will be making extremely heavy use of a walkthough and save-scumming, as i feel this is the only way possible to play the game without being forced into taking actions that i wouldn't take even in a video game. so yeah, if you're the sort that can still enjoy a game with heavy spoilers (cause you're going to need them) and who doesn't mind save-scumming or a person who just has no morals and is fine with being truly evil in a video game, there is a lot to like here. but i absolutely could not recommend this to anyone.

this is probably one of the best games of all time and you should experience it, nevertheless, the company, za/um did the creative minds behind this project so dirty i cannot in good mind recomend you buy it. so sail the high seas or whatever, but treat yourself into the brainrot cleanser that is disco elysium

the interactivity of the world keeps you coming back. it uses real world that is not at all common to games, at least not that i've played. the music is fantastic. the tone of the game is a little odd. strange humor, dark quests and sometimes silly voice acting all at the same time can sometimes take you out a bit. the combat is layered, environments are interactive almost to the point of malleability. you can't change the lay of the land, but you can do a lot on the surface. the only gripe i really have is about the combat. its incredibly long. there's no speed up button. at times i've sat through upwards of 8 enemy activations, and sometimes it takes a while between turns. recommended. there's a newer one which i hear has more va & updated visuals, which you should probably grab instead. unless you're on an older system.

some rpgs make you feel godly by battling big bosses or making heady choices. in divinity: original sin, it's about discovering how you affect the world. i realized the power at my disposal when i used my mage's rain spell to douse the flames afflicting a boat in the starting town of cyseal. piff, down went the flames and up went the cheering arms of the rescued sailors. no yellow question marks or blathering npcs bid me do it; it simply seemed like a good idea at the time. and praise the sun, it was. that's the kind of rewarding experimentation that lies at the heart of divinity: original sin. discovering how its many complex pieces interact with each other and how its complex and amazing spell system can be used to your advantage is what keeps it going for the majority of its outstanding 60-ish hours of questing.

divinity: original sin (classic) is one of a series of turn based rpgs (baldurs gate style) featuring rich classical western style rpg mechanics, a deep story, decent graphics. the developers have superseded this with a remastered edition, yet they're charging a whopping $57 for this. completely unacceptable. as soon as they made this game obsolete, they should have removed it from steam. developer greed knows no bounds.

i dont feel my character abilities do something except damage on enemies who is lvl 1+ higher. looks like game doesnt want me to play how i want to.after finished divinity original sin 2 twice i decided to try this game, i played 40 hours and so tired of random gameplay. for instance i have ability to stun enemy , when i hover on ability icon it shows me chance 105% to stun enemy, but when i use it on enemy who is 1 or more lvl higher then me 99% chances i won't stun him. so basically to much random for me compare to divinity original sin 2 where if ur oponent doesnt have armor u will stun him with 100% chance. that`s why i cant play this game anymore. even if u compare random to never winter nights 2 . first of all this game has more random and also when ur game is turn based it`s really crucial that u miss the entire turn because of random.

just an honestly very good game. i played this afeter baldurs gate 3, and i can say that if you liked bg3, you will probably like this game just as much. in my opinion, the combat system in this one is significantly better than in bg3, and the shield mechanics was very interesting to play around with. at some times the game felt harder, and at others it felt easier, but it was always satisfactory to play, as it had less rng aspects to it. overall, it lacked a lot of the qol that bg3 had, and it shows, such as quick select everything in the intentory, and the movement sometimes feels a bit clucky, but i still had an amazing time with this game!

divinity: original sin 2 is an amazing rpg and a perfect choice for fans of baldur’s gate 3. it’s clear that many ideas later seen in bg3 started here. the story is well written and the characters are interesting. the story is strong, but most of it is told through dialogue and text, so it doesn’t feel as cinematic as bg3. combat is turn-based, fun, and challenging. the game makes great use of combining elements and surfaces, so there’s always something to experiment with. most situations can be solved in different ways. the world is full of side quests, hidden spots, and interesting situations. exploring is genuinely rewarding. the whole game was played in honour mode in co-op, and it was an incredible experience. encounters were great and every mistake could be fatal. this game is a great option that is worth playing. it does not have modern cutscenes, but the story is great, fun combat, and co-op mode more than make up for it. highly recommended for anyone who enjoys bg3 or turn-based rpgs in general. [h2] pros: [/h2] - great game design - phenomenal story - co-op mode - wonderful music - high replayability - freedom in solving quests [h2] cons: [/h2] - lacks cutscenes [h1] overall rating: 9/10 [/h1]

i really hate this game. i didn't want to hate it, i bought it when it was in beta, played it a lot. but i hate it. the combat is awful (people teleport everywhere, positioning means nothing, anyone i talk to who likes it just used exploits to avoid it and lies to themselves about it, etc.). the story is really bad, especially if you have no personal ties to the divinity franchise before this installment (and even then you probably won't care for the truly stupid reveals, references, and twists). the characters have the depth of a puddle. nothing works right. i like crpgs. i've always liked crpgs. since i've played this game game came out i bought larian's own bg3 as well, and i believe that to be one of the best games ever. in part, that's because it has 0 of the weaknesses found in this game. i hope larian's future endeavours look nothing like this game. also the floor effects are constant and miserable. that and the constant teleportation are maybe the worst mechanics implemented in any crpg to date.
a really badly balanced game. also it is impossible to win the game without reading hints in the internet all the time.

the first original sin game was excellent, one of my favorite rpgs. i cannot recommend dos2 though. it has many flaws and lack of improvements that persist even in baldurs gate 3 in a certain extent. the combat looks like a chore, the split between physical and magical armor is very underwhelming since it restricts party compositions. enemies on tactician have like x3 your defenses on same level and you need to kite them, split them, use surface barrels etc to slow them before engaging all at once. the ai is rubbish! they know they have better defense stats so they yolo rushing close to the party without considering their survivability. there are also constant issues with the plane of the game since it has issues with space. meaning you can be on line of sight of an enemy with just a stair in front of you and game thinks something blocks your path. same issues with verticality, you cannot aim enemies in many instances from above but they can from below. secondly the thieving and qol hasn't been improved since the previous installment. thieving is a chore to make money and the ui with so many items has not been improved with a universal inventory tab for all crafting materials. i will finish the game but is nowhere near as fun. lastly half the characters are not likeable in particular prince, fane and sebille are extremely arrogant.

while it might be a "me" issue, the random, near endless loading times make this game a chore to play. one time out of 10 it will load quickly and nicely, the rest of the time it seems to just end up blocked, or taking longer than 10 minutes. and even with the advice of stopping cloud saves, or trying a new game the issue persists. i'd review the rest of the game, but so far i have spent more time loading than playing.

i would love to give this game a very positive review. the actual content in the game is wonderfully built and very fun to play. but it won't work for me. i crash constantly, either loading into the front menu or into the game itself. if i save, i crash. i have tried everything under the sun to fix this because i really enjoy the experience when i get to play. i have: verified game files, put it in windowed mode, run the .exe as administrator and put it in compatibility mode, taken all overlays off of the game, disabled 3d settings, deleted all save files, deleted config files (for re-downloading), fully wiped all data from the game and re-downloaded, updated my graphics driver, turned auto-save off, have nothing running in the background while playing, disabled cloud saves. nothing has worked. it is so disappointing, especially coming from the relatively stable bg3. i hope that it is fixed but i doubt it will be.

not enjoying the combat system. it's doable but i don't enjoy how it creates challenge. for example pre-positioning enemies in good positions and clumping up the party (when the fight happens on a new map), setting them them up to get blasted before they can do anything. or, just making enemies far stronger than the party members, forcing you to figure out what areas to avoid by dying and reloading. the game does a poor job explaining how things work. you get a lot of options and variables without context, and you need to pick wisely or suck. it all results in having to google how things work, and meta-gaming before fights, which is detrimental to the immersion. also, the game world is supremely bleak and depressing; i don't need a game for that.
