i think this game is a good entry point for someone who likes the souls formula, but finds it too unforgiving and punishing. it's definitely on the easier side of souls-like spectrum. the game actually allows pausing. the items and equipment menus are still live, but there is a pause menu where you can adjust basic settings. pausing the game also auto-saves, so you don't need to make it to a vestal (bonfire) before quitting out. you can just quit at any point and continue from there. the game is pretty generous with vestals, so runbacks arent really a thing. there are either a lot of them, or there are several shortcuts back to a particular one, so runbacks aren't as common or as grueling. there's almost always a vestal near the boss. one common complaint i saw that i just don't agree with is the level design. it's not labyrinthian or hard to navigate at all. most areas are straightforward. there aren't a ton of branching paths to get lost on. the levels all tend to loop around and give you shortcuts back to where you started. there's a compass you can buy that points you toward various objectives. the story is decent. i thought va was pretty good. enemy variety is a bit meh, basically everything bipedal and humanoid, which come in flavors of grunt, warrior, elite, and heavy architypes. some quadrupeds. and stealthy guys. character customization and weapon variety is good imo. overall pretty fun souls-like. better than lotf, not as good as lop.
really nice game! really recommend for those who appreciate souls like.

i only recommend the game since i paid $5 for it, which it is certainly worth. the setting in french cities is really nice, although i would prefer a little bit more variety. graphics are a bit outdated, but serviceable. my biggest gripe (and the reason why i would not pay more than $10 for it) is the combat. it is imprecise and not very fun. most enemies and bosses can easily be stunlocked by spamming heavy attacks. hence, it is not very challenging. i would recommend lies of p instead, which is a much better game.

game is kinda fun, unique and intresting, and always on sale. if you get it on sale, its worth it, but i'll be honest, its no lies of p. its a much more janky and indie version of that, you can see the inspiration of it throughout this game, but after 4/5 hours of the game i think i got a good grasp of it. exploration is fun, and with all indie game it is well thought out. ways to get from point a to b have like 2 or 3 solutions if you know how to work around the weird mechanics, which is cool, but speaking of mechanics, they're bad. and i dont mean, im complaining bad, but they're bad. the jump is weird and the pause at the top of the arc is a little too long, especially when you're in battle. the weapon and the attacks are slow, even when using a fast weapon. and there's this weird startup when you run which makes it unusable in battle because you pause for a split-second, then run, and if you know game mechanics you'll know what im talking about. its fun, but after a couple hours, the gameplay is the main turn off for me. story was awesome though.

a good game. much better than greedfall by the same studio, that i absolutely despised. has its flaws and while it is not perfect from a technical point of view, the graphics are beautiful. the french revolution ambience is pretty neat too. a bit clunky and not always super-balanced, pretty easy to beat, but overall a humble yet good aa game.
wasted potentials. things could've gone way better for this game if only the devs cared

4/10 steelrising is, in many ways, a clear imitation of dark souls—from its combat mechanics to its overall gameplay structure. while it captures some of that familiar challenge and atmosphere, it struggles to offer anything truly unique. the map design and story simply didn’t grab my attention enough to keep me invested, and i found myself losing interest before long. it’s not a bad game by any means, but it’s not particularly memorable either. there are plenty of stronger soulslike titles out there that do more to innovate and engage. steelrising feels like one to play only if you’ve already exhausted the rest and are looking for something similar to fill the gap.
this game wish it was lies of p. and it fails gloriously at it lol

the goat: i love the french and paris vibes, the lore, the setting, even the baguette-flavored despair. game combat’s also decent. the clown: too many bugs and worst. isn't optimized properly, it's 2022 game but like pretending in early access. the conclusion: loved the concept, hated the clown performance. game’s good, but the clown side is stronger. negative it is 🤡🤡🤡

el juego no es bueno. combate super repetitvo con animaciones burdas y toscas. aunque las armas son interesantes, rápidamente te das cuenta de lo que realmente vale la pena tener. el parry es demasiado bueno. es tan bueno y fácil de hacer que puedes hacer parries constantes a los jefes, lo cual lo facilita muchísimo los combates. se vuelve más fácil cuando te colocas el módulo para curarte cuando haces parries, y si lo combinas con el módulo para curarte cuando stageas a un enemigo, casi nunca tendrás que curarte. el juego es totalmente mediocre, la historia es malísima y te ponen una custscene larguísima incluso antes de conocer a tu personaje, la actuación de voz mala, y yo estoy jugando con una rtx 4080 y en muchos lugares le cuesta el juego cargar. los enemigos son los mismos, y para empeorar: los jefes nunca se sienten como jefes. sólo se siente como enemigos básicos que tienen un poco más de vida. básicamente, la primera hora del juego ya viste todo lo que tiene que ofrecer. lo único bueno es que tiene niveles estilo metroidvania: poco a poco los vas desbloqueando a medida que vas progresando pero resto... realmente no lo recomiendo, en lo más mínimo. incluso the surge / the surge 2, que ya de por sí no son tan buenos, son muchísimos mejores que este juego porque ofrecen algo distinto. imagínate que te compraste lies of p a través de shein/temu, pero en vez de lop te llega este juego. eso es steelrising.

not recommended in my quest to play as many souls-like games as possible, i stumbled upon this mess called steelrising. on steam it’s listed for 50€, but honestly, it’s worth maybe 10 at best. i’m glad i only paid 3€ for a key, because if i had spent full price, i’d be furious. the game has nothing of value to offer. the cutscenes are boring and badly done, the mechanics feel clunky and unpolished, and bugs are everywhere — from enemies glitching out to broken hitboxes. the combat is stiff, the level design is uninspired, and overall it feels like an unfinished project that was rushed out the door. if you’re looking for a solid souls-like experience, this isn’t it. there are countless better alternatives out there for the same (or even cheaper) price. save your time and money.

i couldn't get into it. i personally don't find the combat to be strong enough to trudge through, and find a gameplay style suited for me. i was unable to find a weapon that particularly stood out as fun to use. when switching from a light, and fast weapon to a heavy, and slow weapon i fully expected to see a response from the enemies when being hit, but i was disappointed. the animations are much too slow to feel rewarding when you don't get feedback from scoring a hit. the frost batons in particular were truly awful to use. in level design, i think there were some strong points, but the heavy use of groups so early on with enemies whose main difficulty is interrupting your actions made the initial experience more frustrating than i could tolerate. maybe it gets better. maybe there is a playstyle that i would love later. maybe the enemies become more fun, but i couldn't push through. i think the company has a strong start, and i will look forward to seeing what they make in the future, but i bounced off of this one because of the feeling of the core gameplay.
after finishing this game i can say: don't.
runs really quite badly. lies of p is a much better game - play that instead.

pros the game has a cool main character i love the design of the weapons cons the story is pretty boring and usually not so important for soulslike, but the combat is easy enough that a good story would balance it out the characters look bad level design is pretty bad jumped down in an area once i didn't recognize and had to do a 10 min runback it feels janky for the jump and run segments horrible performance, 60fps while just running, drops down to 15 when near water all in all buy on sale if you want something to play with time to kill i got it as a humble bundle game but 50€ is just insane for this edit: also suddenly had a choice system in a single sidequest out of nowhere which was never alluded to just bad game design in general that made me stop playing, just get lies of p

this game is bs basically, delay in everything, when i off marking enemy, it makes step forward and then walks where i want it to. jesus, i cant even make make a chain attack without it stop moving and activate "go back in basic stand" animation when im also vulnerable. its just impossible and nothing compared to other souls i finished and its the only time i blame the game for causing the mess.

steelrising started off strong for me, but the deeper i got into it, the more the fun wore off. the enemy design quickly became repetitive, the same basic types reused over and over, just with different elements like fire or frost to make them “unique.” after a while, it stopped being exciting and just felt like a chore. once i realized i had essentially hit the cap on weapon upgrades and certain specs, the sense of progression disappeared. that’s when the game really lost me. by the second-to-last area, i found myself just running past enemies instead of fighting them, not because i couldn’t handle them, but because i was simply bored. looting also felt unrewarding. gear upgrades were expensive enough that i never really switched weapons or outfits, so there wasn’t much incentive to experiment. the whole system made exploration feel pointless. in the end, i didn’t finish the game, not because it was too hard, but because it got less and less fun the further i went. it’s a shame, because the opening hours showed promise, but for me, steelrising ran out of steam halfway through.

i was going to give this game a solid 7-8/10 until literally ten minutes ago. i just beat the final boss. heartfelt cutscene. cue loading screen for post-cutscene cutscene. game crashes for zero reason. i load back in to find my save right before the final boss. sure, i'll do it again just for the sake of rolling credits. except that i go to interact with the lever that opens the door to the final boss arena, and no button prompt. nothing i can do to get back in and truly finish the game, even if its just final cut-scenes and credits. if this doesn't bother you, then by all means it's a pretty solid game. would be a nice and easy introduction into the soulslike (or soulslite?) genre. but both reddit and steam have several threads about this issue that seems well reported over three years ago and it seems they can't be bothered to fix such a small minor issue that creates a completely impassible softlock that prevents people from finishing the game. so i have to say do not recommend purely on principle.

this game makes me wish steam had more than just upvotes and downvotes. in short yes, the game is super fun. if you like difficult games and don't mind sinking a lot of hours in, reading the wiki or watching youtube tutorials, then this is the game for you. you can get it on sale for super cheap and i've played this game along with the together version and will continue to do so. the problem is that the game doesn't tell you how to do anything. don't get me wrong, it's fun to figure stuff out on your own. but how am i supposed to know that giving meat to a bird in a bird cage enables me to make amazing new food or that bunnymen will attack you just because of you holding meat items, causing me to die 15+ hours into my run. i know dying, learning from your mistakes and starting over is the whole point of the game, but it can get frustrating and repetitive. also certain parts of the game like the adventure/story mode are poorly designed in my opinion. it's running around searching for random items on your map for 4 levels, just for you to die on level 5 because you didn't know the final level was in total darkness. reading the wiki, watching youtube tutorial and using mods like display food values, geometric placement, craft pot and minimap feel like necessities for me to enjoy this game.

i am really not a fan of games that don't tell you how to play first. i'm ok with minimal direction, but this game is more complicated than it should be, when it gives you no idea of what to do. it's complicated enough to have several button choices and a huge list of things to do, but nothing is highlighted to give any kind of idea of what you can or cannot do. there are monsters around, but no info on how to heal or fight back. you have to move around and collect materials, but for what? the binding of isaac and dark souls have more "how to play" than this. i understand there are gamers that enjoy this sort of thing and power to them. i'm not one of them.

really depends on what type of games you like. don't starve is a survival game, depending on how fast you are the game will be boring for a while. it's decently easy to die, so it makes the game difficult. beautiful art style, but it gets very boring after a while. it's mostly the same with not too much to do, but again, it's a survival game rather than sandbox. if you're looking for a challenging, 1 life, grindy survival game then this is perfect. if you dislike slow games or grinding then i do not recommend it. i

don't starve, according to its overwhelmingly positive reviews, is a great game. if you think you'd like it, you probably will. unfortunately, i didn't. don't starve is a survival crafter with no tutorial and no explanation. this fits the other-world horror theme of how you suddenly found yourself in this strange and confusing universe. i can appreciate the lack of handholding. is that red or green mushroom going to heal you or hurt you? one way to find out! when i say no explanation, i mean [b]no explanation[/b]. you do not see how much damage your axe does, or how effective your armor is. i found multiple headgears. what do they do? who knows! just pay attention and maybe you'll find out! when you die, you start over completely. the only progress you make is the knowledge you take with you. (hopefully that mushroom didn't finish you off!) while it's a rare take on crafter games to be so unforgiving, i can get behind it. i enjoy a good challenge and mystery. except... man, oh man, is it going to feel repetitive going through your lessons. if your game is going to force players to go through the same motions over and over and over again, you better make sure that experience feels smooth. and [u][i]that[/i][/u] is really the sin of the game. everything feels clunky. combat? clunky. you'll have to "kite" all your enemies. stab, run back, stab, run back, stab, run back. very rote. inventory management? clunky. it all just feels like... "what's the point?" the theme did not sufficiently carry the day.

i don't like games where i feel like i'm forced to do bad things. the humanoid pigs in the game are neutral and can speak. there's really not justification to kill them, but many crafting recipes require items obtained by killing the pig people or destroying their houses. my other complaint about the game is that it is extremely unforgiving when learning. i feel like several of my deaths were just because it was the first time i encountered a new monster, event, food, etc. i know i could brute force my way through by playing and dying lots of times, but i would have to invest far too much time learning that way. one way to address this issue at least with foods would be to clearly explain whether or not a food is going to hurt the character (e.g., +10 hunger, -10 health). my third issue is that it's not clear how much damage weapons are doing. it's hard to tell if one item is better or worse than another. inventory management is a pain. if i'm in my base i should have access to all my items in all nearby chests for crafting rather than constantly digging through different chests.

dota 2 remains one of the most strategically complex and competitively balanced multiplayer games available, offering near-endless depth through its vast hero pool and dynamic itemization. the game’s constant updates and meta shifts keep both casual players and professionals engaged, ensuring that no strategy remains dominant for long. its matchmaking system, while occasionally criticized, generally succeeds in creating challenging and rewarding games that test mechanical skill and strategic thinking. the esports scene surrounding dota 2 is exceptionally rich, featuring high-stakes tournaments like the international that showcase world-class talent and innovation. overall, dota 2 stands out as a demanding yet deeply satisfying experience for players who appreciate mastery, teamwork, and ever-evolving tactical gameplay.

football manager 2020 isn't just a game; it's a deep dive into the world of football management. the level of detail in this game is astounding – from player transfers to tactical decisions, it encapsulates the essence of being at the helm of a football club. what really stands out is the game's realistic transfer market and the dynamic nature of player interactions. you feel the weight of every decision, whether it's in training sessions or crucial matches. the 3d match engine brings your tactical choices to life, adding a visually engaging layer to your strategies. the learning curve is steep, but once you get the hang of it, it's incredibly rewarding. whether you're a seasoned veteran of the series or a newcomer with a passion for football, football manager 2020 offers an immersive experience that’s hard to put down. a must-play for anyone who fantasizes about managing a top-tier football club.

i've played football manager since the very beginning when it was called championship manager. i have watched how it has slowly grown and became so much more realistic over the years. unfortunately is is now going backwards. the database and game itself is second to none. the tactics of the game is awful. managers do not need to change their tactics and tweak every 10 or so games because the opposition figure them out. the best managers in the world have used the same tactics for a decade. altering it to change the flow now and again. they let the opposition worry about them and not changing a tactic because they might get beat. they change the system within the game. fm20 is the worst ever for this. just when you get a decent tactic you have to start all over again. this is just not realistic. because of this fm20 will be my last addition. the game is now dead. i think eventually everyone will get sick of having to create a new tactic 3 times a season. its just isn't a football sim anymore where you pit your strategy against other managers, even if they are ai they should all still have their own character and styles. instead, you are playing against the same ai regardless of what team your playing against. goodbye fm. thanks for the years of entertainment. rip.

+ only usable manager on the market + has original names sometimes + managing aspect of the game works out + looks fun + its deep - "football" simulation itself is one the worst of its kind - game gives useless advices - ingame turorials are minor and not very helpfull - way too much repetitive clicking - no difficulty change - not possible to score a goal if your tactic settings wont pass the in game goal calculation - hardcoded scoring possibilities - low tier managing stuff can't be automated 300+ hours in, still feel very uncomfortable watching this game simulation and my strikers missing 95% of chances while although playing like messi in the passing departement. game itself gives useless advices on how i should start my games, which are most of the time tactics i never trained before and therefore will loose me games. although i have a strong feeling that goals are only calculated by current values like player abilities + tactic setting and not the game evolution itself. that is why you will see 60-1 chances and 80% possession for your team on a regular basis but only 0-0 these games. changing the tactic in game is although not thought through. lots of clicking and annoying window switching will happen too you. the managing aspect of the game can be fun if you are kind enough to overlook the heavy repetive clicking which makes this game a clicker in some way. the heart of the game, the engine is the worst. it ruins most of the fun of this game. how its programmed and how its presents football is like the beginning of football coming to pc in the 90's. fifa did a better job simulating football in 2001 than this does 20 years later.

this was my first fromsoft game, and probably one of my top ten games in general. super fun once you get the hang of it, and i really really love delving into the lore of it all. certainly a good start if you're looking to try a souls game or soulslike, but don't know where to start. the open world aspect means you can leave and come back later if you feel stuck on a boss or area, so you aren't forced to fight something if you aren't having a great time. of course, that doesn't mean it's easy; it's still a hard game, no matter where you go, but the option to go wherever you want (for the most part) makes it a fun experience. also very fun to read messages from other people, and leave some of your own. dog ahead :)

a world that pulls you in... hours played: 21.4 hrs (at time of review) recommended? 👍 yes after 21.4 hours, i can confidently say elden ring is one of the most immersive experiences i’ve had in gaming. the world feels alive — every corner hides something worth discovering, whether it’s a new boss, a hidden dungeon, or just breathtaking scenery. the combat is punishing but fair, and every victory feels earned. what really stands out is the freedom: you’re never forced down a single path. i’ve spent hours just exploring, finding my own way, and still feel like i’ve only scratched the surface. the sense of scale and mystery keeps me hooked, and i’m loving every moment. if you enjoy challenging combat, deep lore, and a world that rewards curiosity, elden ring is absolutely worth it.

if you care about good story telling or a compelling narrative this is not the game for you. not because the story is convoluted, or because it's hard to follow, but because it is utterly and absolutely meaningless. nothing you do matters in the end. characters act as if nothing changed, literally, they act like you didn't actually do anything, likr they didn't even notice it, despite you supposedly having just completely turned the world on its head. nope, not even some cheap repetitive filler comment from the very few characters left hanging around. they say these games are punishing, the gameplay is fine, the most punishing part is how little care was put into having any sort of closure to a somewhat decent adventure. having finished the game more than once, and being disappointed more than once, i cannot recommend this game, based on *my* perspective. if you want a challenging game, with interesting (but completely meaningless) lore, it's a decent game.

i can’t quite see the appeal of this game. as a roguelike, its rng design feels off. there’s a large pool of weapons, but in practice they barely differ beyond dps. meanwhile, the maps, enemy encounters, and bosses vary so little that runs feel like pre-designed stages rather than true roguelike experiences. character building also feels shallow: you rarely get meaningful choices at chests or shops—most of the time you’re stuck with a simple take-it-or-leave-it decision.

i do enjoy this game but i could never recommend this game to anyone, its too blatantly unfair and reliant on rng to a degree that makes ftl look easy in comparison. 1. the camera is crap, you can't see the whole room in a lot of cases and then get clapped by multiple enemies who cover the entire room with bullets. 2. the chests are so random that the chests themselves don't even matter what tier they are. 3. the enemies health scaling is insane considering how rare ammo drops are. 4. while most bosses are perfectly learnable there are some whose attacks are purely random and make them just rage inducing like gattling gull and ammoconda. 5. while i get that unlocking guns and stuff makes it easier as you unlock better ones they are just so expensive and there are so many that you are expected to play hundreds of hours just to get to that point. 6. final complaint is there are zero explanations on anything, you want to know what something does then you have to go to the wiki. i still find the game fun but its just too unbalanced to be able to recommend this game, i don't this it deserves the thumb down i gave it but it definitely doesn't deserve a thumbs up just wish there was a neutral option but since there isn't its definitely more towards thumbs down.

i don't really know what this game is about. i feel like the message underneath the game is a serious one, and certainly existential at that, but it's honestly lost on me. i want to like it for being different and interesting, but i'm having a hard time doing just that in the face of obscurity. at the end of the day...i like it? i guess?

far from being worth 10 dollar obviously, but not a bad game / experience at all! (imo) i got it for a small price on humble so i am happy i have this game. maybe i'd be pissed if i did pay 10 bucks tho...
this game is not for the "average" game player. i love this game, however!!!
a very thought provoking game. even better if you know about computers. a little sad.
interesting concept. not bad storyboard for the concept. video effects can cause nausea.

a story about life, death, and acceptance. the combat gameplay isn't very good, but the character development and story are. it is very psychological-oriented, so you may not like it as much as i did.
there is no fighting the inevitable extermination.

this little indie gem is actually an interesting game. it gave me a feeling of futility and wonderment. the first few playthroughs can make you a little lost but the setting in which it takes place is dark. if you know anything about processors and how they operate, this games gets you thinking about entities it operates on, however unrealistic it may be. dark, depressing, and a pleaseant addition to my library. 8/10

emogame and emogame 2 were staples of my adolescent experience. they turned me on to a slew of music that i wouldn't have appreciated otherwise and managed to be both hilarious and thoughtful throughout. when i saw that the creator of those flash games, jason oda, had developed this odd-looking title, i was intrigued. so, i'll lay out the negatives first: unskippable intro (that you will have to sit through many many times), boring and awkward combat, unintuitive gameplay mechanics. with that in mind, the game is a remarkably beautiful meditation on mortality explored by proxy through slain video game characters facing deletion and finally oblivion. if you go into this expecting a hack and slash dungeon crawl, you will be sorely disappointed. this is more of an interactive poem than a game, and it excels in that respect.

i am very much in love with the 'indie' genre of games. it is inspirational when i hear a group of only a few people who go through the effort of making a game all by themselves. this game, being my game nomination of the year, has amazing art, an amazing soundtrack, a great storyline and decently appealing gameplay which makes for a fantastic game altogether. the only difference is, it was made by only one man.
artsy and pretentious, but in a good way. play it for the content, not the gameplay.
it's not fun to play and it's frankly pretentious.

this game is over ambitious very confusing and over all a mess of ideas. the main puzzle element of the game is delivered through on screen unvoiced dialogue, the font choice is so terrible that it strains the player to read it. the spacing between the words on screen is so tight that is almost dizzyingly bad. the gameplay isn't very strong if it's even there at all it's probalby one of the worst games i've ever played, purely form a gameplay,writing,presentation and story telling point of view. the game trys to be meta and place a game within a game and break the 4th wall of what it means to be a videogame protagonist and it fails in every respect.

a great premise but i can't recommend this game. i'm all for philosophising and a deep story, but the premise is all this game has. i couldn't really find a story behind constant references to prayer and lightning and very brief discssions of nihilism. tedious gameplay with no proper gamepad support and obscure mechanics further marred the experience. if you want ruminations on computer people - play the talos principle instead.

this game feels like it's trying to tell you a message through metaphorical nonsense that is just complete gibberish. very artsy game, in the sense that i'd imagine the dev's wearing billowy poet shirts and writing this garbage while musing under a tree or in a cemetary. the actual game mechanics are just annoying, run around, read and try to memorise nonsense, get to doors before your timer runs out and repeat back the nonsense to have a chance at progressing to the next level. what i'm trying to say is that, well, some people are going to really love this game but to most people it's going to be a complete waste of time.
the game story is about failing. so the game. interesting cut scene, but graphic style ruined it all. 1/10

i purchased this game based on what i saw in the video trailer. i saw a retro-style action adventure game with a deep, sad, yet sweet story that would make me think about life and fill me with a desire to help this poor protagonist sprite. perhaps it's my fault for misinterpreting the trailer, but it seems to be more like the developer misrepresented the game quite heavily. rather than your typical adventure game where you advance the story by exploring new areas, fighting the bad stuff, and engaging in dialogue with npcs, you have here a frantic experience of rushing to find disappearing npcs to talk to and doors to enter punctuated by uninspired slice-and-dice minigames. on the up side, the introductory cutscene sequence is a beautiful thing to watch, but i could have done that on youtube.

there's a major problem with games as art. you need both the game and the art. is continue?9876543210 art? certainly. is it a game? yes. do these work together? no. binding of isaac shows you can concentrate on the game; while dear esther shows you can concentrate on the art. now imagine shooting tears at esther, and you can see what the problem with continue is. like salmon and marmalade, they work great on their own - but together you just feel nauseous. skrillexquest is a far better game with a similar concept - also by the author. continue always feels like it's trying to hard.

the intro is the best part of this game. the gameplay itself is fairly repetitive, and when i had reached the point of repeating levels or scenes, many of the sequences cannot be skipped even when i had seen them a number of times. i really like the concept which is why i bought it despite the poor reviews. i do not really care for the execution and was quickly bored with the title. additionally the linux port is not very good. no resolution/fullscreen configuration without finding the config file and editing it, unlike the windows launcher. it also does not handle widescreen aspect ratios unlike the windows version.
too much story with not enough anything else. an adequate art style put together for someone to do nothing while experiences an okay story with a good premise. do not play unless free and bored.

i really regret buying this.. it is confusing and really irratating being in the same places over and over...and over.. the font is so robotic i cant even read some of it, but it might be my resolution. you could get a lot more with $10.00 outa steam.

this game is trying way, way too hard to be artsy and philosophical. it's especially frustrating when all you want to do is exit the game and instead you're forced to watch a 5 minute cutscene telling you that you should dance with scarecrows. continue?9876543210 feels like the video game equivalent of those crazy yoko ono tweets.

this is a game about, as the description says, a failed video game character wandering around the world of random access memory. i was interested in this game since i first saw it, it looked like a fun little indie-adventure game, and i was put into a beautifully made and well-run game, though not quite expecting as much action as there really was. it was a lot more difficult than i thought it would be (or i'm just bad at games) and it's very confusing. i didn't know what i was doing when walking around the levels and i couldn't find much story to it which is a little odd for this type of game. of course, experiences are different for everyone and for me it wasn't that good. half the time i was confused and the other half i was getting annoyed that i had to fight off 20 munchy enemies every 20 seconds. the game has a good concept and is beautiful, but it isn't for me and i wouldn't recommend it.

kinda wish there was an 'eh' button for reviewing. thats what describes continue?9876543210. when i first found this game i was excited, interesting concept that i don't think has been done before, it had great potential but fell flat. i was (and still am) confused on how to 'beat' the game, i say that because after a half hour of play it seemed like i finished it, took me to the main menu and everything, i was dissapointed so i played again to find the same thing about 30-45 minutes of play time per game. it's entertaining but i would definitely get it on sale.
when u lose it repeats a waste of money
skrillex quest was much better and it's free

i believe that an idea is much more important that how the idea is expressed. as a conseqence, i am almost always willing to overlook bad gameplay provided a game has substance. contine?9876543210 is the exception to this. ostensibly the game is a contemplation of death, but the gameplay is so awful that it ruins anyting that the game is trying to communicate. specifically: -the instructions provided are totally inadequate. -the controls are unredeemably bad. -most sections of the game have arbitrary time limits. these appear to be included solely out of spite that the developer has for you. -a substantial portion of the game is composed of unskippable cutscenes. it seems like the total length of the cutscenes for the total game is probably less than 20 minutes, but thanks to the awful controls you will have to replay most of them for hours before you win. given this situation, it is probably only a matter of time before some masochist posts them online. since the main point of the game is for you to contemplate the cutscenes, if that happens you will essentially get the substance of the 'game' for nothing. finally, do not be fooled by the trailers, they do not accurately represent the game. if you are truly interested in buying it, wait until some gameplay videos are posted online before you make your decision. the only positve aspect of the game was the music.

the developer said it themself: "this is one of those love it or hate it experimental art games." take that into consideration before you purchase this. if you're expecting entertainment or a pleasurable experience then you'll be disappointed. this isn't like bastion or limbo that pair a deep dark story with solid gameplay, this is strictly the former. unfortunately it was just a bit too experimental and surreal for me. i couldn't get into it no matter how much i tried. the fact that the game bugged out within the first 20 minutes and stuck me in an inescapable room didn't help - but hell, for all i know, that might be just another attempt at relaying some covert message to me.

i played this game for about .... 1 minute, but it took me 10 to get into actual gameplay which was me going from the start to the end of "level 1" to get into another cut scene. the sounds are extremly harsh, the animation is weak ( considering the simplicity of the models the rigs should be super simple) and i had no idea what was going on,
it peggled me all over the place. 10/10.
a lot of fun, only negative feedback is some of the final achievements are crazy to get

i have spent over 700 hours on this game, and i am only at cruciball level seven. come on, devs, is it really supposed to be this hard? it's ridiculous to have spent this much time, only playing cruciball the entire time, and only be at level seven. i am not even 'bad' at the game. am i just this unlucky or something? what am i missing here? this is one of my favorite games out of over 2000 games on steam, as you can see, and here i am so frustrated i am actually writing a review just to express my simultaneous love and exhaustion. :(

i love this game, but fair warning, the balance of luck vs skill skews heavily toward the luck side. anything past the easiest base difficulty is mostly luck, and you will have runs that you are doomed to lose because you can't get the items you need, the refreshes are in the wrong place, or you just get the wrong miniboss too early on. that said, beating a run and being able to jump up to the next difficulty is very satisfying.

a really fun and satisfying peggle-like with a pachinko twist. there are skills and strategies to be learned but a lot of the game is rng. build variety is lacking and some playstyles are objectively better than others, especially at higher cruciball levels. update 1.1.18 addressed this somewhat by putting the more "niche" items that you could obtain from chest encounters into the shop. the game is really fun when you are have a good build and a broken run. the standard difficulty is very forgiving and probably the ideal way to play the game, while the higher difficulties can be incredibly frustrating if luck isn't on your side. overall, i still highly recommend the game and it's a good addition the library of any roguelike enjoyer or someone who enjoys peggle.
numbers go up! making combos are also fun. had to get this game after watching a lot of angory tom

the fact that 50% of the time you have zero influence in the path you take makes it a horrendous experience at higher crucibals...

peglin has great pixel arts design and interesting enemies, levels, orbs, relics, etc. however, i wish the impact of luck wasn't so powerful throughout the game. the map, relics, orbs and even navigation through the map can affect the gameplay widely based on the random number generator. the game design is relatively addictive, but everytime i go back to it and the rng hurts me again l remember why i put it aside last time.
game is fun but some of these peg boards are either poorly designed or completely luck based. losing an hour long run to a board where 1/4 of the pegs kills the enjoyment this game could have.
the physics in this game feels awful compared to something like peggle.

all of the updates have made this game a lot worse. everything was broken so the game was fun, but literally everything got nerfed so you have to stick to 1 playstyle now or else you wont even beat the castle boss. so boring.

this game has a charming concept but i just don't feel it man. the enemies being tied to the board makes the game very monotonous, especially considering how little board variations there are per area. by the late game areas i'm either too under-powered to defeat the beefy enemies or too over-powered to feel like my input on the ball even matters. if you're really into pachinko you might like this game, but otherwise i'd say to give it more time in the oven
the rng at higher levels is just straight up not fun.

as far as i would love to give peglin a nice review, i can't. the game itself it's nice, relaxing, of course it brings the good peggle vibes. the problem appears once you unlocked every character. they are just 4, imo the hardest to unlock was the armored one, but once they are there to be played, the maps are the same, there's no biome/zone despite the 3 we always see. more relics are always welcome, same with game balancing and more orbs, but the game feels bored. i love it, but can't enjoy to play always the same exact maps.

i'll give this game a thumbs up for being a unique game and being genuinely fun at the base level. this game does have problems though, as others have pointed out this is a relatively 'solved' game at harder difficulties, and it's likely due to peggle being a poor translation for an ascension focused deckbuilder. there are not a lot options for orbs that will have a positive effect on your run, and the boss relics are situational at best but usually a skip. skipping most of your run because anything you add would actively harm you is not enjoyable difficulty. the games concept is fun, the gameplay loop that they created is fun, and since bigger number always means better person- it has to mean better game too, the damage you do can scale insanely high. i just wish they put more effort into the difficulty settings. casual gaming: excellent and worth it difficult gaming: maybe skip edit: after further consideration, and seeing the game on the app store for $5, i feel taken advantage of.

rng the game. higher difficulties are just reset until you get a good item to counter the bad things. 2/3 bosses are likely runkillers in all zones. every run is just a fucking slot machine, and i'm not even talking about the peggle part. that has its own issues. the boards are mostly super unfun made to not even work. you bounce into one other peg then hit a wall and fall into a pit. some of the layouts are fun, they seem to have added more fun layouts recently, but that doesn't fix the old ones being just super unfun.

you gotta balance luck with skill better than what peglin does - its way too far in the luck spectrum. many of the balls and items are just not impactful in any noticeable way. getting too many of these dud balls or items early, you'll know you won't be able to get through some of the specific battles later in your run.

i really liked this game, but there wasent really enough content for me. i was able to beat the final boss on my first ever run. very fun, but couldnt justify spending money for that little of content. refunded <3

unbalanced to the point of absolutely ruining the player experience. early game is fun but too easy and the difficulty scaling is really bad. there is no skill. it is pure luck. save yourself some time and don't touch cruciball. it's not too bad but pretty quick it turns the game horrible and exposes every single flaw this game has... which is a lot. it sucks cause i bought this game for early access almost two years ago and frankly it has become disappointing. the devs clearly do not care about balancing, which is crucial for a roguelite. pachinko boards are already bs, this game makes me want to avoid every version of a pachinko board in existence. you can see i've put a lot of time in this game. i bought it on mobile when that came out. i want to like it so bad but its just frustrating.

i want to like this game, i really do, but it's just so poorly balanced that i can't give it a positive review. there are some orbs and relics that can nearly solo the game, and there are some that you would never pick under absolutely any circumstance other than trying to fill out the collection of things you haven't picked before. some events like that too. the menus/map navigation are frustratingly slow, restarting for a required good relic at higher cruciballs is annoying, and there isn't enough build variety, as there is almost always a best build for a character unless you're relying on luck to deliver synergistic relics one after the other. the worst part is there *have* been updates to the balance of the game, but they don't address many of the worst problems. i don't understand why.

i want to give it a mixed rating, and this game is fun until, you hit cruciball 6 or so. from there on in just feels incredibly frustrating to get anywhere. the game will just work against you in these later cruciball levels, dumping you against enemies you have no chance beating, because you weren't lucky enough to get the right orbs and/or relics to get a decent enough build. it feels many of the relics are just bloat-like, thinning out the chances of having a good build and run. when you get the build you are after, it is quite fun. however, some of the level designs and 're-designs' are just horrendous and strips a lot of the fun out of the game.

i genuinely would not recommend this game. play vampire survivors, and then don't ever pick up another brain-off slop game again. i hadn't played that type of game in awhile and kept seeing the reviews for this game - i'm unsure as to how it's so highly recommended. 20 waves on a tiny map with hardly any variability. i'm an achievement hunter so i'm biased because the achievements on this game are terrible, but i just can't recommend this game.

it took me a while to actually beat this game. i bought it near to 3 years before this review because it art. i am sucker for religious paintings or perhaps enjoy romantizing martyrdom, this game succeeds in bringing a captivating beauty through misery. speaking of misery, the gameplay of course takes large inspiration for metroid and dark souls. the game does well in making the game feel tough during certain bosses, though after a point it does become easier (i say in better or for worse terms.) the gameplay admittedly didn't sway me, if i had never played a mouls-like or a metroidvania, it would be completely fresh to me but only recycles these ideas and i am afraid to say doesn't bring much to table in terms of new ideas. the gameplay itself does feel almost like an ign review of an indy game. but, the game's atmosphere, and story is where the game begins to shine and find it's identity. it's a fun (though maybe blasphemous,) retelling of christ. the penitent one goes into world to free it from suffering. though in this game it's done by violence and not by kindness. it's an interesting and grim retelling of my beliefs. it's hopeful enough to not feel like an edgy gorefest and bleak enough to feel impactful. there is some gripes i do have with the story, but since i haven't played the sequel, i think it is best if i bite my tounge for now. i would give it probably a 7.5/10.

what can i say about this game other that is an absolute masterpiece. the story, the environment, the soundtrack, the characters, the art, blasphemous nailed each one of them perfectly. i think everyone should give this game a try to admire the passion the developers really put into this game <3
it was fun, not fun enough to go through and do alternate endings or grind post end game content though. kinda releaved when i beat it.

blasphemous is a brutally beautiful metroidvania that blends dark gothic-religious lore with tight hack‑and‑slash combat. you play as the penitent one, exploring a twisted land called cvstodia, fighting grotesque monsters, and uncovering deep, sorrow‑laden secrets. pros: stunning pixel art and a haunting, atmospheric world. hard-hitting, rewarding boss fights and combat. lots of build variety through relics, prayers, and abilities. rich, dark lore that feels unique and deeply unsettling. cons: platforming can feel finicky and punishing at times. some instant-death traps and cheap spike placements frustrate players. backtracking is often required, and fast-travel isn’t super generous. the learning curve is steep; not super forgiving for newcomers. realistic score: ~8.5/10 — it’s not perfect, but for fans of challenging action-metroidvanias with incredible style and atmosphere, blasphemous is a deeply satisfying journey. most players are very positive about it, but be ready for a dark, demanding ride.

sin. a very tricky subject considering the capabilities humanity has to inflict pain onto others, this game switches the dynamic and has all the people be the recievers of pain. unrealistic. there should be one guy who owns all the land and he should be the one inflicting pain and suffering onto others. this game also brings back my own memories of sin, i remember when i was growing up i would rip the legs off of spiders, the rush you would feel when they were twitching is remeniscent of beating all the bosses but still not getting the good ending because you beat that one boss before the last one holy shit fuck off i did all that and got the shitty anti climax ending

absolute masterpiece. for 800mb the game has so much content to explore. the maps is huge, there are many hidden areas, quests, items, endings, i still had so much hidden objective to complete. wanted to get ending a too. would have much preferred the teleport ability to at least pass over to ng+. will play again in future. buy it you won't regret it.

not just a game; it is an experience. developed by the game kitchen, this is a title that carves its own unique niche by seamlessly blending the tight, exploration-driven structure of a metroidvania with the brutal, pattern-based combat of a souls-like, all wrapped in one of the most striking and original aesthetic packages ever seen in the medium. it is challenging, grotesque, and at times unsettling, but for those willing to endure its penance, it is an absolute triumph.
lore is great. combat is great. environment is great. music is great. ladders suck ass.

it took more than i expected to 100%, can't be done in a single playthrough, it's an amazing metroidvania, it's more gore than i am used to but it's great overall, not too hard but still there is enough punishment to keep souls fans in the game as well, 10/10.

brutal metroidvania set in a stunning, extremely religious city influenced by 16th century spain i must emphasize my choice in the word brutal, as environmental hazards are extremely punishing with stuff like spikes killing you instantly and the bosses and mini bosses have a large amount of health and do a lot of damage to you

balsamaceous is easily one of the best metroidvanias out right now. the dark, twisted lore adds so much depth to the experience, and the sense of mystery constantly pushes you to explore every corner of the map. the art direction is on another level—cvstodia is absolutely stunning. every area has its own unique beauty, and every enemy and boss is crafted with incredible detail. i genuinely enjoyed every moment of my playthrough. going for the platinum was a great experience too. it wasn’t overly difficult, but it had just enough challenge to keep things interesting while still feeling chill and enjoyable. overall, this is without a doubt one of the best metroidvanias out there, and i recommend it 100%. a true 10/10 experience.

it has a great artstyle and art direction, but it's gameplay is too slow to me (i have hollow knight silksong brainrot lmao) i decided to watch the rest of the game instead of playing it and i can clearly see all the love poured into it, if you don't mind the slow gameplay and some at times wacky controls and you still want to experience this game for it's grim, gory artstyle and story you definitely should

dying is not an exception, but merely the way in the world of cvstodia. with its harrowing iconography reminiscent of spain's, and specifically seville's cultural zenith, blasphemous fuses disturbing, yet evocative storytelling and worldbuilding with brutal platforming and unyielding combat.

blasphemous is not just a game, but a haunting and unforgettable religious experience delivered through gothic horror and stunning pixel art. it is a brutal, beautiful, and essential masterpiece for fans of dark fantasy. graphics and visuals: at the peak of modern pixel art. the world of cvstodia is a breathtaking nightmare of baroque architecture, grotesque monsters, and meticulous detail. the animations are fluid, impactful, and intensely visceral and stunning. music and sound: world-class. the soundtrack features mournful pieces with spanish and religious undertones, creating a heavy atmosphere filled with dread. the combat sound effects make the sword strikes feel weighty and responsive. mechanics and gameplay: a perfect blend of metroidvania and souls-like. the combat system is precise and unforgiving, emphasizing parrying, dodging, and correct timing. the use of the fervour meter for powerful abilities adds a strategic layer. exploration and narrative: the map design is clever and full of secrets. discovering shortcuts and new items is highly rewarding. the game's lore, conveyed through environmental details and item descriptions, possesses a terrifying depth and allure. conclusion: blasphemous is a triumph of artistic vision and uncompromising game design. it is a challenging but fair experience that is highly recommended.

never realised how underrated this is, very interesting story and world with amazing art to top it off. fun gameplay and full of small secrets and easter eggs, at first it can be difficult but relatively easy after your second and maybe third pilgrimage. recommended to anyone, as long as they unlikely to give up after dying twice lol.

man i dont even know what to say, i love this game its innovative with its aesthetic the vibes are incredible i was not bored through out all the hours i played one of my top 5 games of all time. the combat took me a bit to get used to since i typically dont play metroidvanias but once it clicked every fight was so rewarding with the constant implementation of the movement mechanics in different ways to get the upper hand. if you have not played it you need to.

it was fine. i'm really on the fence about this. the game is lifted up by its over-the-top imagery, intricate graphics, interesting level design, and delectably obtuse story & dialogues that practically beg a wiki to be written. but blasphemous is swiftly brought back down by the moment-to-moment gameplay, plagued by clunky combat & one-trick enemies. gameplay is king for me, and i just couldn't bring myself to see the game through when so many other more fun games are calling to me from my backlog.

i was really enjoying it at first, and i tried my hardest not to give up on it. but every minute of progression felt like it cost me ten hours of trying to figure out where to go next. i spent more time searching where to go than actually playing. tabbing out every second to look up guides, wandering in circles, and wasting time not knowing what the next step was just completely killed the experience for me. i wanted to love it but i just couldn’t go on anymore. what made it worse was the map. every time i opened it, it looked like a scribbled piece of shit paper drawn by a 7 year old arkham asylum patient. it’s genuinely one of the most confusing and unusable maps i’ve ever seen in a game. it’s a shame really, because the art, music, and atmosphere are all incredible. but when you spend the majority of your time lost and confused, it’s hard to appreciate the game.

the bugs are, to this day, game breaking. especially in the cities, tileset issues cause you to clip through and under terrain, where you get stuck, hitboxes desync from the enemies, damage done to the player feels wildly inconsistent, you can do the same action or face the same attack and take wildly different damage values. explosions are far wider in radius than their visuals would indicate. everything ragdolls you. weapons feel inconsistent and weak. enemy spawns seem capricious, spawning on top of you constantly. until and if they get their shit together, i cannot in good conscience recommend this game.

extremely fun game; immersive, epic, and with tongue-in-cheek humour. gameplay loop is engaging and the battle pass system in the game is generous and free-to-play friendly. some say the balance is off-whack, but i think it adds to the more casual nature of the game. i have little qualms about the game itself; it is amazing and i applaud the devs for the years of development that went into this modern live-service masterpiece. with that said... the optimization is extremely subpar; game literally shuts down my pc with no bsod. helldivers 2 is the only game that does this on my setup. the game literally screws with the hardware of my computer, which mind you, is fairly beefy and was built a year or so ago as of writing this review. the anti-cheat in the game might also have something to do with this. also, 130gb+ storage space is appalling when on consoles it is less than half of that. its not worth saving 130gb of space on a game that has the potential to kill your computer without warning. i absolutely adore this game, but i cannot in good faith recommend it in its current state; not until the devs polish up the game. if you do buy this game, play with caution.

not a fully negative review, but the grind needs discussing... i beat the run for the first time after 20 hours. after another 10 hours i saved an important character. after that? 35 hours later i am still hunting for fucking stupidly padded and grindy achievements that require absurds amounts of items to do. absurds i tell you! and all the events, randomized. while the game requires like 5 of those random random random events that happen once per run randomly, or maybe not. because is random... soo annoying.

boons do too little and don't synergize nearly often enough. you are entirely at the mercy of rng for a viable build or not. hitboxes are way too generous when you're being hit but way too precise when it comes to landing an attack. visually beautiful but good f***ing luck deceiphering what's happening behind 13,459 projectiles, aoes, and 20 different enemies with attack patterns all out of sync with each other. when the dust settles you will be a red smear on the floor and back to the beginning. no to mention all the times enemies move to a spot that cannot be reached or which makes them invisible thanks to the isometric view. in summary, it's a visually stunning mechanical nightmare. take your money to a casino if you want to gamble. at least in the casino you can win money. all you're going to get playing this game is high blood pressure.

don't have a history of playing hack and slash roguelites but gave it a go due to reviews and i liked the artwork. first ten hours were very exciting, but eventually the game turned into grind. a combination of things that i really disliked are: 1. it takes time to get to bosses that kick your ass and every attempt takes time and further you go, more i feel like i am wasting my time clearing first levels. 2. the game beats you by throwing a lot of sfx which makes it extremely difficult at times to see what's going on and react. combined with importance of life preservation it makes for a frustrating experience. 3. the deepest runs happen when i use weapons i am lukewarm to. combined with random boons that force gameplay style i don't enjoy a significant chunk of playtime turns into a chore.

brilliant and relaxing traversal (web-swinging is amazingly fluid and fun), decently fun combat (albeit a bit easy and overpowered (even on the highest difficulty), but it's much more flashy and fun than the arkham combat), and a great last bit of story. the beginning of the game with fisk and the lack of a good showcasing of everything is a massive turnoff, though, and the sections where you essentially just run around and hide as miles or mj are very, very boring, to the point where i began to dread them arising. i also had some weird performance issues and bugs, at times. otherwise, this is surprisingly a very good game, and the end of the story allowed me to now somewhat like the character of spider-man (the final fight was also just very graphically beautiful, even if not very in-depth, engaging, or difficult).

swinging around the city is fun, but there’s some crazy stuff going on all the time. a lone civilian gets mugged in broad daylight by ten masked guys with crowbars and assault rifles. you fight enemies who randomly yell “sweep the area!” right in the middle of a brawl. drug dealers in balaclavas hang out on rooftops for no reason. and so on. i get it — game logic — but it’s a bit too much nonsense. as for the game itself, the story’s average, missions repeat, and there’s not much to do in the city besides photographing landmarks and collecting 55 backpacks — not exactly exciting. meh, 5 out of 10.

if you don't have this game already...don't bother unless it's on sale for cheap. spider-man is famous for his rogue's gallery yet the game barely scratches the surface when it comes to villains. there is no green goblin, sandman, hobgoblin, venom, kraven, vulture, carnage...the list goes on. and miles morales is introduced but nothing happens. the combat & gadgets are cool, the suits are nice, swinging through the city is nice as well....but after a few hours of game time, it just feels... hollow just buy it for cheap on sale. then, it will be worth it because the combat is fun when you unlock everything (which takes several hours)

like many others say, the game is good enough until you realize how unforgiving the checkpoint system is. most reviews i see talk about this. you reach the first really tough boss, end up losing over and over again and are reset to a checkpoint that is miles away to walk all the way back and try again. this is a souls like game that instead of offering you retries, punishes you for dying. oh you lost? now walk all the way back from beginning. also you lose all your upgrades until you reach the point where you last lost. then hope you don't die again to waste more time traveling back to the fight again. it's a cute game, good music, good graphics, fun game play. awfully unforgiving checkpoint system with no retry option for tough battles. quality of life is very low on this game. i may not play again for a long time if ever. i've wasted my money.
the fucking game doesn't have a skip credits button

honestly i don't get why this game is overwhelmingly positive. is it good? yes, but overwhelmingly? imo no. half if not most of the game is running around trying to figure out what you're supposed to do, i don't find that fun. i would have preferred to have directions or a hint on where to go or something. yes exploring is fun, but not when you spend most of your time going over the areas you've already been, running around trying to find what the next objective is. imagine gta v but without mission markers. it gets boring and annoying having to google everything. later on you can buy markers to put on your map. great! just mark where i've already been or where i want to come back, right? nope, you get a max of 6 markers (for each color) for whatever reason. ok i'll just remember where i've been, right? well, what happens when i don't play for a few weeks then come back? already forgot everything. then during boss fights, or i guess in general, if you die, instead of respawning nearby, you respawn at the last bench you saved at. it's not fun and frustrating dying and then having to walk all the way back while taking damage along the way. then there's also the fact that, for whatever fucking reason, in order to see where you are on the map you need to sacrifice a slot which could be used for other upgrades. same thing for automatically picking up dropped coins from monsters, like why aren't they just permanent upgrades? i'll probably still finish the game, but i wanted to share my frustrating experience for a supposedly top rated game.

tldr; the environment is very pretty, but game is dogpiss. dont buy even on sale. in my opinion the only thing that was consistently positive in this game is the environment and the mechs. it is extremely pretty, even though sometimes it's blinding cos you can't turn off lens flare. and the mechs are sick as hell. - story seems interesting in the first few hours, and nothing actually happened during that and then at the last 10 hours they loredump heavily - combat is a little dogshit, the enemy has an invincibility window a couple of seconds after you crit them, so you never actually feel powerful even with all the upgrades you get. and the enemies just get tankier and tankier as the game progresses - most dialogue is trash, and aloy isn't a very easily likeable character. i think this was made during the marvel era sassy dialogue so she's consistently negative about almost everything. - the backseating on puzzles is insane. aloy would consistently tell us what to do before and during it. - and for some reason, to me some of the people are either grey or very yellow, but that could be my monitor being weird.

act 1 is the highlight, though with the card augments it becomes inevitable to win. the "puzzles" are thinly veiled stopping blocks and most the game just gives you the solution. act 2 was fine, though i felt like i just autowon any battle without really using my brain after a certain point. act 3 is a rehash of act 1 but pushes a painfully slogged, incremental-improvement mechanic that slowly pushes the player over the edge of a game that has light strategy, that can feel deep but the decision choices are few and lacks punch when the game checkpoints so frequently.

i do think this game is worth the price and was overall fun. i am leaving this negative so people who are actually looking to buy the game have a warning about something i wish i had known before i bought it. the game you see in the trailer is only about a third of the actual game. partway through your playthrough the game fundamentally changes. i won't say anything else, because i don't want to spoil anything. but just be aware that the game you are paying for might be a lot different than you expect. if you are willing to give it a chance, this is one of the weirdest, yet coolest, games i have played in awhile. but during my first run through i was pretty frustrated with how the game pulled the rug out from under me, and i think prospective buyers deserve to know that going in.

wish there was a middle rating. this is a good game with a lot of heart and passion into it. the problem: it decides it doesn't want to be a traditional card game, but rather try and tell a reddit-tier story and betray its solid art and atmosphere in the first part. the latter parts felt not as nearly as polished and thought through mechanically and felt uninspired to me aesthetically. you either like it or ya don't.

be warned, what you see is not what you get with this game. the 3d card game is a temporary act in the game, then it goes to a pokemon lookin 2d adventure with far worse mechanics and none of the charm the game had until then. i was enjoying what it was, but now i'm locked out of returning to the part of the game i actually liked, so that's where i'm done with it. i honestly can't recommend buying something that will tease you with a fun gameplay style just to rip it away and force you to slog through something that's not advertised or made clear at all. i loath this dev trend of mixing up gameplay styles with no rhyme or reason to it, it just comes across as "i had way too many ideas for the game than what i could be f***ed to animate so we're doing a 2d ags game now". its pretentious to act like we should have to play through the entirety of whatever slop is served to us when clearly one part is better than the rest by miles. i've never played undertale because that game looks like crap, i couldn't care less about the story, that can be enjoyed on youtube, the gameplay is what matters and it looks awful, and because i know that, i can make an informed decision based on my own tastes to not buy it, this game just shows you the part that looks good then pulls the rug on you just long enough into the game that you're passed the refund window. absolute bullshit.

so i was absolutely loving this and was completely addicted, but then i found out that that was just one of three parts. spoiler warning but the first part is the super cool and spooky card game you see in the trailer, then it completelyyyyy switches up and goes into 8-bit, then back to a card game but a completely different and less cool one (i stopped playing once it switched to 8-bit and just googled the rest). extremely ambitious, but just not for me unfortunately. ughh why couldn't the entire thing be like the first part i was sooooo in. welp.

you can really feel the level of care that went into this game. it's one of the last games released before the current ue5 slop era of gaming. the graphics are amazing, and very performant. i easily get 500 fps on 2560x1440 on the non-enhanced version. this level of performance puts any recently released game to shame. if you're looking for a fantastic story driven fps, this is one of the best. i recommend non-enhanced if you care about motion clarity, the enhanced version performs much worse and doesn't really look that much better. (i also recommend looking up how to turn off mouse acceleration and smoothing) fantastic work by 4a. it's tragic games are no longer made by people who care this much.

an unforgettable post-apocalyptic journey metro exodus is not just a game; it’s an emotional journey through a ruined world filled with danger, hope, and breathtaking moments. from the very beginning, it feels like you’re living inside a real story. the characters are incredibly well-written, and every choice you make feels meaningful. the visuals are stunning. the open areas are rich with detail, each region having its own atmosphere—from frozen wastelands to dry deserts. the lighting and shadows are phenomenal, especially in dark tunnels or during sunsets over destroyed landscapes. gameplay is perfectly balanced: deep weapon customization limited resources that make every encounter intense a smooth blend of stealth and action atmospheric music that enhances every scene but the heart of the game is its story. it's emotional, human, and makes you feel truly connected to the crew of the aurora. even the quiet moments around the campfire are memorable and meaningful. metro exodus masterfully combines open-world exploration, a dark and immersive atmosphere, emotional storytelling, and exceptional artistic detail. it’s one of the best post-apocalyptic experiences you can have.

i thought escaping the metro meant i was done wearing a gas mask. i was wrong. turns out, the world is still a giant toxic mess, but now it's got more trees and fewer rats that look like tiny bears. this game is basically a post-apocalyptic road trip across russia in a train named the aurora.

pros: • good gameplay • large maps • high-quality graphics • addition of new game mechanics cons: • change in miller’s appearance • reworked mutant graphics appear already in moscow; the explanation of a “different type of mutation” feels illogical since we are still in moscow • save system – the game does save, but when loading it sometimes places you elsewhere or up to 20 minutes back, even though the save timestamp shows only 5 minutes ago (i'll probably get a bad ending because i don't have the patience to do it correctly five times in a row.") • miller has prosthetics from the start; it would be more interesting to first see him in a wheelchair and gradually show him getting back on his feet (could include 1–2 extra missions)

the game is a plain ok for me, followed by a couple of technical problems with it. first of all, it runs on a separate window instead of through steam which results in various crashes, when alt+tabbing for example. secondly, i couldn't roam the caspian level because the vehicle was stuck between desert particles; i was unable to move it and roamed through the level on foot. story-wise, there were a few enganging moments but nothing too serious nor it had the crisp of the other two installments in the franchise. side-stories, additionally, felt too detached and quite "empty". combat is mediocre with some erratic movements from the enemies. point-blank range can fail and for long-range there were no distinct physics that would result in avoiding the target (or maybe i couldn't identify them) the reason i uninstalled, and thankfully i played two colonels dlc first, is the autosaves that did not happen for half an hour in the sam's story dlc. that resulted in a huge loss of progress. however, that issue was not present in the main game and the flow was fine, overall, i would rate this as 3/5 and 2.5 with decimals allowed.

recommended ✔️ hours played: 40+ steam review: lethal company stands out as one of the most unexpectedly amusing and genuinely thrilling co-op experiences i’ve encountered in quite some time. it strikes an ideal balance between horror and humor — one moment, you find yourself stealthily navigating a dimly lit corridor, listening for any signs of movement, and the next, you’re shrieking as your friend inadvertently opens the wrong door at the absolute worst moment. the game’s lo-fi visual style surprisingly enhances the eerie ambiance without detracting from the enjoyment. the diverse enemy types keep each mission engaging, while the sound design is exceptional; if you notice something breathing behind you, it’s probably too late. what truly sets this game apart is its player-driven chaos. every session unfolds like a unique narrative: - there’s always that one person who gets overly ambitious for “just one more piece of scrap.” - someone inevitably forgets to secure the bunker door. - and there’s always a player left behind during takeoff. the replayability factor is immense, as even after numerous runs, i still find myself both laughing and feeling frantic simultaneously. if you enjoy cooperative gameplay, light survival elements, or shouting at friends while hurrying towards an extraction ship, this title is definitely worth purchasing. **10 out of 10 would willingly sacrifice my coworker again.

i will try to be very objective in this review. this game has brought me many hours of fun and enjoyment with my friends. however, i can’t turn a blind eye to the current state of things. the game, as it stands right now, is very lacking—no significant updates, extremely basic “changes,” and a complete lack of effort to keep players engaged. sadly, it seems to be heading down the same path as many other indie games. what i mean by that is it appears to be stuck in early access hell forever. it wouldn’t really be an issue if the game were free-to-play or sold as a complete product. my biggest gripe with all of this is that this is no longer a small project. the game has sold well and even had a collaboration with epic games. the means were there to continue developing the project and not leave players in the dark for so long. however, the predictable choice was to almost fully abandon the game and focus on other things while the game you paid for rots in early access limbo. in conclusion, as of right now, i cannot recommend the game unless it somehow gets back on track.

amored core is the 6th game in an entry where the last game was over a decade ago made by the people who made a game franchise that still gets used as an inspiration to this day. with that preface, do you like violence? do you like guns? do you like the feeling of cold hard cash after slaughtering anyone who gets in your way? do you enjoy a game where you can freely craft the perfect combat automaton to counter anything that gets in your way without commiting to a specific style? do you want a easy to follow yet deep story which is the polar opposite of how fromsoft handles all of their storytelling and lore in the souls series? do you enjoy making your gundam look like a ferrari? if you answered yes to at least 2 of the ones above, this game is for you. if not, go watch the keanu reeves vid, then come back to this.

i've been gaming for over 30 years and this is one of the rare games that i honestly can't find a flaw with. in terms of what it is trying to do in its genre, i would give it a 10/10. to give some context, i think i have only ever rated crono trigger, metal gear solid, and breath of the wild a 10/10 off the top of my head. that puts this game in rare company. that being said, i don't think it necessarily is one of the best games of all time, i just think it is a flawless game. everything from gameplay, the missions, layout and story are awesome. and honestly i think this is the literal best instance of how to do new game + correctly. it gives you a reason to replay the game while also dolling out tiny bits of new content while doing this. the only other game that might be a better instance of new game + is crono trigger and i put that as the best game of all time, so that is saying something.

armored core: fires of rubicon – review 8 armored core: fires of rubicon feels like a time capsule from the golden age of gaming—a reminder of when titles were tough, gameplay-first, and unburdened by fluff. its lineage goes all the way back to the late ’90s psx era, and that heritage shows: this is a game that knows exactly what it wants to be, and it delivers with confidence. visually, the game isn’t a powerhouse. graphics: 8 —nothing spectacular, but clean, stylish, and perfectly functional for the speed and clarity a mech game demands. the real star is the combat. gameplay: 8.5 —high-paced armored-mecha action at its finest. like the classic entries, it expects you to adjust your build for each encounter rather than brute-force with pure skill, and that philosophy is still part of its charm. the presentation hits solid notes across the board: sound: 8, with industrial beats and sharp effects that fit the world, and story: 7.5, a simple but compelling narrative that does more with restraint than many modern blockbusters do with endless cutscenes. if you’re tired of bloated open worlds and checklist design, fires of rubicon is a breath of fresh air. it’s focused, challenging, stylish—and the kind of game that can make you fall in love with the medium all over again.
