not sure if i don’t like the game or if i don’t like that this is not what armored core used to be back in the day. so take my review as a failed attempt to manage my own expectations. unlike in the older ac titles where strategic planning and resource management were still a thing, ac6 focuses more on mechanical execution of combat maneuvers, dodge timings and overall button pressing technique. the stagger mechanic rewards ultra-aggressive combat style over any type of cautious approach, meaning that the action is extremely frantic all the time. you can spam all your weapons simultaneously and most of the time an effective combat approach is just to mash all four weapon triggers without thinking. failing a mission is not usually caused by your build or miscalculated strategic approach but more often just a consequence of wrongly timed button presses and badly executed combos. mech parts you regret having bought get fully refunded when sold and the only penalty of failing a mission is the annoyance of having to replay the mission again. this is underlined even more with the very forgiving checkpoint system, which on the other hand is really mandatory due to the overtuned boss encounters. having no consequences for bad decisions means that there is also no incentive of getting invested in planning. the linear story is expressed through brief and meaningless radio chatter that supposedly tries to be cool and serious but ends up being deeply embarrassing to mature audience. if you want to have another action game influenced by the new generation from software games but this time with a mech reskin, go for it. if you are looking for the classic armored core experience, there is a high chance that you will be disappointed.

in many ways, the work of a critic is easy. we risk very little, yet enjoy a position over those who offer up their work and their selves to our judgment. we thrive on negative criticism, which is fun to write and to read. but the bitter truth we critics must face, is that in the grand scheme of things, the average piece of junk is probably more meaningful than our criticism designating it so. but there are times when a critic truly risks something, and that is in the discovery and defense of the new. the world is often unkind to new talent, new creations. the new needs friends. last night, i experienced something new: an extraordinary game from a singularly unexpected source. to say that both the action and its consequences have challenged my preconceptions about fine decisions is a gross understatement. they have rocked me to my core. in the past, i have made no secret of my disdain for life is strange's famous motto, "this action will have consequences." but i realize, only now do i truly understand what it meant. not everyone can become a great artist; but a great artist can come from anywhere. it is difficult to imagine more humble origins than those of the genius now working at life is strange, who is, in this critic's opinion, nothing less than the finest developer on steam. i will be returning to life is strange soon, hungry for more.

spoilers ⚠️⚠️⚠️ stunning game, and i love how the models are made like legos, especially the hair, the lighting and environments are simply lovely what a heartbreaking journey and characters development through all the twists and turns that they take. you get to visit many different locations which is sometimes jarring to transition between chapters, but it offers variety as well. sean is a great protagonist that has to assume the role of being both a parent and a brother after tragedy strikes, daniel is the perfect annoying younger brother, and i know that will put some people off but this is what having a sibling is like. i opted for the "happier" ending since i didn't want our journey to be for naught it's quite a heavy game emotionally, and there are some mild issues with pacing imo with how long of time is spent on certain areas vs. others, but i would love to play through with some different choices in the future and get all the collectibles. i recommend this game on the basis that it's a great story, with some fun choices, yes there are some moments that are frustrating but overall i grew to love the characters and the story they've given us. and i especially believe it has relevant materials in it which i am sympathetic to, and is important to pay notice to.

i went in blind with this one. i remember playing the first one when it came out and it was a little mah for me, so now in 2025 i decided to give this a go and was really surprised with it as i actually enjoyed the story and characters and the soundtrack does a lot of the heavy lifting for it. the choices are quite difficult to make and at times even heartbreaking as i've shed a few tears more than once with it. all in all i recommend it to everyone as it's a wonderful piece of art. thank you developers for putting this out there and giving us the opportunity to experience this rollercoster.

i really enjoyed the first life is strange. it sucked me into the world and the characters. i felt there was definitely some jank in involved in the game and the dialogue, but overall it really worked for me. this one didn't. i'm not sure if its because the main characters are younger and i had a more difficult time getting invested in them because a lot of the choices that were made by the characters and by the player felt childish or that the story just didn't connect with me, now i know the leads are children here, so the childish responses and choices make sense for these characters, but it doesn't change the fact that it really felt frustrating watching them make bad choice after bad choice and then giving me the option between 2 or more bad choices. now with that said, its not terrible, it just didn't connect with me. the music is still good and the art style is still the same as the first life is strange, so those are both points in favour of the game. i feel this game has less “game” to play. it felt even more like just watching the game this time around. when there is so little gameplay, the story really needs to hit and i just didn't find the adventure was as interesting as i would have liked it to be. it's not a terribly in depth review, but i really don't have all that much to say about the game. i started to lose interest in chapter 3 and the rest of the game i was just waiting for it to be finished so i could move on to the next game.

do not buy this i got the game and it dont run and the producers of the game were trying to help me but once they couldnt fix it they stopped responding to me fucking stupid and there is no reason why the game dose not run

[h3] not even half quality of the masterpiece the first lis is. [/h3] the story, the moral, the bigotry, hatred, racism, religious/cult themes, (all delicate) could have been good, but [u]the pace of the game really ruins everything.[/u] i feel the game was stretched unnecessarily. 5 boring chapters that could have been 3 great. is like watching a very, very slow pace movie, with little meaningful interaction. i fell asleep countless times "playing" this game. choices make little to no difference at all, a lot of dialogs and notes are useless, and the constant pushing on sexual orientation of couples or characters was totally unnecessary. despite it, several characters were indeed very good like stephen, cassidy, finn, anton... even karen. i would not recommend it, but if you already have it you may give it a go.

i’ve played through all the previous parts. compared to them, this game feels so much worse when it comes to story and emotions. it could still be decent, but it’s stuffed with in-your-face woke propaganda. you can see it most clearly in the way the characters are written. it’s full of old, worn-out clichés. almost everything here is black-and-white. people opposing mass migration are shown as xenophobes and fascists, or at best just rude and nasty to others. on the other hand, anarchists, hippies, gay people, and those living in communes are always nice, smiling, and cool. anyone tied to the church has to be a villain, or at least a brainwashed lunatic with no will of their own. in the end, of course, the church has to burn. migrants and minorities are always portrayed as good guys and victims. people protecting their country or opposing migration are painted as thugs. the border fence is “evil” and must be torn down to save the heroes. there are also layers of symbolic references placed throughout the game. for instance, the main character bears a symbol of baphomet on their sleeve. overall, the impression is that the game is designed less as a story-driven experience and more as a vehicle for conveying progressive ideas. after a while, it becomes difficult to ignore the sense that this message takes precedence over the narrative itself. it’s disappointing, especially given the studio’s earlier achievements. sad. dontnod, enjoy yourselves without me.

to be honest i'm dissapointed by this game. it gives you the delusion of choice, but forces you to "do the right thing" by all the narrative around. i'm not happy only how poor power of the daniel was but how it's all been developed. no one cares about sean except some of the later events in the dessert. only repeating how he have to be the adult one and protect brother and such. the game forces you to put priority of daniel's happy first no matter what. that's stupid. game of choice without a choice to be honest. to more technical stuff - damn, this game bugged more than i expected, just because i moved a bit too quickly from the place, cause i didn't hear the next dialogues starts... like wtf, i had to reload checkpoints few times, that was annoying. anyway, for me this game is kinda 5/10. it touches tough topics and they're showed without feeling that they're forced too hard, but overall the story wasn't that great for me. it had some good moments, but a lot of choices were forced to get it daniel's way and i don't get it how people love his character. he was such annoying brat, that i would leave behind if it was an option in early stage of the game and just run away alone if i was at sean's place. i'm surprised that i forced myself to go through all episodes.

i don't recommend this. it's my first experience with this franchise, and since there's very little fun in the gameplay, it's all down to the story. and overall, that gives me more negative feelings than positive. even the ending can't make up for that.
this game didn't grab me as much as previous life is strange games. after finishing the first episode, i had mixed feelings. i honestly don't think it's worth the time.

i wanted to recommend this game so much. while there were moments i really enjoyed, overall i feel it’s a step down from the first game. despite sean and daniel’s story seeming like it should have more emotional impact than sam’s in the first game, it just didn’t connect with me. the game ends in one of two ways, neither of which feels particularly satisfying: sean’s life is either ruined by surrendering and going to prison, or he escapes to mexico by forcing his way across the border (at least, those were the options presented to me). while reaching mexico is the goal of the game, there isn’t enough shown of their arrival to make it meaningful. the brothers deal with some gang trouble, then have a beer and look at the ocean. there’s no real follow-up on lyla or other supporting characters like jacob or brody, who helped the brothers along the way. it feels like there should have been an epilogue to show more of their new life, but instead we get maybe two minutes at most at the end, and that’s it. a bit of a let-down, considering how much i liked the first game. i’ll probably give the next game a go, but i doubt i’ll replay this one, and i don’t think it’s a title you need to rush out and buy.

i had this game wishlisted for years and was pretty excited to play it but i'm really not comfortable with being forced to play a 16 year old boy that's talking so casually about sex with his friends. i want to say it's predominantly the age that's an issue for me, but maybe it's just that i don't want to see or experience that being demisexual myself. i looked it up and there are forced sexual scenarios later in the game as well. overall this might be fine for most people, but i don't think i can enjoy the story because it's just stuff i really don't want to see/experience.

this game has a very different feel to it than the first two dragon age games, but it's still enjoyable nonetheless. the characters are well written, it has some awesome diversity representation within the game, and the new world style allows for hours and hours of playing. it did take some getting used to after the first two games, however. i also love seeing my choices from the first two games make their way into the story here. overall, even though i enjoy the first two games more than this one, i would still recommend this one.

probably the best game i’ve played in a while. sure the graphics aren’t extremely fancy and there’s no hair physics but the story over looks all of that. quite literally hours of fun and guess what 160 hours in and i still haven’t finished my first play through!!! if you want a great game with a phenomenal story telling and characters that’ll get you invest in not only the main story but in their lives, interests and who they are as a person, get dragon age inquisition!! if you want fancy graphics and hair physics, get the veilguard….

absolutely love this game. the graphics aged well imo. its pretty, characters are not cookie cutter nice to each other. some like others and some don't like others. the areas are vast, beautiful, and filled with lore and side content that'll keep you busy. the story has good twists. the character leveling and creation is fun and the optimization is good. the story pace is almost up to you. if it feels slow you can just speed it up by doing the story missions, it doesnt force you to do them. overall i love this game.

took me 3 trys to like this game just cause dragon age as a series always changes. story was alright with a couple nitpicks here and there. still hate having a dialogue wheel since it takes me out of my immersion. combat felt so bad and leveling up felt so unrewarding with the skill you get to pick. overall mid dragon age game this series gets worse with every entry.

[h2]summary[/h2] back to the roots of dragon age [h2]the good[/h2] - deeper story lines - lore that is interesting - combat relatively smooth [h2]the bad[/h2] - still some bugs, including quest breaking ones - decisions are not as important as dao [h2]the deets[/h2] after the brain numbing slog of dragon age 2, this was such a treat. the developers realized what made dao special and tried to bring back what was lost. overall, i still think dao is a better game. the decisions you make in it have far reaching effects and it feels like it matters. characters are flushed out better and are more worth investing into. however, dai shines in its combat that is smooth and fun to play around with to figure out new unique ways of playing. hey, they must have done something right if i 100% this game and not da2.

a genuinely great rpg with some minor pain points. a solid 9/10. i loved the story, and i feel like they did justice to the characters both old and new. overall the story has a much bigger scale than i expected, with some pretty epic twists that keep you engaged through the whole journey. visually the game looks great, even in 2025. frostbite engine was way ahead of its time and does a great job with the wide variety of environments and cool lighting setups. it helps that the art direction and tone is very coherent and fits the dragon age's gritty world. (unlike you know which game) the combat is decent, but the controls are a bit clumsy and can take a while to get used to. i mainly played as a mage and a bit with a rogue. rogue was surprisingly fun, having a parry mechanic is neat af! and i loved that the game doesn't hold your hand for most puzzles, the characters don't mumble the solutions to you if you're stuck for longer than 10 seconds, and a lot of the puzzles were very fun to solve! on the downsides, the open world bloat is a bit excessive. especially the shards, massive amount of effort for a practically nonexistent payoff. i love my open world side content, but it needs to have more variety and a more balanced effort/reward ratio. the ending left me excited for what's to come, and hopefully one day we'll get a true and faithful sequel to this very cool game!

this review is 30 hours into the game. so i'm playing this game for the first time in 2025 as i was looking for some open world fantasy rpgs that are not complete garbage. i haven't played origins or da2, so this is my first game in the series. the goods are the graphics are nice and still hold up, and the companions are interesting. the story being a political epic in a fantasy world is not bad either. but the gameplay, oh god. it is extremely boring and dull. it feels like you are playing world of warcraft except it is single player and there way less spells and skill. it is literally and single player mmo where you run around the world collecting and gathering resources. the rpg is the choice to be a tank, dps with 2h or with 2 daggers or with a bow or with magic (cold, lightning, fire). that is it. your choices barely affect anything. again i've just played 30 hours, i don't know if it gets much different later on. there armour and weapons are simple and boring. the crafting system is as basic as it can be. so overall the game is not bad, but it is boring. 6.5/10.

holy overrated. i've played da:o through multiple times da:2 multiple times i even full cleared veilguard i have tried and tried and tried to play this game but it is just *so* bad. the combat is the worst in the series. the game started as an mmo and you can tell. the terrible fetch quests and pointlessly large maps were clearly an artifact of the devs having to scrap their plans for an mmo and change it to singleplayer. you get a horse to make the travel slightly faster, but it handles like it's drunk. the companions range from mid to awful. solas is cool but wasted on this game. the "inquisition board" game mechanic has real time counters where you send your troops on missions, but it's miserable and has to be modded out for the game to be playable. the writing is actually decent, but the game is just *so goddamn awful* that i don't care. i am honestly baffled how this won goty. again, i love the da series, i've played every other entry start to finish, some multiple times, but i have tried to play this game on four separate occasions and i always stop before even getting through the first act, because it's simply unbearable.

played much of the side quests and took several breaks. ea just ruins the experience with the launcher. all of the male voices are annoying. various errors have me trying to reinstall. wish i had just kept the money. can't see why someone would be reading reviews at this point, but not recommended for anyone.

the system interface is awkward and uncomfortable. although there are brief tips on how to do things, key details, such as how to add your new skill to the number on your keyboard, are not included. the movement keys on keyboard are awkward. i was able to adjust the steps to wasd, but i have to turn the camera by using other keys (left or right only, not up or down) or by right-clicking and dragging with my mouse, which is exhausting after awhile. i just want to move the camera with my mouse without clicking on anything and have my character move accordingly. using a first-person view would simplify matters even more. skyrim, which came out a few years before, has much better controls compared to this game, but the creators do not appear to have learned from their rivals. this game gives the impression it was designed for controls other than the keyboard, and adjustments weren't made properly when modifying it for pc. the layout could easily be adjusted to give players an easier time creating characters. the options for darker skin all look terrible, even after adjusting the complexion. although the option for elves shows a card with blue-skinned characters and no nose bridge, those options are not available at all in the character creator, making them misleading. the subtitles don't work, so i missed quite a bit of dialogue. the game does win some points for animating the bow, which i've found to be rather rare bonus in games.

imagine pouring countless hours into dragon age: origins and dragon age ii—crafting your own story, making tough choices, grinding through quests, tackling every dlc—only to discover that when you move on to the third game, none of that effort carries over. instead of importing your hard-earned world state, you’re forced onto a webpage to manually recreate your past, with limited options that don’t even cover everything you actually did. and this isn’t years later when memories fade—this could be just weeks or months after finishing the first two games, and you still have to piece it all back together. then, to make things worse, you go to play what is mostly an offline single-player game, and if ea’s servers are down, you simply can’t. it’s frustrating to see so much player investment treated as disposable, especially in a series praised for its choices and consequences.

mass effect has been my favorite game since it came out in 2007. this game is an enhanced version of the originals. the first game benefits the most from the graphics upgrade. also nice that this version of me includes controller support even though i still play with k+m because of preference. pinnacle station and multiplayer isn't included since they don't add to the story. i was never a fan of multiplayer being forced into the 3rd game, but i kind of miss p.s. because the action was a fun break from all the talking and exploration. also nice to play this game through steam instead of the old ea origins nonsense.

i have not done a complete playthrough on pc yet as i have only just started the first game, but i have put more than enough hours on console to leave a review here. the trilogy are my favourite rpg games to date. the first game might be difficult for some people to get into as it is extremely slow, but trust me, the rest of the games are worth it. the choices you make drastically effect the progress/ experience of the current game and the next game in line. the combat, exploration, dialogue and soundtrack are fantastic. it does make you very immersed. the remastered graphics are very well done and you do not need a nasa spec pc to make this game look incredible. the dlc included with the le are also great but it is a shame the me3 multiplayer never was imported to this version. i have been recommended by one of my mates to play this game with mods to change my experience. a player called synth has made a modpack which has very good feedback for any of you are interested - https://youtu.be/7eqg9fdclcm?si=kekdwwzu_ng_i6v4

i have finished playing the game through at the time of writing this review. and i have very much enjoyed this game. from starting the first game and learning through talking to all sorts of species and reading through data collections to know more about this universe;. this game was very well made for back in 2007 and beyond and enhanced in this remake. the story is amazing i enjoyed it and the lore. it drew me in from our protagonist comm. shepard learning their past and going through the story and each game. it is interesting in a way that your choices matter i noticed it much more in the 2nd installment. and the lives of the other characters depend on our choices and much more. you transfer your shepard to each game and you determine the personality of shepard through dialogue and action choices. i wont delve into it much just got to try it for yourself. it is a realllly good game if you like story based, decision making, single player games. 10/10 from me.

yes i never played it back in the day and i bought this trilogy for a few dollars and it's everything i wish starfield was. land on a planet, something to do (besides pick up rocks...my dig at starfield). i'm only into me1 and the interface and combat is a little dated though but fun. it's definitely intriguing and well written. it's a darn tooting shame what ea, bioware and aaa gaming has become. just a note for mod obsessed people like me, really got to mod it before starting the game.

mass effect 1 is one of my top 10 favourite video games in my lifetime--maybe even #1--and the whole series is a standout, forever-favourite. the story is so phenomenally told, with characters that are unique, fascinating, and satisfyingly complex. many of the cast of characters will forever possess a piece of my heart (especially commander shepard themself, liara, garrus, and tali'zorah, joker, jack, miranda, edi, cortez)--though, ahem, we don't talk about jacob. the games also have a gorgeous soundtrack that draws you into the wardrum heartbeat of the series, though there are plenty of tracks suited to thoughtful character moments, and capturing the sheer majesty of setpieces (like seeing the destiny ascension and the citadel for the first time--wow!). the legendary edition updates a ton of textures, and consolidates everything into a clean menu of the three games that keeps it all feeling consistent and meaningful across the trilogy. super highly recommend--fantastic for fans of the series, and perfect for people picking it up for the first time. i wish i could experience it all for the first time, but honestly, every time i play this immersive game is a joy. mass effect always evokes a kind of wonder, passion, and curiosity all braided together that makes this game unforgettable and genuinely life-changing (especially for being one of the first games to ever show same-sex relationships; liara and jane/female shepard will forever mean so much to me for that).
great game, still a classic

the game and story are great story - 8/10 gameplay - 7/10 music - 9/10 choices matter and game decisions lead to a verity of different outcomes and endings so it is certainly replayable. total - 8/10 would recommand anyone who did not play this yet and likes sci-fi where decisions matter story with shooter/ability gameplay if you pick this up you wont regret it. *note it does require ea launcher and account to play on steam this is a negative but i would still recommend the game especially in current price. (this review is created after i completed all 3 games thoroughly including all side content)

i grew up with the original games, not that i likely should have, but i have always been facinated with this franchise. anyone who knows me personally knows that mass effect is simply part of my personality, and have heard me talk about it at one point or another. this game specifically gave little me all the dlc and addons she could hope for, and it brings joy to my heart every time i get around to playing it all once again. my shepard has changed and grown with me through the ages, and it reflects who i am and who i want to be. this game is and will always be one of my favorites. i will be forever thankful for getting to experiance every bit of it, from bullets to calibrations. if you've read this far, you should just buy this game. it's so good, i promise.

i tried to give this game a positive review. it is so frustratingly bad at times. story: great, i love it. very well written and relly fun to experience. gameplay: me1 is the best part, but a bit bland and old feeling. me2 is just stupidly boring and aged worse than me1. me3 is litteral dogshit. the dodge and cover systems got way worse and on insane it is a real nightmare to play, because it keeps bugging out on you in the worst way possible.

game won't start without being connected to the internet. get rid of the ea launcher. especially after the new acquisition. stop requiring players to create accounts for third party launchers when selling games on steam. i only got this because it was on sale for $5. i already have these games on steam and my high praise (except mass effect 3 ending) reviews of this game series still stand. this game isn't the improvement i had hoped for. it changed very little. the "improved skin rendering" in the trailer actually looks worse. i got the impression the character building and weapon systems would be condensed to being the same in every game, but no. this is pretty much just a game port. the game flaws have still never been fixed. in mass effect 1 the m35 mako still gets stuck on random things and you have to reload to an earlier game or return to the normandy. at some points there are less options than the original games. in the original mass effect 2 you could modify your imported character's appearance. they removed that feature and now you have to manually type in your me 1 character's appearance code if you want to fix the messed up eye brows imported characters get or start from scratch.
no matter what i do i can't get this crap to run right, looks to be a good game but just can't be bothered trying with it anymore.

unfortunately, the game requires the ea launcher, but after downloading it, it doesn't work—and without it, the game cannot be launched. i've tried many solutions and guides, but unfortunately, the constant updates to the ea app only make it worse and it can't be fixed. give us our money back for the game, or make it possible to play without the ea app. i love mass effect and would like to try the legendary edition, but so far, i haven't been able to.

the mass effect trilogy is fantastic, but having to log into ea every time you just want to play the game makes for a frustrating experience. the launcher also regularly forgets credentials and forces you to wait 10 minutes while they send you a security code, just so you can launch an application. i don't think i'll continue to buy ea games in future

wow this aged like doodoo dogwater. the mass effect trilogy is one of those classics that i finally decided to give a try but honestly it's baffling how anyone liked this in the first place. this came out after kotor, halo ce, and morrowind, and it's like a fusion of all of those games if someone blended them up into a smoothie, drank it, peed it out in the toilet, then dunked a ladle in there and went to town. i really tried to give this game a fair shot, but 90% percent of my playtime was spent aimlessly wandering as a soldier with the worst cardio in the universe, wondering where tf to go. i've seen many people say "well this game doesn't hold your hand," but there's a difference between not holding my hand, and throwing me as a baby off a boat into the open ocean. i've played games where you're only given hints where to go and you have to figure the rest out on your own, but the difference is, those games actually give details and provide reasons to explore, while in mass effect, everything looks the same, around every corner there's jack squat, and as an added bonus commander shepherd is the worst note taker in human history. "go to poopenfarten central," cool, where's that? what do i do with this information?? oh, it's marked on my map? oh, but it's not on my current map, it's marked on the map of the area i need to go to. sick. see you in 3 hours. also, the combat feels dreadful, which i could forgive if the story or any other aspect of the game had hooked me, but alas, this game is ultra poop from a butt.

i bought this edition a while ago. i'm on pc and the legendary edition had no option to change field of view. it's set narrow by default, which is fine if you're on a console looking at a tv across the room, but hot garbage if you're on a computer at a desk. there were no mods available to alter fov at the time so i returned it. if they've since added fov controls then this is a great purchase. if not then it's a still console port with shitty display options.

i went into it just looking for something to unwind with after work, and it ended up becoming one of the most chill and relaxing games i’ve played in a long time. the loop is simple: explore, loot, build, chill. there’s no crazy rush or punishment every 5 minutes. you can take your time, set up your base exactly how you like it, and just vibe. the world has this calm atmosphere — even when you’re running into enemies or diving into the shroud, it never feels stressful. half my time has been spent just gathering materials, expanding my base, and trying out new builds. co-op is even better; it feels like hanging out with friends, not grinding. if you want a game that lets you relax, zone out, and still feel like you’re progressing, enshrouded is absolutely worth it. i didn’t expect to sink 115 hours into it, but here i am.

early access review! i played the game for about 70 hours in my first 2 months after the release. i got somewhat bored after that and i now returned and there is so much new stuff to do, new areas, new material to build and craft with. new weapon types and all that jazz, i really like the game and i really do recommend it, no matter if you play solo or with friends. playing with friends is ofc a bit more fun for the most part and can make certain things easier. speaking of easier, there is one boss in the game that makes my blood boil. the mechanics and battle arena is just all bad and the only good thing about the boss is the design of the boss itself, not the mechanics or the battle. i cheezed the hell out of that fight by dropping the damage and health of the boss down to 20%, i love being able to customize my worlds with difficulties and resource yields and all that. there are plenty of kinks and bugs to work out but the developers are working on the game and it shows. i hope the full realization of the game will come into fruition with the 1.0 update at some point.

i want to post this review for anyone who is buying this game for the building aspect as i wish i found this out before it was too late to refund. from what i understand, the world is on a grid for building, so the direction in which you can place the walls is tied to that - meaning if there's a place you like that you want to build your house on, you can only build the walls in one specific direction, which is extremely limiting and frustrating. i would not recommend if building is important to you unless they eventually fix this. unfortunately this game was a waste of $25 for me and i wish i could get it back.

absolute dogshit. everything is janky. no one is ever going to fix the main mechanics. they built a foundation out of crap and are just slapping 'content' on top of it. for example: the wolves. they will just damage you no matter what. put up a block? standing on level ground, facing the wolf? damage goes through. people playing in zones at their own level might not notice this, but we wanted to venture out further. the result—getting our asses torn apart by these f*cking wolves. there is no actual combat system here. and it's like that with every aspect of the core mechanics. people usually say a game is good depending on the price tag. even for free—don't waste your time.

i went back and forth if i would write a review for this game as i did not finish it but here i am typing. 36 hours i made it, every night me and my duo got on was a night filled with why am i playing this, surely it will get better but it just got worse over time. on the surface this game looks amazing, plays well enough and the world looks great but then you actually play the game and regret your choices. i really tried to like this game and i will start with its main positive which is the building system, you got terraforming and a lot of building pieces to pick from and can rebuild the broken down villages. but that is the only positive i got. the number one thing i noted playing this game was that it just hates the players... like dark souls but i love dark souls i have 300+ hours on dark souls 3. this game actually just hates you... it wants you to get stuck, killed by hidden explosives, a swamp that insta kills you, monsters that hit for 500+ damage when you have a 480 health pool with the best armor you can get at the time and a vertical map that is cool at first but really is just a problem. i really hated this game the whole time i was playing it, and im a survival craft player im not new to the genre. i kept telling myself just give it more time but it just got worse the longer it went. this game sucked a lot and its a shame cause it looks good and obviously had good development dollars but this is a hard no from me.

a game i've been eagerly awaiting, and i'll finally be able to play it in 2025. i love the visuals and character designs, and the story is marvelous. yes, because i'm a gamer who's not only looking for visuals but also looking for a story. this is great
wtf this is blessing my ears. if you're reading this, i just want to tell you that you should buy this game!
might just be the greatest game ever made. play it if you love yourself.
first 3h : i love 2b's ass the 37h remaining : i am so sorry for everything you're enduring 9s .........

i love the soundtrack and story, that can be experienced in full, as there is more new content with each successive playthrough that shows you the world from a different perspective. i appreciate that you keep your items, level and completed quests from the last playthrough, so you don't have to start over with all of the grinding and questing each time, even though this is inconsistent with the story. i only had three negative experiences with the game (one of which was the fault of windows), but thankfully these weren't game-ruining. one was during a simple-seeming escort quest i started at level 23 and immediately regretted when level 50 enemies showed up (on my second attempt the enemies weren't so high level, so i suppose it was just bad luck). the second was having to travel to a certain story-relevant location to progress a side-quest, but a short cutscene was automatically played that made the quest unavailable. the third was losing a days worth of progress after eating a fish, because, as it turned out, windowsdefender "protected" my save-files from being changed, making it impossible to save the game.
this game seems freaking epic dawg

fantastic game didnt really like the plot was broken up through multiple playthroughs ending b was annoying to play through again but i did like the plot and if you go watch how this links up with the entire nier timeline its really pretty good. ending e is fucking ridiculous to get that credit sequence is a nightmare. great graphics and 2b is the sexiest videogame character of all time. not enough 2b, focused to much on the other two characters they were good but i like 2b. sad we'll never get to see her again.

i get it now. i bought this game after playing a whole bunch of character action games thinking it was going to be more of the same. i can't comprehend how much i completely misunderstood what type of game this was and why people recommended it so much. i got a hell of a lot more than i bargained for. there is a reason why this game is recommended by everyone that has beat it. this is one of the most meaningful pieces of art you will have the joy of experiencing, stop what you are doing now, and buy the game. [spoiler]i still have a few side quests left to do and then on to ending e, see you in the credits![/spoiler]
if this game didn't have the 2d sections it'd probably be a 8.5/10
the combat just doesn't feels right..

i expected so much more out of this series based on the hype and attention it gets, but man this was a let down. visuals are drab, music is repetitive, combat is so-so, exploration is a slog, and worst of all are the performance issues are constant. that is also not mentioning the fact that the camera is absolutely broken in some areas from getting stuck in top down to not being able to keep up with the player during sprint. it just does not feel like a modern game in a few areas and while that can possibly be overlooked, the crashes are inexcusable. if i were able to finish this game, i would assume i would score it around a 5.5, but again, i quit after the myriad of issues.

on paper, it looks like an amalgamation of everything i like: postapoc, androids, bots, greenery, heavy on philosophy plot, multiple endings, rpg, outstanding ost etc. but my omnissiah, what a bore it is. the world is barren, combat is shallow, npc-s could have been an email, side quests are a chore. i could go on, but if jrpg doesn't have neither a compelling story, characters nor gameplay, what else can it offer? this game is famous for its story, yes, but i just couldn't force myself to slog through the gameplay to see it. if anything, it felt pretentious and shallow. unfortunately, 2b's butt is not enough of a plot point for me to stick to the experience. the only thing i liked about the game (long before i actually played it) is the soundtrack. fortunately, that i can experience [i]without[/i] the game itself.
i have a motion sickness from this game...

play through the opening sequence before you get to the bunker and you'll know if you like it or not. for me, this was an absolute slog. i did not enjoy the combat at all, and the grindy, unnecessary levelling system exacerbated it. i played through to the c ending before i was done dealing with the shitty combat and being underlevelled. frankly, i really don't get what people see in this game. replaying through the same mediocre combat and missions as 2b and 9s is baffling. the quest design is bad, the map and level design is extremely uninspired, the va is spotty, and the characters are very one note. the chip system wants to be something clever like nine souls or hollow knight's abilities, but then neglects to provide any interesting abilities, preferring instead to increase your melee damage by a literal 2%. we can do so much better than this. if you want to experience the story, go watch it on youtube. this frankly fails on every metric i'd evaluate a game by.

since the majority of the reviews for this game are old and positive, i think i'll be the minority report. if this game is on sale, resist the urge to purchase it. if you buy it, and you play it, you'll know why i told you not to. you've been warned.
poorly optimized played on rtx 3070
degenerates can't add button to skip prologue

my problems with the game -worst start of a video game ever even if you consider to play game on hard the start of the game will be the hardest thing you do in the game -no auto lock on enemies on hard is dumb and easy is also dumb where you pretty much dont need to click attack just move around -uses 100% of gpu regardless of the settings all time -it forced ended my stream 8times so as a streamer that was annoyin 6/10, this game could have been great but it just done so many things wrong that it ruined it for me ,consider playing on xbox or ps maybe you will have better experince with performance

[b]merits:[/b] ▪ a very intriguing premise (told in a terrible format) ▪ dynamic switching between game genres ▪ fantastic musical score ▪ 2b's assets & animations [b]flaws:[/b] ▪ ps2 level graphics ▪ terrible ux, especially on the map ▪ grindy and repetitive combat ▪ a ton of boring fetch quests ▪ requires multiple playthroughs for the full story [b]verdict:[/b] i have heard great things about this supposed masterpiece, however the reality did not meet the expectations. the switching between shoot 'em up/hack 'n' slash/platforming is novel but the pacing of the game is terrible. it absolutely does not respect your time, expects you to constantly backtrack and play the game multiple times. when it comes to the story or lore almost nothing is told to the player and you have to very slowly unravel things through tidbits in the world. my recommendation would be to watch the cutscenes on youtube or better yet, watch the anime series that is based on the game, you will have infinitely better time. [b]rating:[/b] ★★☆☆☆ - average

i always thought this was a mindless action game with fan service. i tried it out because i heard it had a good story (which i found surprising and suspicious). the gun aiming in 3rd person is fine. in side scroll-er it's up or left or right. nothing in between. which is frustrating. the melee combat is better. the heavy hits feel impactful. i hit my first 'quit moment' 5 minutes into the game. the game yanks the camera all over the place throwing you from 3rd person, side scroll-er, top down, and everything else with little to no warning. the game is trying to be so many genres at once it's like being shoved in a barrel and tossed over niagara falls. i had a feeling this wouldn't be my type of game but i gave it a shot. turns out it was right.
what i expected from this game, i got from signalis.

11 hours into the playthrough. gameplay: terrible graphics: ps3-level difficulty: unbalanced (normal mode is too easy; hard mode, you get one-shot—might as well play very hard mode) story: after 11 hours, nothing significant has happened. i know the story gets better, but how much longer do i have to play before it’s actually enjoyable? characters: likeable also worst map navigation in history of games! so basically, if you’re willing to spend at least 20 hours for the game to actually get good, i’d recommend it. otherwise, you might want to just watch a youtube video—preferably a 6-hour one—which covers everything and is free, saving you a lot of time.

i came into the game thinking it's gonna have a fanservice story with good gameplay like stellar blade. but it turned out to be the opposite. the this game surprised me by being the opposite of that. the story is excellent and the gameplay has some excellent ideas but the execution is so bad that i had to drop it. first of all the keyboard controls are terrible forcing me to play this on controller which i am not too familiar with. however the reason i am giving it a thumbs down is because my laptop ran out of power while playing the endgame levels and now it does not let me continue the story at all. the forums just accept this as a thing but it's the last straw for me. it could have been great but they fucked it up by adding too many gimmicks.
i fucking hate this game 10/10
i have played many roguelikes over the years, and this is by far the best one. the game is cheap and its a must buy for lovers of this genre
rare gem, 10/10, still love playing the gun god

this is it. look no further. the nuclear motherlode of arcade gaming. a timeless piece of artful mutant mayhem. buckle up and blast your way through the wastelands - the nuclear throne awaits a new king.
going to jump into a vat of nuclear waste i hope i get the ability to roll!!!

hands down my favorite video game of all time. there is not another game that has had me hooked for as long as nuclear throne has. this is what i would consider to be the gold standard for a tight, refined gameplay loop for roguelites, and every one that comes after should strive for it. doesn't waste time getting to a truly singular arcade-style experience, and will absolutely not hold your hand. win or lose, you will play again, and that much i can almost guarantee you. one of, if not the most impressive games i've ever encountered, and will probably never stop playing. ever.

fläshyn one of the greatest games to ever been made, it has inspired so many other games with its simple yet addictive gameplay. can't believe there is an update coming soon that will add more skins for the characters, i will never get tired of this game and the amazing mods the comunity has made. also verify venuz.
just in 98 minutes ive seen more "you did not reach the nuclear throne" than i have heard "i am proud of you" from my father

the masterpiece from now-somewhat-inactive studio called vlambeer, it's a fast and chaotic top-down shooter game that you'll die a lot. shooting guns is fun. swinging melee weapons is also fun. characters are quite unusual yet funny (i think there are only few humanoid characters). i play with a mod called nuclear throne ultra and it's neat.
this game has fun gameplay, cool pixel art, and meaty-sounding weapons.
one of the best in its genre. please play this if you're a binding of isaac fan.
played this game since college. 8/10 give me a sequel you animals

this is genuinely one of my favorite indie games of all time. post apocalyptic rogue-like with a bunch of mutants (yv is the best) from simple pops to chaos and plasma explosions. highly highly reccommend
great game, one of my favorites
one of my favourite no stress games to restart and restart after each death. i took me five years to beat the game and i think i saw nuclear throne once in the first year and never since today :d
hate this game. will i continue playing it while suffering? absolutely.
had this game on a different console before i lost it, and i had over 100+ hours. this has to be one of my favorite roguelikes and i just got it again for mods to. fish can roll.

it's the dead body lootin' mutant shootin' venus youthin' rootin' tootin' luger totin' ruger loadin' bullet throwin' way-too-long grenade holding triangular, might mangle your weapon to rap flash color-coded clips 'n' an rpg hat baby, baby blue ammo turns red when it claps shoot your face in the fat give your cadaver a slap where the level boss at? i wanna clickclickcaclack-ch'pow-clickclickcaclack that see 'em, shoot 'em, skin 'em, wear 'em, mount 'em on a wall if it's completely armor plated imma shoot it in the ball... ...in' like a black hole or vulture flock you're violently challenged your thangs don't cock your things get shot your party stop when i roll up teen wolfin' on an ambulance top this ain't no game ain't never been no show and i'll gladly gun down the oldest lady you know
i enjoy this game a lot, but i equally do not enjoy it. many deaths or situations are extremely frustrating and not enjoyable to say the least. i would only recommend if you are very hardcore

the largest frustration i have with this game is there are absolutely zero i-frames at any point. if you're in one of the many wrong places at the wrong time and you catch multiple bullets within a split sec of each other, you're dead. if this game were $5 i think it'd be a solid buy but in my personal opinion the game isn't worth $12.

this game is mad hard, which is fine and all, but there's not a real sense of accomplishment to keep you playing. i feel as though the insane difficulty exists simply to hide how shallow of a game it is. the power ups don't feel at all impactful enough to help you on your runs. there's not enough kit variety. it's addicting, sure, but it's totally not fun being sometimes completely helpless against giant swarm of enemies that the game just randomly decides you have to fight. sometimes you'll have a decent kit, then spawn in a level and have no chance for a reaction before you die. that happens wayyyy to often. it's as though the game is designed to give you no chance sometimes just to reset you run.
if you like bullet hell with shit graphics
poor man's binding of isaac. it gets boring real fast.

at the current state i cannot recommend it. there is just too little variance at this time - it is always the same 3-4 mutations you want with the rest being meh/not useful, it is always the same small handful of weapons you look for, as the rest are meh or are very likely to kill you. it is always the same bosses that come by at the same time. in essence, the only variance is how lucky you are with the weapon drops and even then it just means 'do i get a good gun early or only later', in either case, the end game is the same. - if only the mutations actually changed the gameplay/runs, that could make a huge difference.

devs: haha game go 4:2 aspect ratio and 30fps on pc left click betas on the left hand side of the menu and select openbeta_win64 - open beta for 2023 testing. close the properties menu and the game will update. launch the game, go to settings > game > mechanics choose your framerate and aspect ratio, customize it with the custom fps/size option if you wish.

i've tried this game at least four different times over the years. the first couple of times i wrote it off to not enjoying the rogue rinse and repeat loop. then i played games like vampire survivors, halls of torment, death must die and crimsonland, and put hundreds of hours into them. so here i am, again, trying this game, and i think i know why i don't like it. this is a roguelike, and the other games are roguelites. there is no feeling of progression in nt. it truly is rinse and repeat. not saying this is a bad game, but it's not for me.
too willing to throw the most random, genuinely frustrating design choices ever at you (i.e. lil hunter, especially if the game spawns you in an area without cover, which it will)
shallow & unrewarding, balanced enough but overall a game set to hidden in library..lol

feels like a drastically less polished and sophisticated version of enter the gungeon. maybe a great game at release, it can't keep up with more modern roguelikes

for me this game is pretty much the same as "enter the gungeon" - bullet hell, difficult and other missing tags should be there. no luck going further than 3-3 level, seen the turtle only twice, was killed immediately, no fun at all here, and i tried. for no hardcore gamers (like me) i'd recommend smth like "dead estate" - much more fun, more chances to not die right at the entrance and see the whole game. i assume that nuclear throne might be more interesting on later levels, but as i can't get there - won't play it anymore.

smooth movement, smooth gameplay, amazing animations and outstanding graphics. there's nothing wrong about this game... every aspects of what makes a game a game is executed perfectly here. a huge congrats for the people that made this one of a kind game.

one of the best metroid-venias out there. the visuals and sound of tha game are so uniquie you owe it to yourself to try it just because there is nothing else quite like it. i recomment playing the first one first and than this one to apreciate the progress that the developers have made and for story reasons. the experiences and emotions while playing this game make it stand out as one of my favourites of all time.

a great improvement on the first game. i like silksong more, but this is a solid metroidvania. theres alot more powers/movement stuff than the first game which i like quite a bit. more boss battles and you fight with a sword-like weapon rather than the orb of the first game.

i just beat this, after getting it to test out a few new displays (i heard this game has great hdr impact.) i can't believe this game is so good...holy cow. if the devs ever see this...thank you for your' work. i was shockingly moved through the game...the themes are more touching than they have a right to be. the gameplay is outrageously fun. this is about as "fun" as a game can be to play. getting around is just spectacular by the end of the game. this should be a must play for anybody.
like the first one, this still amazing.

good game, fast paced and fluid traversal and combat. good unlocking. story is beautiful. graphics are beautiful. not sure what else it could've done. the abilities in this game are insane compared to the first one.
i'ts such a cute game to play :)

so cute and such a good story! i actually liked this one better than the first ori (which shocked me too!). if you don't have ori and the blind forest, i would recommend playing it first so you get the whole story. :)
one of the best games i have ever played. amazing gameplay, music and story. this game made both me and my gf cry.
this shit sound like skylanders™ 😛😀😂😂😂😂🤣
very fun platformer/metroidvania with just a few glitches and a decent although predictable story.
if you thought the first game was perfect, they managed to make an even better one.

if you can handle having to do the same part countless times then this is the game for you. it is not fun and the only reason i wasted this much time on it is because i am stingy and didn't want to give my money to a game and not attempt to finish it, had i've known that this game was going to be this frustrating within the 2 hour window i would have gotten a refund.
loved the first game, but this just didn't click with me at all.

the game is incredibly beautiful, but doesnt seem to offer more than its predecessor. story didnt do much for me and the game didnt offer much fun but if you were a sucker for the previous game, you will appreciate what this game does. only consider getting this if you generally love metroidvania / search action games
should have stayed with the blind forest mechanics

if you liked the first game but thought the escape scenes were obnoxious, don't even bother with this one. idk who thought "ooooh and then!!! big monster!1!!! run! run from big scary monster oooooooh" was an idea that needed to be executed three times (at least, i'm very clearly not intending to continue so idk if there's more), but that person can bite me. would be a great game without that but the chase scene obsession makes it a massive slog. shame, i liked it a lot outside of that

i have tried everything to swap the trigger and bumper controls and i can get the right swapped but the left doesn't properly. even through steam. i just can't play this game with the lack of controller remapping. i have been more frustrated than i am having fun and so must call it there.
great game so far but im stuck because the game bugged and didnt give me an item (kuros feather). now i have to just quit playing or restart from the very beginning.
game is beautiful but far too difficult to enjoy comfortably. the key sequences are too much to enjoy in any comfortable way.

game it self is great, if you liked the first one you sure gone love this one. yeat, i cannot recommend this one due technical issues. game keeps crashing and after playing about 5 hours, it wont even start (crashes at startup) and no driver updates, verifying game files nor reinstalling to different drive fixes it. and im not the only one who has these issues. so if you wanna test your luck and try if it works for you go ahead. i cannot even get my money back anymore.

game constantly crashes. ran completely fine until 2.25 hours in and then it's been a constant stream of freezes; blank screens, etc... should have read the other reviews as this appears to be a known issue. (before someone asks; my computer is far more than above the min requirements).
great rpg computer game. i highly recommend it.

cautious recommendation. i completed the main campaign and my feelings towards it was entirely lukewarm. "that's it...?" it was then continued in the expansion (really cool) but i'm like ten hours into it but basically nothing has happened. we're wandering around with almost no purpose and not really accomplishing anything. it's fun because it's bg3 before bg3 was a thing, and it's kinda janky at times, but the combat is solid and that's what kept me playing as long as i have.

super fun game, great combat mechanics with forcing you to use/benefit from many different spells/abilities instead of always the same meta choices. story is above average but the combat and character customization are what really shine
definitely one of the best fantasy adventure games ever made.

pros: good game really close to 5e dnd tabletop experience... if graphics were a bit better and ui too, it would be really awesome :d cons: a bit too easy in the standard difficulty. also is a bit slow game but as i play story gets more engaging ;) recommended if you like dnd
very fun battles and it is also good that your own characters is doing the animated inbetween talks. it heightens the unique feel.

i'll start with my biggest issue with that game. the voice acting is beyond awful in this game, one of the worst, add on to that the cringe dialogue that is sometimes used and you have a massive turd. despite that, the game it's self is very fun and it just feels like playing d&d, and that is the exact reason i bought this game. i look forward to trying the dungeon maker and workshop items once i have finished the campaign.
this game is excellent if you like all dnd systems.
very, very good. in 2025, the game hasn't lost much to time - a faithful adaption of dnd5e in great iso format. i recommend this game.

the personality system shines! i fell in love with my four misfits because of their interactions and the dialogue choices that were all a result of their personalities. now i'm playing with a totally different party with their own personalities and the feel is totally different. it's like watching a sitcom with four main characters.

hard core rpg, learning can be fun! i would suggest easy level to learn it, but normal level is very challenging and rewarding after you learn it. first tried normal without really reading the tutorial tips, and after a few hours needed to restart on easy, but playing easy leaves out some of the fun stuff i like, so went back to normal and read everything! camera control is another thing... my god! a trial in frustration! but, for some reason, i diggin it! pretty cool! 9/10

good game overall. if you wanna play something like dnd, baldurs gate 3 kind of stuff this is a good game for that. only thing is that its a bit less quality in general but the combat feels a bit more advanced except physics based things. the best campaigns are the main game's and the dlc palace of ice. the rest is just additional stuff like classes (some classes are dlc locked. yes pretty scummy.) and lost valley is something a bit meh for my liking. overall very good, took 150 hours to beat every campaign available in the game with all dlc. you can also play workshop campaigns made by other people. while its less quality and clearly no voice acting in these ones it adds a lot of replayability.

i am enjoying this game. great tactical rpg with a lot customization, alot. it is not at the level bg3 but what it is it does well. very d&d focused. i like the combat the game looks great. i plan to get more from these developers.
great loot system, just enough narration as to not weigh the game down.

this one is worth picking up on sale, if you need to scratch that d&d itch. we will not see the like of baldur's gate 3 for some time, but this one is serviceable. solasta is more gritty. there is no multi-classing, and the main campaign is very stingy with loot. you have to make due without the more fantastical weapons and armor. a +1 item that you can actually use is considered good loot and will be used for a good part of the campaign. the best items are crafted in the main campaign and getting the recipe, correct faction requirements, and ingredients will take you half the game or more to put together. the 2 dlcs that add new classes and races are straight up rip offs that should have been dropped for free. the full bundle is a good deal when on sale. you get all the races, classes, new dice, and 2 extra campaigns. i just finished the palace of ice dlc and it was great. getting the loot thrown at you without worrying about factions and recipes was very satisfying after the main campaign. i would recommend to pick this up mainly because the next solasta coming out early '26 looks amazing. they are revamping the graphics, and making a slew of improvements. this one has minor issues like elevation is handled improperly, cover system is not great, crossbows are broken (in the players favor), graphics are meh, and few other minor things. all that aside i have put enough time in this one to endorse it, it'll do.
straight forward play along d&d lines. replicates a campaign quite nicely.

played bg3 and heard this was also based off d&d so decided to give it a try. i was surprisingly shocked by how much fun i'm having with the game. bought all the dlc and look forward to playing it after i finish the main campaign.
everything besides the gameplay was just sad :(

i really wish there was a maybe option or something in between. i don't hate this game. i find the gameplay very fun, and the depth of mechanics that's just 5e srd mixed with some homebrew is fun. however, and big however, i cannot really get into the game. there's very limited choices in subclasses. the dialogue is a w f u l. what draws me even further away is there aren't really much options for character customization, and all characters look off. it's weirdly uncanny. would i recommend this game? if it was on sale, sure. if you're looking for a tabletop like experience, this is one of the few that will "somewhat" scratch that itch. there are better options. here's hoping the sequel is better.
the game looked good, and i wanted to play it. but it won't let me start the campaign, it freezes every time.

writing is pretty bad, voice acting is atrocious, exploring is fine. the only fun part is the combat, because it's dnd 5e and they didnt make it themselves, yet somehow half of the classes and races they didnt create are behind a paywall after i pay full price. hard not recommend
scaling is way off, interactions are buggy, and co-op disconnects frequently.

it's bad. really bad. it was "campy" bad at first... dialog, story, graphics are all scraping bottom of the barrel. rules are inconsistent with dnd and even inconsistent with itself. some fire creatures are immune to fire, others are not, some are *sometimes* immune... highly inconsistent. most *base* classes and races are hidden by dlc. very scammy. there's a mod that helps with this, but it's not on steam, so it's a pita to get it installed. ***however*** once you install the mod, multiplayer is ruined. constant desync between host and client. there's a "decent" fix, by hard setting your gpu to 60 fps. which means, for wtf ever reason they connected network activity to the gpu. and it still desyncs, but not *every* fight. even worse, once you install the dlc and experience the desnc, you can't uninstall it... and after seeing all the classes/races left out by the orginal came in the mod, you can't enjoy going back. story is bad and get worse as you get to the end.
the random encounters killing you before you can move ruin game.
temu version of baldurs gate...sooo janky! i wanted to like it though

the general low budget vibe was fine. the bad graphics, the questionable ost, the hilariously bad dub, the basic plot, the generic ui that doesn't tell you much about your spells or enemies etc - all of this is literally ok, because having a coop dnd game with 3 other friends every weekend is great. but i draw the line at losing a coop campaign of multiple months to a bug that prevents main quest progression. unplayable, inacceptable and downright awful.

the voice acting, close-up 3d model cutscenes and writing are all kinda atrocious. characters are ugly which would be fine if they weren't in close-up focus all the time, and 5 out of 12 classes are locked behind dlc (warlock, bard, monk, barbarian and druid). gameplay and exploration seemed okay, and the tutorials are helpful, but i was rather put off by the previous points and wasn't enjoying myself.
10/10 but i forgot to save and had to redo a bunch of sections. please save. totally improved my depression.

one of the fucking best games ever, i have played qutie a few games myself if may say so. i even beat dark souls so i am basically a videogame expert. this game is absolutely great, i heard so much great beforehand but it was even better than expected. so i really recommend buying it and also playing it to the end without spoilers. good luck my friend!

omori is my favourite game of all time, and i doubt this'll change. i found omori in 2022 before it was taken off of xbox, initially glancing over it at first, i decided to play it later on into the year. omori has easily been the most impactful piece of media to grace my life. the story is incredible, easily the meatiest part of this story is locked behind a huge spoiler wall, which i won't go into to allow people to really sink their teeth into something they equally should and shouldn't... omori's artstyle and soundtrack are both brilliant, both of which influencing my artwork and music tastes in their own beautiful ways. after getting a pc in july of 2025 i wanted to see this game again the most, and it was nowhere near as lacklustre. i'd argue it was better. the story doesn't erode, it grows on you and hits you really hard regardless of how many times you brush the dust off of it's cover. omori is, and likely always will be my favourite game of all time.

this game is just.. on a different level. a level in which everyone cries and understands these characters to the point where we think of them as our own friends. as us. that alone should be enough information to buy this game. this game is very story heavy with strong themes of depression and suicide. if you're struggling, i suggest thinking it over. this game has ups and really, really hard lows. that being said, it's those lows which pull the story together and make the player feel something. a connection. so, all in all, i'd rate this game an easy 10/10. i may be bias, but this game affected me in such a way i can't help it. amazing pixel art, story telling, fun gameplay, and so many npcs to interact with. if you plan on buying the game, don't spoil it for yourself. keep to the experience, it's worth it.

i don't know why this crunchy rpg maker game is overwhelmingly positive. its got crunchy rpg maker graphics, and they want you to play windowed and on a modern monitor with how low res the game is that means you will be squinting at a tiny piece of your screen straining your eyes so make sure you have eye insurance before playing. the first area is extremely dark but i think that was intentional so you can't see how garbage the game looks. the games whole gimik to try to counteract this mediocrity is to break the 4th wall like a dora episode. you move at the pace of a snail but at least there is fast travel so you only have to crawl through each garbage area a a single time. maybe the game gets better idk but i don't know how anyone made it through the start.

base game is good, although very overrated. music and visuals are charming, and the game gimmick is fun. the 10 bucks steam version adds newgame+ content, featuring a different "route" with a new ending. this new content is hidden from players, and is mediocre at best. it is empty, with barely any new rooms and no puzzles. it's poorly written (with lengthy jumbled explanations all over the place), and the story it tells completely shatters the purpose of the original game and its ending. overall, this doesn't justify the price. just play the original game for free, unless you want to financially support the creators of course.

it states linux support, but it's very broken on linux, it doesn't even run without manually messing with the files if you are using linux, do not play this game unless you want to debug why it's not running other than that it's a pretty good game, however i didn't get to experience the ending because of the support issues listed above

the game and its idea are great, but it doesn't work on linux properly. unlike windows, linux environments can vary greatly. [spoiler]when it "cleverly" modifies files on your system, it should do so in a way that always works, for instance by using available system facilities.[/spoiler] on my machine, the ending, for instance, simply does not (cannot) work. [spoiler]i managed to find out what was supposed to happen in some cases that didn't work, and thus managed to arrive at the ending, but there, i'm stuck, b/c the program it tries to run fails with various errors. i fixed one of them (broken librt), but didn't bother with the remainder of the error messages.[/spoiler] also, [spoiler]some of the puzzles aren't thought out properly, so you can get stuck in some situations, where you don't have the necessary items anymore.[/spoiler] so, to me, the game is partially broken. don't play this on linux.

soma is the first horror game i played in a long while after around a 5 year hiatus from gaming in which the last horror game i played was alien isolation. i gotta say the theme & horrors of soma regarding existantialist dread was a breath of fresh air. this also happens to be my very first game from frictional so i had zero expectation or biases from amnesia. the monsters & feeling of isolation you get from playing this game is on a whole another level. some of the monsters were not that scary but some are definitely notable highlights such as ackers, the weeping lady, the dude who follows you around definitely sends shiver down the spine. 10/10 highly recommend to anyone looking for a good existantialist horror game

love how this game gets you to think about the way consciousness works, the value of life, and whether a situation is deemed to be better than death. spoilers for the themes and an integral twist in the game: [spoiler]"native americans used to think photographs would steal your soul." it's not a cut and paste, it's a copy and paste. would i create a copy of myself to live a better life? yes. would it really fucking suck to continue being the doomed version? very much so, but it would make me feel better that there's a version of me out there that's getting another chance. i've always been a big supporter of the idea of transferring one's consciousness to a mechanical or virtual form in order to evade death, i just usually think of it as a transfer rather than a copy. that might just be idealistic thinking though due to the disconnect between biology and what might be capable with technology.[/spoiler] love this game. top tier story, walking simulator gameplay (i turned off the ability to die but the horror scenes felt just as tense, just less annoying. hope this studio makes another game build on an idea with the same vibe as this, rather than another amnesia sequel. 8.5/10 art or cool rating: art

even after a whole decade, i'd say this has to be one of the best story-driven games i've ever played. just the way the game makes you feel, especially at the end, is too good not to mention. simply put, this game is a masterpiece that everyone should play at least once

this game is so magnificent that even when speedrunning it still manages to be scary in many aspects: its atmosphere, art direction and story, and mikko tarmia's score is one of the best pieces of music i've ever heard in gaming and it fits soma perfectly. frictional games is known for amnesia games, but i believe soma is their best game to date. looking forward to their next sci-fi project.

⭐ devour – the best co-op horror experience out there ⭐ rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) devour is easily one of the best co-op horror games i’ve played. the tension, atmosphere, and unpredictable gameplay keep you on edge from start to finish. every map feels unique, every run feels different, and the jump scares never get old — even when you think you’re ready. the game rewards teamwork, communication, and strategy. when things go wrong (and they will), the chaos is actually the fun part. whether you’re running from demons, collecting objectives, or reviving teammates in panic, the adrenaline rush is unmatched. the developers keep the game fresh with updates, new maps, and challenges, making it a title you can return to again and again. smooth performance, creepy sound design, and smart difficulty scaling make devour stand out from other indie horror games. if you enjoy horror, teamwork, and intense moments that make your heart race, devour is absolutely the best co-op horror game to pick up. highly recommended.

solid multiplayer game. firstly, this game isn't the smoothest. interact prompts can be weird, the map balance is off, and some animations are pretty cheesy and rigid. however i am surprised at the variety in this game. you look at this game and think, "so i do this one thing over and over with new coats of paint?" well, no. weirdly enough while the goal and basic, find x and use on specific spot 10 times never changes, but the "how to" changes and it can get pretty enjoyable. the maps are really fun and different. the maps shift from open to tight hallways really well. there is also really fun spots to jump railings and evade the monster. the maps are also really well designed and i like how not one map looks or feels like another. solid multiplayer game, play it with your friends for a fun time.

after sinking over 450 hours into paladins, i can confidently say this is one of the most enjoyable hero shooters you can get—especially for free. is paladins perfect? no. the matchmaking can be hit-or-miss, and balance patches sometimes feel like they were decided by throwing darts at a board. but when the gameplay clicks it’s genuinely some of the most fun i’ve had in a shooter. for anyone wondering if paladins is worth trying or returning to: yes. absolutely. it’s chaotic, stylish, surprisingly strategic, and still manages to be addictive after hundreds of hours. if you’re willing to embrace its quirks, you’ll find a game with a ton of depth and replayability. 450 hours later, and i’m still not done.

been years since i last played. apparently it's now winding down in activity. seems like i never made a review for this. better late than never. all in all, i liked the gameplay. but disliked the "free-to-play" monetization. every new character (non-free) they introduced was always op, until they introduced a new character (again op) and "re-balanced" the earlier one. you could usually pay for them with an exorbitant amount of in-game currency, or a fairly small sum of real-life money. so "free-to-play" became "pay-to-win". i especially liked the character skill/attribute customization options, where you could build your character to your own play-style. there might not be overly many players online, anymore, but i would recommend trying this. skye ftw!

a 5v5 team-based shooter like paladins looked very promising on paper. it had a good variety of maps, a large roster of unique champions with different abilities, and even a shop system where you could buy extra perks to improve your stats. the gameplay felt fast and dynamic - fights were happening all the time, yet it never felt overwhelming or chaotic. the balance and anti-cheat existed, though not always in their best shape. still, for a while, the game managed to stay alive, build its own community, and even have an esports scene. but as time went on, it stopped evolving. players began complaining that the only updates were new skins, while major improvements were nowhere to be seen. the game had squeezed out everything it could from its audience - and decline followed. it's not a bad game by any means, but today it's simply not worth your attention anymore. ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ☆ ☆ ☆ ☆ ☆ (5/10)
