as a longtime paladins player, the matchmaking and balance issues have really ruined the ranked experience for me lately. way too often, my team gets paired against players who are obviously way more skilled or ranked much higher, turning matches into totally one sided stomps. it’s super demotivating when you realize that winning or losing feels out of your hands not because of how well you or your team plays, but simply because the matchmaking threw together teams of wildly different levels. frankly, i want my effort and skill to matter, not just luck or who got stacked on my team. recent matchmaking changes have only made things worse. matches feel even less fair than before, with the system regularly putting beginners against top-tier veterans, or grouping talent in ways that just don’t make sense. sometimes i feel like the queue cares more about filling spots quickly than about actually creating competitive, fun games. all this randomness means i rarely enjoy ranked anymore, since i don’t get consistent, challenging matches with players on my level. honestly, unless the developers address the core of these matchmaking and balance problems pairing teams based on actual performance and skill rather than random chance i just don’t see myself having fun in ranked mode anymore. competitive play needs to be fair, and right now, it’s just not

path of exile completely changed the way i look at arpgs. what started as a casual curiosity turned into one of the most immersive gaming experiences i’ve ever had. the depth of its skill system, the freedom to build your character in countless unique ways, and the constant introduction of new leagues make the game feel endlessly fresh. what truly stands out is how rewarding it feels to grow your character. every upgrade, every crafted item, every perfected build comes from your own effort and creativity. it’s a game that challenges you, but it also inspires you to think, experiment, and push your limits. path of exile didn’t just raise my standards for arpgs. it completely redefined them. if you love meaningful progression, complex systems, and worlds that pull you in and don’t let go, this game is a must-play.

it just isn't fun. poe was the diablo 3 people wanted back in the day: it was a passion project that filled the "no, we want more d2" gap left by blizzard. and so for that, it was good. but as it continued, the complexity and customization only increased. and now the world has moved on. loot games have evolved. and this game is unapologetically complex because it believes that is what you should want. i'm sure it gets amazing once you get deep into its systems, but last epoch is right there, folks. and even diablo 4, lost ark, and a million others - including poe 2. if you want unlimited customization which is only possible with unlimited complexity, then this game may do it for you. but otherwise, you can do better.

crystal project has an amazing sense of adventure! easily one of the top 10 games of the decade for me. its open world feels on par with titles like breath of the wild and elden ring, offering true freedom and discovery at every turn. the class system is brilliantly designed, allowing for countless creative strategies and builds. the itemization is deep and rewarding, making exploration and experimentation feel meaningful. on top of that, the game is packed with thoughtful quality-of-life features that make the whole experience smooth and enjoyable. easly 10/10

hell of a beast! ❤️ kudos to andrew. **warning bit of spoiler** while normally i'm a bit of a sucker for a story in my jrpg's., this one has none present, short, albeit funny dialogues here and there. the gameplay of platforming and metroidvania as well as the jrpg with different classes / sub classes / wpns / gear / acc's / archive entry etc got me hooked! quintar breeding was a pain, but oh so worth for sequoia tree, got pretty close to the top with owl & salmon but wanted to die x.x, never again. do not suggest unless you're into pain and rage, masochistic style. currently bulking for the 4 superboss in the depths, 1 down 3 to go. there are assist options if you feel you need a bit of a break on certain aspects of the game. imo the 3 homepoints are a must. others at your leisure, i find most stuff balanced as is. the music is superb, really immersive. the world is fun to uncover, and i know some of you, like me, will reach out for every corner of the map possible. 😁 mini games are harsh at first, but becomes easier as it goes. quintar breeding is money and time consuming. there are ways to break and fast forward the games progression, as this is non-linear game. speedruns are out there on every crystals. workshop supported and lots of guides and videos online. def recommend, two thumbs & two big toes up. 👍🏻👍🏻🦶🏻🦶🏻

dont feel like writing a long review. tldr one of the best game worlds i have ever played trough, the design of the map itself gives the game so much character it is not comparable. the game was obiviously heavily play tested and it shows. its 10 bucks, trying it wont hurt. and if you dont like the current job balance (i dont lol) there are rework mods that change that.

it's a great blend of the job system from ff5, a minecraft parkour map, and a metroidvania. if you like all of those, then this is a fantastic game, but you really have to be into all of them for the game to truly shine. the combat is good, lots of different class combinations and interesting setups you can make. the game is very difficult by normal jrpg standards, but there are a plenty of ways to break the system. the game even has a preset system that lets you save specific setups so you can swap them easily. the exploration is good, very open-ended and tons of little secrets to find. it can be a bit tedious to get around, as even with all of the teleport stones it can take a couple of minutes to get to where you need to go. none of the areas really stand out in terms of level design, but there are tons of skips and tricky jumps you can make to completely break the intended order of progression. the platforming is, in my opinion, the weakest aspect. it's fine, for the most part, but there are way too many areas where one missed jump can set you back upwards of five minutes to get back and try again. areas with platforms over spikes or water were the best, since there if you miss a jump at least it puts you back where fell from. nothing stings worse than missing the final jump in a section and falling all the way back to the bottom. definitely worth it if you like all three of the genres it's blending. if any of those are a turn off for you, it's probably best to just skip this one.

a very well-made passion project. super fun exploration, good combat, good progression, amazing class system (including multiclassing). 9/10

perfect rpg for an rpg hater like myself. specifically: * i'm not interested in story or dialogue. the game has minimal both. * i want combat to be interesting and not a grind. here, it's similar to slay the spire in that it's almost a puzzle: the enemies broadcast their upcoming actions and you need to both plan and react accordingly, rather than just apply a broad strategy. (sometimes the normal enemy encounters can feel a bit repetitive) * traversing the world is actually interesting, and only restricted by your movement/inventory rather than plot triggers. * skill trees and character customization are deep enough to be interesting, but simple enough to not warrant analysis paralysis. * effectively no decision is irreversible, and no missables. if you ever want to pivot to a different strategy it's always an option, and just requires light time and resources. and there's no sense of "don't miss stealing an item from this boss" * you feel you can liberally use items. there's no sense of "save all your megalixers!" i can't imagine an rpg that's more in line with what i want out of an rpg. (fully completed on switch)

100% recommended, i'm enjoying this game a lot. kind of like a mashup of old school final fantasy and elden ring huge world and the exploration is awesome, nice music, some challenge but not too difficult and was this made by 1 person?? crazy edit: i took a break and came back to finish the game. i will say that the level cap is unfortunate, because some of the end game bosses will still be quite difficult even when you've reached max level. you can lower the difficulty, but it can't be increased after it has been lowered. makes no sense to me and i'm stuck on easy now normal difficulty was fine for most of the game, but some of the later bosses feel pretty unfair the worst part of the whole game, though, has to be the quintar racing/breeding. not only because the racing is difficult and not very fun, but also because you need to breed a golden quintar to access at least 2 areas in game. and for that, you will need to win a lot of races and spend a shit-ton of gold to feed your quintars which get hungry every 2 seconds. so then you might actually need to grind to get gold to feed your quintars, which is the absolute opposite of fun summary: very fun overall, huge game world with much to explore, but the end of the main game and the post game are disappointing for sure

it's just fun. if you want a game with lots of freedom and deep combat that feels like the fever dream of a ff3/ff5 fan, then this is a game i think you'll love. if you want a deep story...it doesn't really have that, but there's a little something here that pops up from time to time. really this game is about the exploration, the fights, tinkering with your party's builds, and even some solid laughs. sometimes a game just clicks for you, and for me this is one of those games. plus it's super inexpensive and has mod support! it's great!

one of the best classic turn-based rpg i have ever played. simple graphics, very fun to explore world with a variety of enemies, bosses and biomes. you mix and match abilities from different classes to create your party of 4, lots of combos to optimize for different bosses. you can choose to customize the difficulty perfect for you, i cranked it to the max and had fun creating builds for the hardest endgame bosses and their gimmicks. multiple times i was surprised at finding out many new areas when i was expecting to be at the end of the game, also you need to actively chase down and defeat summons before they become available as skills for the summoner so 10/10

there are some parts of this game i like, but overall i can't recommend it as it copies too many of the bad parts of final fantasy too. i really like the exploration, which reminds me of crosscode, and it is very similar with the influences from final fantasy too. however, unlike crosscode, the slow battles make the grindy combat very tedious, especially when most fights require no tactics whatsoever, just repeatedly bonking the enemies until they die. it reminds me of the bad parts of final fantasy: mystic quest - which is a shame as the exploration part is done very well.

the game is unnecessarily hardcore with mechanics which just don't bring any pleasure. like unlocking classes, which apparently you need to change while playing... you can't develop love towards your character at this pace. the mine-craft block style map was something unusual for me to see, but in the end it's just depressing because the majority of secrets are hidden in between these blocks, with crazy jumping mechanics of 'press longer to jump a bit higher'... i did my best to really make myself play the game and at least understand what a hell i am actaully doing it. until... you get a message on the message board that the only sense of all what i am doing is ... looking for crystals... which depresses me, because... crystals unlock classes... (which i would never transform into during playing because i created the characters as per my own understanding...) ... and serve as requirements to go further in game... to sum up - it's exceptionally boring, with great soundtracks, drugged monster sprites (which i liked), mana troubles and too much complication. also, there is not a single thing about jrpg in it. apart from final fantasy hero sprites... wish i could refund these 6 hours back to my life.

hardcore grindfest with minimal mechanics or fun strategies, barely any depth outside of it having a great open world design. if you want a casual rpg look elsewhere. this one on the "no grinding" normal mode has unbearable amounts of grinding due to horrid game balance the soundtracks, and artwork are nice but it has no story and there are hundreds of amazing rpgs you should play instead. this is a last resort one if you want to torture yourself with dull gameplay.

this game was pretty fun, right up until i realized that there is literally nothing to it to keep you coming back, unless you want to install mods. without mods, this game is a shell of an rpg. more to the point, if you want to have any kind of actual "fun" in game, you basically have to learn to use crystal edit to improve the game and classes yourself, otherwise you'll always feel under-powered, under-leveled, and ill-equipped. i shouldn't need to go into the game files and make the game what i want myself. i hate that i paid money for this. don't buy this game. seriously. i play the game still, but only because i changed it to be what i wanted it to be, not because it was fun already.

i'm disappointed i didn't manage to get into this game, seeing how positively it is generally regarded. you really, really have to love platforming not to find the exploration part frustrating. it's just an endless series of jumping puzzles with little direction and plenty of nasty punishments if you mess up (long backtrack, unwelcome fights etc.). the combat is good and the character building is a nice riff on the old ff system. but it's mainly the boss fights that are great. the regular fights feel a little overtuned. they're doable of course, but tax your attention and resources (potions to refill mana mainly) and the combat isn't quite interesting enough to make me want to do 10 semi-risky trash fights just to traverse some zone. you can avoid lots of fights, but that relies heavily on being good at the platforming parts.

cons: [b]#1.[/b] no mouse support (which makes overworld movement obtuse and menu navigation even more obtuse). [b]#2.[/b] huge lack of information provided to the player, like when creating your party at the start of the game, or when selecting the difficulty setting, there's almost no information provided. [b]#3.[/b] no reliable fast travel to previously visited locations / towns. [b]#4.[/b] a gigantic amount of platforming. [b]#5.[/b] if you save at a savepoint, and load that save, you're taken back to your single 'home point' instead of spawning at the location where you saved. this makes no sense. if a reliable form of fast travelling was implemented, then perhaps i could bring myself to shifting my overall opinion to slightly positive, but honestly, the lack of fast travel is going to waste hours and hours of your life in the game, and that's something i can't abide by (i'm not talking about the 11shrines in the game, those don't even take you to 10% of the places you'd want to go, like nan's place or the fishing place, etc.)... i simply value my time too much to spend it backtracking for hours. i'd honestly rather replay earthlock or ff9 than play this game anymore. i'll check back in a year or so to see if #1 & #3 was fixed atleast, perhaps then i'll give it another go for more reviews, visit my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7851637/ for my full recommended list of games: https://steamcommunity.com/id/lfpg/recommended/

ok... i really want to like the game, and find the openness very interesting... but (in my short time playing) literally 70% of all my time is just spent on jumping puzzles. it's cute having a couple secrets be tough to jump to, but literally progressing all my quests and areas is based on jumping puzzles (with a map that doesnt rotate). i just spent 45 minutes trying to get a final dog bone that i can see, but never figured out how to jump to it.

i like everything about this game except for the overworld. there's a job system! there are unlockable classes! there are no random encounters! unfortunately, none of that matters when you're lost: you're just going to spend hours wandering around on an empty map. i don't have the patience for that. at least give us a hint of where to go, please. 2025-03-09 - i love almost everything about this game, so much so that i struggled through the parts that annoy me, or that i strongly dislike: the huge, empty world with no direction is tedious, but you can at least keep a guide open in another window. the platforming challenges are awful, especially when you can't see the xyz coordinates of where you're supposed to be jumping, so you just have to guess, die, and try again; but at least the auto jump option helps in some instances. but what i hate is how, at the very end of the game, in the final dungeon, there's an unskippable platforming/ice block challenge which is longer and more difficult than just about any other obstacle in the game. if you start this game, you might not be able to finish it, but you won't know until you've wasted dozens of hours.

a fast, tactile vr fps that channels a counter-strike-like energy: tight rounds, bomb plants/defuses, and clutch moments, translated into full-body presence. manual mag handling, bolt pulls, and sight alignment make every reload and peek feel earned. gameplay & mechanics — 8/10 snappy gunfeel with satisfying manual reloading and clear hit feedback. movement options cover stick locomotion and smooth turning; room-scale peeking around corners is a genuine edge. occasional jank and the learning curve on weapon handling can spike early deaths, but mastery is rewarding. modes & content — 8/10 classic search & destroy sits alongside a grab bag of community favorites (ttt, zombies, ww2, gun game). the workshop/custom servers are the secret sauce - maps and modes keep the playlist fresh, though quality varies server to server. presentation & audio — 8/10 clean visuals for quick reads under headset constraints; positional audio and proximity voice chat add tension (and hilarious chaos). not a visual showpiece, but it prioritizes clarity where it counts. comfort & accessibility — 7/10 smooth locomotion can challenge vr newcomers; comfort tweaks help, but motion-sickness-prone players may need shorter sessions. weapon manipulation is immersive but demands practice and decent controller tracking. conclusion pavlov vr is a fun, counter-strike-like arena shooter made better by vr’s hands-on gunplay and a thriving custom scene. it’s not the most polished or guided experience, but if you want competitive rounds with real-world reloading and endless community variety, it delivers. score: 82/100

breaks my heart to not recommend this game, but it's just simply dead at this point. the game thrived on mods with players making crazy custom modes and maps. you could easily lose yourself for hours in the variety. the devs made the decision to move everything to ue 5, and in the process essentially nullified all existing mods. the issue with doing that to a game that's been out for a while is that a lot of the modders aren't actively keeping things up to date, so we lost all the cod zombie maps and have only gotten 1 or two back a while later after some dedicated modders revived them. so in short, the devs attempt to shore up the game is the very thing that ended up breaking everything good about it, which has led to an exodus of the playerbase. at this point, its maybe one or two populated servers, and then a ton of private lobbies and empty lobbies. and sadly, i can't blame them. keep in mind, this game made the move to ue 5 in summer of 2023. plenty of time to fix it up for the modding community, so this is not just a matter of impatience but an active decision to stall / not consider it. since the update, i've installed the game twice in the last year to see where it's at, and sadly it seems mostly everything has stopped dead in feb. no new mods really, no new dev updates, no new mod kit expansions to allow for the people still playing to save it. save your money and just accept that you missed out on this title when it was king, and if you pick it up now it will be a shell of it's former self.

disappointing performance and accessibility issues i was really looking forward to trying pavlov vr, but unfortunately the performance issues made it hard to enjoy. even with an rtx 3070 and a ryzen 9 3950x, the game runs very poorly — with frequent stutters and inconsistent frame rates. it feels heavily unoptimized for what it offers. the tutorial does an okay job at teaching the basics like movement and shooting, but it doesn’t go much deeper. i also struggled to find a way back to the main menu — after several minutes of searching, the only solution i found was to close and restart the game. because of these problems, i didn’t even make it to the multiplayer part, which was the main reason i bought the game. hopefully future updates will improve the performance and usability, because it seems like there’s potential underneath all the technical issues.

used to love this game. it had loads of fun modes like pavz, tons of mods, and always full servers. since the move to unreal engine 5, all the mods are gone and so are the players. now it’s just the same 25–30 sweatlords playing the same three maps, spawn killing everyone else. all the fun stuff that made the game worth playing is dead. you’ll be lucky to find a full server anymore. it’s a real shame because the gunplay and maps are still great, but without the community and mod support, there’s nothing left. unless you’ve got a big group of friends to play with, don’t bother buying it.

squad 44 is a tactical ww2 shooter. as an avid enjoyer of first person shooters, this is really fun once you get into combat situations. its not a spectacle like call of duty or battlefield. instead, its much closer to hell let loose. unfortunately, new players like me who are not experienced with realistic shooters struggle to properly engage in these battles. another issue is that there aren't enough servers in asia which makes it hard for me to play the game at a smooth performance because of the high ping. the game's file size is also clearly large. still, i find that the gameplay is very engaging. guns are responsive and close quarters combat is intense. the game also has a wide selection of weapons and vehicles to choose from, so the game is great for you if you're into tanks. the game doesn't look that good compared to modern aaa titles but it holds itself well. buy this game when it discounts by 50% or more if you are into realistic shooters.

it's a great game with best ww2 maps i've ever seen. it's just dumb to point at hll and immedietly claim it's better, simply put, if you like a more 'arcade' experience that is less realistic and more casual then you're going to like hll better for sure. but if you want a more simulation experience with more realistic details and larger maps then you're going to like squad 44 more. also everyone complaining about performace issues must have no idea how to change their video settings because it always runs at a stable 60fps on my 3060. tldr: hll is the 'rising storm' of ww2 milsim while squad 44 is like a hardcore version of regular squad with better maps more realistic details and it takes place in ww2. both are good games but hll is more arcadey and sacrifices realism for console friendly gameplay

squad 44 is an outstanding world war ii tactical shooter that captures the chaos and camaraderie of large-scale warfare like few games can. every match feels like stepping onto a living battlefield, with massive 50v50 fights where teamwork isn’t optional—it’s survival. the authenticity is incredible: weapons have weight, vehicles require coordination, and communication through proximity and squad chat pulls you right into the action. it’s not just about shooting; it’s about building defenses, holding lines, and pushing objectives as a unit. playing with a well-organized squad is unforgettable—you feel the tension of storming trenches, the relief of repelling assaults, and the adrenaline of clutching a point in the last seconds. the sound design is chillingly real, from artillery barrages to the crack of rifles whizzing past. squad 44 isn’t an arcade shooter; it’s immersive, tactical, and demands cooperation. for anyone who craves authenticity, teamwork, and large-scale ww2 combat, it’s absolutely amazing.

actually a pretty good game, and the coop works without issues (atleast for 2 player) so far for me (8 hours) yes the game lacks some features etc, but considering the next patch that is in experimental at the time of writing (taming) it seeems to just be a perfect rendition of rimworlds early days, but with a sweet integrated coop. the coop: each player starts with their own colony, but on the same map. you can play solo or as allies, or you can semi integrate your colonies and share resources with trades. (you can not control each others colonies / use each others resources etc.) i really like this coop integration.

softer and simpler than dwarf fortress or rimworld, but it runs along the same lines. i'm excited to see where this game goes. it's certainly worth the price as-is. the co-op runs smooth, and is something the other colony sims simply don't offer. works well with this game's scope; lots of fun.

review_text: graphics are great. the controls are minimal. death is only semi-frequent; very far from the pointlessness of the dark souls games. also, the ambience in this thing is amazing. very horror-centric. it's made up for whatever the heck re 6 was supposed to be, and wasn't.

review_text: i've been a long time resident evil fan and have played basically all of them except for some of the more obscure ones. with that in mind, i honestly think that 7 was a fine addition to the franchise and made for a unique and enjoyable experience. scuffed chris redfield notwithstanding of course. i just recently played through this game again and enjoyed it just as much as i initially did. when the game was first announced, i was admittedly skeptical that the game's formula wouldn't translate well to a first person perspective, but i was pleasantly surprised that it worked well. of course, it doesn't play like your average call of battlefield ce fps so don't expect slide canceling and drop shotting. what you'll get is a good first person horror experience that is a fun ride in a unique setting. i give this game 7 chris redfield boulder punches out of 7.
genres: Action, Strategy, Simulation, Indie, Massively Multiplayer

review_text: resident evil 7 completely blew me away. coming from playing the older re games and being amazed at their action and scale, stepping into re7 felt like entering a whole new era of resident evil — and i loved every second of it. the story is insane in the best way possible. the mystery of the baker family, the creepy atmosphere, the plot twists, and finding out the truth behind eveline… bro, i was hooked the entire time. every reveal just made me go “no way, so she was behind all this!?” the gameplay is tight and genuinely scary. the first-person perspective hits different — it puts you right in ethan’s shoes. exploring the baker house felt like being inside a horror movie. the tension, the footsteps, the doors slowly opening… damn. peak horror. i also loved how the characters operate in this game. jack chasing you down the hallway like he owns the place, marguerite with her creepy insect powers, lucas being a psycho genius… and ethan? that dude is him. the man takes more damage than any human should and still keeps going just to save mia. respect. and bro — the guns feel amazing. the shotgun slaps, the pistol feels crisp, and every upgrade hits hard. when you finally get fully geared? you feel like a badass walking through hell to end everything. overall, resident evil 7 reminded me why this franchise is goated. it’s terrifying, emotional, intense, and unforgettable. if you love horror, story, and pure resident evil vibes, this is a masterpiece. 10/10 — eveline tried to control me but she can’t control my love for this game.
genres: Action, Strategy, Simulation, Indie, Massively Multiplayer

review_text: good setup and great gameplay about third of the way through the story. then it speeds up so that you don't get bored having to deal with the same 2 common types of monsters. looking great even 8 years after the release. sound design is great as well. story is neither here nor there for me. it felt more skewed to "just stupid" than "so stupid it's funny" that we come to expect from re. it has some good moments and some very, very boring clicnes. it doesn't really connect to any other re in a meaningful way. remove couple of documents and rename one character and it would be a game in it's own competently built world. good game in general. well worth the time. p.s. dlc sucks.

review_text: edit: after trying the game again, i'm pretty furious. the game is so buggy. first i got the recreational room book glitch that needs you to restart the entire game to get around, now the game crashes every time i try to cross this bridge to save my progress. i literally can't do anything about that. al the fear i was supposed to feel was replaced with frustration. this game seems kind of cool, but i definitely enjoyed 2, 3, and 4 far more. nothing is really too scary, it just seems like jumpscares. i don't mind puzzle solving, but fighting seems so clunky. guard doesn't seem to work when i need it to, i get grabbed at at stupid distances, and shooting the enemy to stagger them for a second doesn't really work as well as you think it would. i especially don't like how the game doesn't stop when i open my map or inventory (which sounds better for the fear factor, you're never safe, but it really just causes annoyances when i'm trying to do something and get attacked from behind). i can see the effort in this game so i'm sure it's a very good game as everyone is saying, but for me personally i just can't play for more than 30 minutes without getting a legitimate headache.
genres: Action, Strategy, Simulation, Indie, Massively Multiplayer

review_text: there are two types of design philosophies i absolutely despise in games, corridor shooter that require a substantial amount of backtracking to progress( with mandatory puzzles), and shooters that throw a ton of enemies at you with very little resources at your disposal. tack on bad pathing, tedious level design, and a story that seems interesting on the surface, but is about as deep as a puddle, and you get resident evil 7. that is not to mention the absolutely atrocious inventory systems as well, or insanely limited resources. the worst thing about all of this, is that the game is a slog to playthrough. there is some cool ambience that is served up, but other then that- i'm not compelled to finish the rest of the game. seven hours was enough for me to want to uninstall this game. final rating: 2/10- buy on sale or just watch the cutscenes on youtube.
genres: Action, Strategy, Simulation, Indie, Massively Multiplayer

risk of rain 2 doesn’t feel satisfying to play: it becomes repetitive, build development is uninteresting, and progression feels slow. there’s no real sense of danger or urgency. some thoughts: the teleport event seems pointless—its only function is to move you to another biome, but there’s no meaningful reset or shift in pacing. boss fights are significantly harder than regular encounters, yet the reward is the same single item, so defeating a boss doesn’t feel genuinely rewarding. opinion: as a roguelike, the game has potential, but it needs substantial rebalancing and a deeper rethink of how builds and progression develop.

game play is not my cup of tea. the fact that they throw waves of a lot of enemies at you in several rooms and expect you to dodge all the stuff with only one dodge is ridiculous. also, eris debuffing you if you get too far in a few runs is stupid. if you need to pad your game play length by doing this, you have a bad start to your game. also, dealing with cerberus is a very large ramp up, and by the time i get to chronos, i have very little health just because of one boss that has too much damage and aoe. i will keep trying to play the game, but i usually only do 2 runs before i have to stop because this game play is ridiculous.

after finishing the full release, i have to say i’m disappointed. i supported this in early access but after all this time the game just doesn’t pull me in like the first one did. the tone, writing, and presentation constantly break immersion instead of building it. the story and dialogue never clicked for me. in hades 1, conversations felt clever and fitting for mythic figures. here, it’s casual and repetitive, and the characters rarely grow or respond meaningfully to your progress. the plot never gave me the same drive or emotional hook that made zagreus’ journey compelling. the characters feel weaker, and melinoë never really develops, even after dozens of victories. the cast lacks the charm and spark of the first game, and the serious tone never lands because there’s no wit or emotional payoff. the redesigns of many characters feel wrong, they clearly weren’t meant to immerse you in the world or tell the story, but to do something else entirely. that takes me out of the game more than anything else. gameplay is solid at its core, but the magic of the first game isn’t there. weapons feel too similar, combat is slower, and builds rarely feel impactful. progression is bloated with too many materials and grindy systems that make runs feel like chores. on top of that, screen clutter from attacks and effects often makes fights frustrating because you can’t see what’s happening. overall, the game lost the personality, charm, and tight design that made hades 1 special. supporting it early felt exciting, but the final result just didn’t deliver, and if this is the direction supergiant sticks with, i won’t be backing their next project.

same formula as the first, but nearly as tight. they added more systems, but a lot of it is frustrating rather than intriguing. super builds aren't nearly as common which adds to the frustration. all-in-all a more poorly paced game that has issues with the story and the presentation.

[progressioin spolers ahead} i beat typhon and chronos both 3 times. i beat polyphemus like 50 times. and you still do not give me a normal ending after all that,.....that's not ok. i just lost interest in trying to beat this game. in fact i already did, multiple times, but you rigged it and designed it in such a way that forces your players to keep coming back over and over again. very scummy and i didn't enjoy this. how is it possible? i mean... how? the first hades game was great all around: great combat great pacing great story great characters great music great endings (both of them) on the other hand, this one still have a good combat, but it's very hit and miss, glacial pacing, terrible story, boring characters, ok music (except for the sirens, they are great) e abysmal endings (especially the epilogue)... add the total lack of respect for greek mythology acurracy and you have hades 2... such a shame...

need a "meh" option. it tries to do way too much. where the first was a tight, balanced experience this requires way more grinding for materials for even basic functions of the first game. bosses are far overtuned in comparison to the first game, while mel is a much less powerful protagonist. a step back.

a bit of a different experience from the original hades, some things are better some aren't. story wise it has its ups and downs. melinoe is everything that zagreus isn't (which is very good honestly, doesn't make it better or worse, though). what we fell in love in the original is there, but also the steven universation... the old story of old dude can do all terrible things and get a pass. there are better ways to solve a conflict, talk no jutsu is one of the worse.

it doesnt click as the first one, hades 1 is perfect and this one tries to be similar but different at the same time. the characters are less charismatic copies of the first game. for example, nemesis and oddyseus feel like aliexpress versions of meg and achilles. the new gods are bland, and the returning ones come off like actors worn down after six seasons of playing the same part. personally i didn't enjoy any of the weapons and i'm not having fun with the magic system. any weapon in hades 1 is more fun than the witch staff. also, i'm color blinded and i didn't have problem seeing things in hades 1 but after 60 minutes playing this one my eyes were exhausted.

after completing it and getting to the epilogue i'm realizing only after the fact that... it's just not as good in terms of writing as hades 2. it's nonsensical and unfulfilling in a lot places, with either unearned or hanging plot threads and characters all over the place. this is one of those times i wish i could give a neutral recommendation, but forced to pick yes or no? it's no. make no mistake, what's here is an improvement gameplay-wise on hades, but hades 1 was a complete package and that's why it was good: writing and mechanics actually interlocked in such a great way to keep you playing well past the ending. that isn't present here. they really dropped the ball with the development of the narrative overall here, it's all weird and disjointed when you stop to think about it, all the way from simple bonds you have with characters, to how things 'resolve'. and that just isn't good enough when you're only standing on your mechanics, and being compared to a much better complete experience like hades 1.

i loved hades 1 and was so, so excited for this game. and i really enjoyed it for 60 hours! and then i reached the ending and ate the greatest dissatisfying nothingburger 0 character development of all time. the game and characters had so much potential and none of that is ever addressed. melinoe isn't particularly likeable and she never gets character development throughout the entire game, she isn't even a satisfying protagonist which sours the otherwise great gameplay. the art style change was just disappointing, considering how hades 1 had an incredibly unique, dynamic style

review_text: rust is less a video game and more an ontological crucible—a ruthless simulation of human fragility in which players are unceremoniously thrust, naked and bewildered, into a violently indifferent world. armed initially with nothing but a rock, one becomes acutely aware that this primitive tool is not merely a means of gathering resources, but a symbol of humanity’s eternal struggle against entropy. the island itself operates as a living ecosystem of paranoia, where each footstep behind you triggers a sudden philosophical inquiry into mortality. what truly distinguishes rust is its uniquely volatile social dynamic. alliances form and dissolve with the same instability as subatomic particles, and the concept of trust becomes a rare and precious hallucination. the player must navigate a landscape saturated with machiavellian scheming, economic desperation, and a level of unpredictable human behavior that borders on the anthropological. a single encounter with another player can unravel hours of effort, transforming personal progress into an existential tragedy worthy of greek theatre. the emotional turbulence rust generates is unparalleled. triumph feels mythic—your first fortified base stands not merely as a structure, but as a monument to defiance against an uncaring universe. conversely, being raided at 3 a.m. by a clan of sleep-deprived marauders is a humbling reminder of the cosmos’s disdain for your ambitions. this perpetual oscillation between empowerment and devastation makes rust an experience not of simple entertainment, but of psychological endurance. in conclusion, rust is a hyper-chaotic meditation on survival, cruelty, and the volatile nature of human interaction. it is exhausting, awe-inspiring, and occasionally soul-crushing, but it is unquestionably one of the most brutally honest reflections of human behavior ever disguised as a game.

i like this game alot. it’s very fun and addicting, with tons of challenges and quick action that keeps you on your toes. i played the vr version (13 hours), and i loved that game. although this game is flawless with no complaints, i must say that in my opinion the concept of superhot: where time moves when you move. is better executed in vr. i had so much more fun in the vr version because superhot’s gameplay is smoother and better done in vr than in the original. also, with how short these games are, i don’t find real value in the $25 price tag for each of them. the vr version is by far worth its price, while the original feels lacking because its gameplay and difficulty is just stale in comparison. now, i do want to make this clear: superhot is not bad. it is wonderful and a joy to play through, and i can see some people justifying the $25 price tag. i just think that when you compare it to superhot vr, its price isn’t worth it to me personally. i bought this for about $8, and i’m happy with it, but i would not pay the full $25 price. if you can buy this game on sale, then i’d say it’s worth your time and money. however, i believe that superhot vr is the definitive and better version to play.

it’s okay — it’s actually great for, let’s say, modern yu-gi-oh. the game itself is probably much better than previous titles. updates are frequent, new cards arrive about five months after they’re released in the tcg, duels are found almost instantly, and there are often events with changed limits or forbidden cards. but for me, the game would be much better if you could switch the game mode to formats like goat, edison, etc., and find opponents who play the same format as you. of course, you can create custom games and play that way with your friends — which i do — but why should i only play with my friends when i could play against you? overall, the game is good. i’ve made all the decks i own in real life, and it’s a great option to experiment with different strategies and to learn new decks much faster.

the most accessible way to play yu-gi-oh! online. cards trail behind the tcg/ocg by about 6 months. gems for cards are earned at a decent rate. perhaps the least gacha gacha game on the market. unlike duel links, cards can be crafted/dismantled for dust, similar to hearthstone at about a 3:1 ratio of dismantle to craft. this means even unplayable duds of the same rarity contribute towards cards you actually want. no need to scrape the bottom of the packs looking for must haves like duel links. events are held roughly twice a month for some variety and include loaner decks to experience the latest decks, albeit not their meta versions. ban list is wildly different to the tcg, for better and for worse. while it doesn't make paper play obsolete, it is a fine alternative if you are just looking to play yu-gi-oh!

pros: - yu-gi-oh card simulation seems smooth. - music is good. - highlights relevant card text for various effects. - some event duels create new metas outside the traditional ranked. cons: - story mode content is basically a nice looking power point. - in app account management between devices is a dumpster fire. (do not play on any device before linking up your account. there is no simple log out button.) - once event duels end, there is no meaningful way in game to engage with casual play. - game locks packs of various archetypes, and you can only purchase these various types of packs by generating a card from that 'set' or using gems (earnable, but still a paid currency.) to hopefully pull an sr from the set. which then allows you to spend gems on the set you are actually aiming for. it's a yu-gi-oh! tcg simulator. as an official product that generates revenue, i would say it doesn't meet expectations. if you like yu-gi-oh! - you will enjoy yu-gi-oh! in the app. that's as far as it goes.

i could not get the game to respect my settings and not use hands free calling for my wireless headset. for those who don't know this results in horrible audio quality since bluethooth is not capable of handling high quality in and output at the same time. just imaginge putting your phone in a tin can and put the volume to max. then you know how this sounds. this is not an issue in any other game i own. every game respects not using the headset mic how its set up in windows. deactivation all other devices besides my usb mic and headphones did not work. changing gamebar and xbox settings to use the headphones for just output and the usb mic for input did not work. deactiviating hands free mode via windows resulted in no audio at all. the game always forced the hdeadphones to be used in hands free mode resulting in horrible audio quality for the whole system. after trying everything i could find online about fixing it and nothing working i just gave up and refunded without playing a single second. i wasted over an hour researching and messing with settings without success. sad that a mircrosoft related company can not get their product to work properly with their own operating system.

hard to recommend this. e.g. - the game is designed in a way to make it very difficult to learn. you have to get good at parrying, and weirdly it offers you very little opportunity to really do that. - far too much bs, and far too many situations encouraging cheese. - op consumables that trivialise fights, but extremely rare to find so tough shit if you didn't kill the boss the time you used snap seeds. - punishes the dying and learning cycle with dragonrot mechanic. i did get to a point where i enjoyed the game, but fromsoft really did make it as difficult as they could to get to that point. i'd recommend lies of p or khazan over it any day.

the combat system is neat. its enjoyable for a bit but gets really repetitive and drawn out on some encounters. a lot of bosses have really cheap tricks that they throw at you that feels like it breaks the flow of the combat and i don't find the cheapness fair or interesting. most of the bosses and mini bosses can kill you in just one or two hits, which makes learning them a painful chore, but of course you need to get about 50 in so that their posture bar doesn't deplete so fast in order to kill them. player dropoff is almost 50% by the first major boss. for the rest, a lot of players resort to cheese tactics to beat a lot of the encounters, which i think goes against the intent of the game. i get being tough, but i find this game doesn't always play by its own rules. despite picking it up a few separate times to give it a fresh approach, each time i find i just hate it.

sekiro is a great game that suffers from the syndrome known as being apart of the soulsborne legacy. that is to say, everything that sekiro does right feels like an evolution of the darksouls formula, but fails to let go of aspects that makes it miserable. the game play is excellent- when you already know exactly what to do. the map is well designed - when you know exactly where to go. the game is fun to play - after you've already mastered it. if that sounds nice too you, get it, but i can't recommend a game like that in good faith. pros (which there are a lot of) - fast and interesting evolution of souls-borne combat - excellent boss-gated leveling system - amazing atmosphere - interesting bosses cons - weird tacked on souls-mechanics that detract from the experience (abhorrent camera, weird hitboxes, souls-esk stumbling and uncharacteristic clumsiness, occasionally inconsistent rules) - lack of proper tutorialization/introduction to mechanics (lightning attacks, shielded enemies, archaic actions required for certain areas of progression.) - very forgettable story with mediocre characters - beginner unfriendly, not encouraged to experiment (very low heath at game start, potential to be soft-locked out of using an xp mechanic due to death mechanic, items made to ease difficulty implemented frustratingly poorly.) i'd say this game is a time sink, where if you spend the time, you will enjoy it, but after 40-some hours, i know for me this is not something i'd recommend to others, nor is something i'd complete without a guide in hand, cheesing every boss i had the mispleasure of facing for the first time.

not well designed and incredibly overrated. the good things include the visuals, the story, and the one on one combat is amazing. however, they do their very best to avoid that. nearly every miniboss is some sort of duo fight, completely ruining the combat and making it severely unfun. the open areas are passable but overall mediocre. in summary, you have to wade through hours of slop until reaching a handful of amazing bosses, which just isn't worth it. there are too many good games out there to waste 30 hours on this. i would suggest nine sols as a similar game that just was miles better for me. sekiro has potential to be amazing if it leaned into one on one combat and reworked a couple of the areas, but it feels like it does its best to avoid this, so overall not worth the time or money.

insanely overrated game. boring, tedious, and repetitive. it boggles the mind to think that quick-time-events are unanimously hated in the gaming community (and rightfully so), but this game is universally praised as a masterpiece. essentially, every fight is a punishing, lopsided qte simulator that requires quick reflexes and enemy attack pattern memorization. block/parry most attacks, dodge/jump when it's something like a charge, sweep, grapple, etc. succeed and you get a brief window to chip away at the enemy, maybe 3-4% of their health. fail and you get hit for 50-75% of your own health. it's guitar hero, but with ninjas. f*ck off.

a well calculated game... nba 2k20 continues the franchise’s tradition of delivering a highly realistic basketball simulation, with stellar visuals, tight gameplay, and robust content. however, it’s not without its flaws. pros: gameplay mechanics: smooth and responsive controls make dribbling, passing, and shooting feel intuitive. ai improvements enhance realism in both offense and defense. graphics and presentation: stunning visuals and lifelike player animations capture the essence of the nba, while dynamic commentary keeps the experience immersive. mycareer mode: a compelling storyline with celebrity involvement adds depth, alongside satisfying customization options for your player. variety of modes: from myteam to myleague, there’s plenty of content to keep players engaged, whether you prefer competitive online play or managing a franchise. cons: microtransactions: heavy reliance on in-game purchases in modes like myteam and mycareer detracts from the enjoyment, especially for casual players. repetitiveness: despite small updates, gameplay can feel overly familiar for long-time fans. server issues: online connectivity remains inconsistent, which can be frustrating for multiplayer enthusiasts. verdict: nba 2k20 shines in gameplay and presentation but stumbles with aggressive monetization and recurring technical hiccups. it’s an excellent choice for basketball fans who can overlook its shortcomings. rating: 7.5/10.

i'm only not recommending because of the price. it's good, but only worth it if it's on sale. i got it for 700jpy ($5 us), and i'd say it's worth it for up to $10, maybe 15 if i'm being generous. if i compare similar and similarly priced games like hades, this doesn't even come close. very basic. i feel like once you've played it for about an hour or 2, you're not really going to run into anything new with the gameplay or progression. it seems there's only 3 levels to clear, which will take you around 90~120mins, and you just do that over and over again, while not really getting much stronger per run aside from the new cards you unlock on level up (which only happens once every 2~3 attempts, and then you have to find those cards in a run. your starting deck doesn't change, so it's hard to feel good about starting a new run when you never get any stronger. story and characters are non-existent, so the game has to stand entirely on it's gameplay and while it's fun enough if you take it for what it is (a single player card game) and don't compare it to more fleshed out card games like mtg, again, i'd say i wouldn't pay full price for it. i certainly don't understand the glazing that it gets.

a bit more than a month after finishing this game, i've come to the conclusion that i need to make a review about it. this game is one of those experiences that i can't really imagine leaving you after you go through it. i absolutely recommend it. the music is beautiful, the characters are memorable, the gameplay is fun, and the story is genuinely amazing, with some of the best writing and execution i've seen. there are a few people who think the endings get a bit irritating to do over again and again for all the endings, which they aren't wrong in, but i enjoyed seeing that all again personally. with the sole exception of the junk heap. that place sucks. nice music though. this is a game you want to go into blind. don't look up stuff before or while playing or it won't feel as impactful (this goes for most games tbh). unless its about getting through the junk heap... i am very much looking forward to playing nier automata. once again i heavily recommend anyone who sees this review plays the game.

fun game. good story. nice to see some background from automata, but damn this game is just one big long fetch quest. constantly running back and forward. it is a drag. and sure, i guess you could choose to just not do some of it, but you don't know if it is worth it until it is over. just like automata, some of them are important. most of them are just a boring time suck. also, just like neir automata, the keybindings for pc are kind of wack. this one is a little better than automata, but unlike automata, no one made a mod to fix it. you cannot re-bind mice keys.

nier replicant ver.1.22474487139 is an action rpg that builds on the cult classic nier. the updated version improves visual fidelity and gameplay flow while keeping the original structure. the world design presents a bleak tone that pushes the player to question the value of progress. strong art direction supports this. combat uses light and heavy attacks mixed with magic abilities. animation timing feels responsive. enemy variety grows at a steady pace. boss encounters stand out through scale and pattern recognition. the combat system is not complex but remains engaging across the runtime. the narrative focuses on a journey to save a loved one. it presents moral ambiguity without pointing to a single correct answer. dialogue reveals layered character motivations. themes involve identity and the cost of survival. emotional impact builds as the story advances. multiple endings encourage repetition. new routes add narrative context rather than simple alternates. later runs change perspective and reframe earlier events. this structure rewards patient players who want deeper lore. it also increases the total playtime without feeling padded. the soundtrack is notable. vocal tracks rise during key story beats. ambient music maintains tension in quieter moments. sound design fits both exploration and combat. audio feedback supports player awareness in fights. visual upgrades include refined textures and improved lighting. character models feel more detailed. environments show stronger depth. performance remains stable on modern hardware. load times are short. nier replicant ver.1.22474487139 succeeds as a refreshed version of a niche title. it preserves the unusual tone and narrative risk while modernizing weak points of the original. it appeals to players who value story driven structure more than mechanical complexity.

i do not get it. i couldn't finish it and had to put it down. the voice of the book is so grating. constant exhalation, way more than necessary. switched to japanese and then had trouble reading the tiny subtitles in the middle of combat. the constant backtracking is mind numbing. you spend more time running from a to b then doing anything. the side quests are the absolute worst form of mmo garbage. this is totally unacceptable. half of them require you to either grind a bunch bullshit, or just buy arbitrary quantities of things. story moments frequently lock you out of interacting with npc's critical to services and side quests. music is great but there is only like 4 songs. combat sucks. no gap closer, wonky camera when locked on, getting stuck in a 5 second combo facing the wrong direction, basically all magic except dark blast is pointless and a waste of time, and every trash mob has a steel foundry worth of armor you need to bash off before doing damage. characters are unlikable. main character might be the best, fashion sense aside. the story of the endlessly sick sister that everyone wants to have her just lay in bed "resting" until she dies drives me up the wall. bitches days are numbered, let her have fun. emil is cloying and melodramatic. kaine is some kind of futa fetish fantasy constantly talking shit. the desert mask people are supposed to be cute? they are annoying, the desert i have to constantly cross to get to them is annoying. the forest text dungeon was waaaaaay too long. i just skipped through all of that crap. after heading back to the starting area for the bajillionth time i just couldn't take it anymore. this game sucks.

this is a very relaxing game! no pressure to do the quests. lots of exploration. you're contributing to someone's wellness so has a good heartwarming feel. lots of new things to do as you slowly keep unlocking more and more. the only cons were one of the main characters (the deer) is extremely self-absorbed and narcissitic. and all dialogues are extremely verbose and boring. who talks like that in real life? besides these 2 things it's pretty awesome. there's a variety of gameplay like cutting trees, smelting, cooking exploration, island exploration, navigating to new places on the map etc. i played it for 7-8% and i'm saving it for my retirement. this would be a good one to play in the future.

spiritfarer is a beautifully crafted gem that offers a unique blend of soothing gameplay and heartfelt storytelling. the game's cozy atmosphere is unmatched, making it a perfect escape to unwind. improving your ship adds a satisfying layer of customization and creativity, while exploring its vibrant, hand-drawn world is endlessly engaging. with its gentle rhythms and emotional depth, "spiritfarer" feels like a warm hug **** yet brimming with adventure. whether you're connecting with its memorable characters or simply enjoying the journey, it's a delightful experience worth savoring.

the game is beautifull , relaxing , have a great community , he is easy to play no need to be skilled , you will not have to defeat some eldrish abominations. try it , the game will make you cry with his delightfull story. the other games of the studio are really cool too try it. in resume very good story , gameplay and graphic and attentive dévelopers

i started this game thinking, 'what even is this?' and ended it feeling like it had etched itself into my very bones. every spirit i bid farewell to made me reflect on my own life. it makes you feel something—something deep, melancholic, yet strangely comforting. spiritfarer isn’t just a game; it’s an experience, a beautifully crafted meditation on loss, love, and letting go. the hand-drawn visuals are breathtaking, the soundtrack lingers in your soul, and the balance between management mechanics and heartfelt storytelling is masterful. even in its quietest moments, the game never feels dull; instead, it invites you to embrace the journey, one farewell at a time.

não é apenas um jogo, é uma experiência. um novo conceito de como contar uma boa história. se você se permitir mergulhar na magia do jogo, tenho certeza de que irá se encantar. a gameplay pode ser um obstáculo para alguns, já que é simples, sem grandes desafios ou dificuldade. no entanto, todo o encanto do jogo está em sua proposta: uma narrativa cativante, uma ambientação repleta de carisma e personalidade, com um estilo visual único e músicas incríveis. cada nova descoberta ao longo da campanha é um verdadeiro deleite.

at 17.9 hours and bought for $9.99 short answer: yes its worth buying, bethesda wont stop breaking fallout 4, and when they get around to releasing fallout 5 in 2200, we all know it going to be horrible anyway. dont buy over $20 wait for a sale they come around too often. longer answer: honestly screw bethesda they need to shut their doors for good and sell the ip to someone who cares. this game is entirely made up of extremes. if somethings good, then its really good. if somethings bad, then its really bad. iv watched this game from afar since before the release waiting for the right time if there would ever be one to buy. its nowhere close to the miserable state of crap i expected buying it, and im actively enjoying myself. if you`re thinking about buying it, its likely because fallout 4 is just unplayable with bethesda trying to appease their hallucinated new audience of people suddenly interested in fallout because season 2 of the show is around the corner and they will break every mod and destroy everyone`s saves to do so. don`t be afraid, the waters actually fine. there is for sure a player base here and active, and im strictly solo so no ones helping or assisting me in anyway outside of chance encounters with people out in the world.

it's more complicated than a yes or a no; even as i am writing this, i'm currently playing it, and i've put 94 hours in in the past two weeks, apparently. fallout 76 was one i initially picked up on ps4 when it dropped; i've been through a lot of the highs and lows, and so my recommendation is: if you can find your own fun in things with friends or alone, you might like this game. however, that said- there is absolutely no reason this game should be as buggy as it is, 7 years out, over some of the most basic of things. it's a real shame that bethesda doesn't give this so much more technical support, too, as it could really be a good game- but it's ultimately stunted by some design choices, by lack of bug fixes, and a healthy dose of corporate greed for microtransactions. again- overall, i personally really enjoy my time with the game, but i can't in good conscience suggest it to others at full price. wait for a sale. there's a ton of fomo marketing at play with it, too, which frankly sucks.

qol is pretty bad. basic items not included (think fo4), you have to use the atom shop. server stability is not good, random disconnects with "server is not responding" pretty much kills emersion. basic graphics settings are not available (contrast/brightness, etc...) instead you have to monkey around with custom ini files hoping you can make the game playable. visuals are not ideal. shadows at mid-day render, while in them, a pitch black area where enemies are hidden. there are so many i don't have time to list them all. basically all of these little problems add up to make the game more annoying than fun. the only reason i am still playing is i wanted to give the game a fair chance so i told myself, "self, i will play to level 100 and then see". well i'm at level 68 but with the random server disconnects i may not make it.

buen juego. un rpg de acción de tipo soulslike que nosinvita a vivir una aventura durante una revolución francesa alternativa en la cual luis xvi echa mano de un ejército de autómatas para recuperar el orden del país. básicamente es un soulslike de serie b, con muy buen acabado gráfico y de diseño, pero que cojea un poco en cuanto a la dificultad de los jefes ya que no son combates para nada desafiantes. aún así es un juego entretenido que te va a dar algo más de 20 horas de entretenimiento por poco dinero.

très bon jeu mais optimisation du moteur graphique catastrophique ! bon gameplay, bonne histoire, bon sous like, mais l'utilisation du moteur graphique est mauvais. le studio spiders aurait dû faire un jeu plus court et mettre les moyens pour travailler sur le moteur graphique..

steelrising es un soulslike que innova muy poco (alguna de las armas son algo originales, y puedes saltar y tienes algo más de movilidad que en otros juegos del género) pero ejecuta bien lo que se propone hacer. para mi tiene una virtud innegable en su ambientación, ya que la francia revolucionaria está desgraciadamente muy poco explorada en juegos o películas y es un periodo fascinante, incluso en esta versión fantástica. caminar por las calles del parís de la época, visitar palacios y lugares importantes como la bastilla o versalles, es genial. la historia en sí está bien pero tampoco es para tirar cohetes, pero sin duda está mejor contada que en cualquier souls, cuenta con diálogos y decisiones que afectan al final de la historia, etc. y el combate es ágil y fluido, con una personalización del personaje más simple que en un souls pero que funciona decentemente bien. gráficamente no pasará a la historia, especialmente algunas animaciones faciales flojean un poco, pero como ya dije la ambientación me fascina y está muy bien recreada, con lo que a nivel visual acaba resultando un juego distinto y bienvenido. quizás algunas zonas se hacen demasiado parecidas entre sí. a nivel de sonido está todo lo bien que se puede esperar, tanto en efectos, como voces (me gusta que intercalen palabras en francés) como en el apartado musical. y en cuanto a bugs, he encontrado muy pocos y todos han sido bastante irrelevantes, lo cual siempre es **** resultado es que, sin ser un juego memorable, sin duda es un buen juego en su género. un 7.

leggendo le recensioni pensavo fosse veramente fatto male male però devo dire che tutto sommato è piacevole,certo non è un capolavoro il combat system è legnoso,la storia non è un grande e il level design si poteva fare meglio,però l'immaginario e fantastico e la mobilita di aegis con tutti i suoi gadget è straordinaria, il livello di difficoltà generale per essere un souls non è il massimo l'ho trovato abbastanza semplice,i titani magnifici, consigliato a chi non trova nulla di meglio

spiders, why??? why, after releasing a masterpiece real rpg, you then wasted a bunch of time on soulslike????? you could have done greedfall 2 in the meantime, which we are all very much looking forward to =). i have no complaints about steelrising as a soulslike, as it's basically a pretty boring genre of games that i very rarely finish. steelrising has very resourceful unique abilities and combat, the gorgeous visuals create a memorable atmosphere, and the story is great (well, only among soulslikes, again). overall, i liked the game in general, but i still don't understand why such an interesting setting was wasted on a soulslake instead of making a real rpg =(
просто круто! в игре своя атмосфера, хорошая история, довольно забавное оружие и очень интересные боссы))) новое веяние soulslike игр!

solid, enjoyable game, a soulslike but with difficulty settings which can make it pretty light. - graphics is ok, but the game is badly optimized with lag spikes - animations are good but with a few more combos or special moves it could be even better - the story is ok too, pretty nice side quests and ideas, with a little more thinking it could have been great; especially if you are interested in french revolution history - combat is ok, good moves, good ideas; sound and music great overall i enjoyed this game, can be played once but not an instant classic or favorite.

what a disappointment. quality-wise, it has nothing to do with greedfall. everything in this game feels rushed, unpolished, and unfinished. performance is terrible. the art design is good and the plot interesting, but all its other departs are poorly executed —a low-quality product.

fransız devrimi'nde mekanik bir robotu yönettiğimiz, görsel tasarımıyla göz doldursa da dövüş mekanikleri çok keskin olmayan, bu nedenle bir yerden sonra sıkan soulslike oyun. ben parry yapabildiğimiz yelpazeye benzer şeyi kullandım. element hasarı veren, uzun menzilli olan silahlar da vardı ama bu oyun çok hızlı olması nedeniyle parry yapmak keyifli olur gibi geldi. karakterimi de ona göre dancer sınıfından seçtim zaten. oyunun ortalarına kadar çeşitlilik iyi gidiyordu aslında. yeni düşman çeşitleri geliyor, yeni yetenekler geliyor, kullanmasam da yeni silahlar ediniyordum. ama ortalardan sonra özellikle yeni düşman çeşidi gelmemeye başladı. boss'lar farklıydı bir tek. ancak onların da çok kolay olduğunu söylemem gerek. çoğunu tek denemede geçtim. böyle soulslike oyun mu olur? boss'lar hiç agresif değiller. çok az vuruyorlar, genelde mal gibi vuruşlarınızı yiyip duruyorlar. boss savaşlarını hiç beğenmedim. bir önceki souls oyunum thymesia'nın fersah fersah gerisinde bu anlamda. yan görevler falan da vardı ama oyun çok sarmadığı için uğraşmadım. hatta son 2 bölümü etraftaki düşmanlarla hiç uğraşmadan direkt boss'lara koşarak geçtim. netice itibariyle olmak istediği şeyi tam olamamış ,eksik bir oyun.

((**to get this out of the way at the start, i played this on the steamdeck. it isn't verified, but the only issue noted was small text. i would add another issue: this game for me crashed quite a bit in the later game locations.)) review: this game is hard to review. i love action rpgs, and this studio's last title, greedfall, was alright and had some interesting ideas, particularly with the setting and basic story. and that might be steelrising's best aspect- the setting is a really nice looking revolution era france instead of the typical dark fantasy of similar games. the combat and builds are alright, but had all the flow of dark souls 2 (and even has the two-tiers for healing items). this was good for me, as that is the only dark souls game i've managed to finish so far. still, it's really rough around the edges, and the side missions were mostly bland and were piled on at a certain point before the late game rather than more evenly placed throughout (or they would be available but you couldn't advance them until you advanced the main game when it returns to that location anyway). still, i enjoyed it enough to play it thru to the end, so for me, that counts for a lot.

i love the soulslike genre. this game is not the worst in the genre, but far from the best. the plot may be of interest to those who are well versed in the history of the great french revolution. the plot was not very interesting to me. the bosses are completely uninteresting. the game turned out to be simple. but the game still has some special atmosphere and this is a plus.

easily the best game i've played this year. beautiful visuals, stellar gameplay, and level design, great fun combat, brilliantly reach story. and it's one of the best soulslike games i've ever played.

overall: ★★★★★ – who knew being a tiny cat in a big cyberpunk city could feel so emotional? 🐾💖 gameplay: ★★★★★ – jumping, climbing, sneaking… so smooth and fun! 😸 story: ★★★★☆ – short but really touching, loved the little mysteries 🕵️‍♂️✨ visuals: ★★★★★ – neon streets, tiny details everywhere, just wow 🌃😍 music & sound: ★★★★★ – super immersive, perfectly sets the mood 🎶💫 atmosphere: ★★★★★ – lonely but magical, i got completely lost in it 🌌🐾 fun factor: ★★★★★ – honestly, just being a cat exploring this world is pure joy 😹 ✅ recommended for: cat lovers 🐱, explorers 🌍, indie fans 🎮, or anyone who wants a short emotional journey 💖

phew.. this really hurts me but i think overall i wouldn't really recommend it. soft spoilers in the review (mostly just settings) the first level is amazing, exploring the town, meeting robots and learning about how they function is great. you can explore with great verticality to either walk on the streets or over the rooftops. but unfortunately it falls off pretty hard after that, the sewers are intense and i liked the vibe but the gameplay was stale and very linear. the town in the sewers is also just a path to go further up untill we reach midtown. midtown was the most disapointing aspect for me because while it is pretty big there is just so much less in it. you can't really climb up anywhere to explore and outside of the main quest you can ignore everyone in it unless you really want to see what their one line of dialoge will be. the game is nice, i think a lot of people can have fun playing this but for me personally once the charm of "awe cute cat" has worn off i really felt that most of the developers love and attention was put into the first area.

very short (5h), storywise very bland and predictable, super linear and very, very easy. it's a cute concept and visually superb, but i would only recommend it when it's on sale. if this was a proof of concept and there's gonna be a sqeuel then i can't wait, but i don't think so.

i have to say no as i think £23.99 is a quite frankly extortionate amount of money for the game. on sale at 50% off its worth it but i wouldn't pay more. while exploring as a cat does have a lot of charm to it, the ending was the most infuriating. spoilers ahead. you get to the top, you unseal the city, but i get to see almost nothing of what happened to my friends i made along the way. i spent so much time in the low area, was shopping with them, bartering, and all i see is one robot happy. just feels a bit, of a shame. my companion b-12 kills himself at the end for the greater good. bit of a boring plot device that i kind of saw coming. once we get back to the outside, what other purpose would he serve, all the humans are dead. again his whole demise felt a bit, rushed. the whole final level felt rushed and just a bit, boring. it was underwhelming and sad. i really liked my cat player and i think its a good game at half the price. but i finished it in 6h30m didn't focus on collectibles but tried to explore everywhere. there was a lot of room with the world they had created to expand upon it with the characters and allow me to revisit or, see people rise up against the peacekeepers and the sentinels, things like that. i don't know why they felt a need to cut the game so short. i hope stray 2 is a longer game that feels more polished in how it looks after its characters. it felt like certain decisions were made simply because they didn't want to have to animate or do x thing.

to be honest my expectations were higher, i bought this game for like over 40 bucks something (? not sure it was july/august 2022) and to be honest its just kinda boring, might be a skill issue though. you'll probably still love this game because there's a cat

buggy!!!! - defluxor doesnt work (already tried rebinding on both keyboard and controller + restart checkpoint) so had to reload story chapter - after reloading story chapter, lost all item progress (sheet music, pass codes, items for specific quests etc.) - lost all character progress (meeting certain npcs for quests/achievements to proc) - clipped through floors at certain spots when trying to do quests - npcs needed for quest wouldn't move/walk/give items - bugs only start after the rooftop/outsiders arc for me good story, very cute protagonist, great music, very sick character designs for npcs (ily morusque), ok-ish graphics (very pretty atmosphere but looks weird up close in my opinion), ok-ish performance/optimisation (frames would drop at certain areas, especially before chase scenes) but sooo buggy for a game that has been released for 3yr+, cost 29$(?) and won awards buy at ur own risk and on discount!!! :d

storia e narrazione molto convincente . molto intuitivo capire cosa bisogna fare, fin dai primi minuti di gioco. le movenze del gatto sono un qualcosa di unico . molto bello il rapporto tra il gatto e i robot che incontra , sopratutto la sua mascotte che spesso risulta indispensabile per progredire nella storia. molto bella l’idea di creare una lingua incomprensibile , ma grazie al traduttore è tutto molto comprensibile anche in italiano . saltare sui tetti , per capire come raggiungere alcuni luoghi , alla ricerca di oggetti o aiuti non risulta noioso. il suono e le ambientazioni sono ben curate ed esplorare è sempre un piacere sia per gli occhi che per la mente . capire cosa fare risulta semplice , farlo , delle volte necessita ingegno ed investigazione , anche se non troppo difficile. molto belle anche le situazionid’azione , dove bisogna correre , saltare e successivamente anche eliminare i nemici con un’arma costruita dagli amici robot. un gioco come questo mi ha piacevolmente lasciato sorpreso. giocato su un mac mini m2pro al massimodella qualità grafica a1920 x 1080 sempre fluido . purtroppo in un solo caso il gioco si è bloccato. consiglio a tutti coloro che amano esplorare , ragionare e vivere una storia ben narrata , ma che odino quel genere di giochi dove bisogna spesso sparare. finalmente un gioco che si discosta dal solito genere spara salta e corri.

a wonderful game with a great story and graphics. it was truly enjoyable to play, and i'm happy to say it was the best game i've ever played. by the end, i couldn't stop crying. i honestly recommend it.
